Customer Support, Insurance Division

---

To: max@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry about wheat transport from Odessa to Barcelona in early August
Timestamp: 2023-07-01 13:42
Body: Dear Max, Yes, we can accommodate the shipment in early August. Regarding the demurrage terms, we operate under the standard FIOS terms. Please confirm if you would like me to send you the full contract for your perusal. All the best, Vicente

---

To: vicente@shippingco.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry about wheat transport from Odessa to Barcelona in early August

---

To: max@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry about wheat transport from Odessa to Barcelona in early August
Timestamp: 2023-07-02 14:15

Hi Jose,                    My team and I are busy planning a 3,200MT shipment of palm kernels from Pointe Noire to Antwerp next month. If we need to load in a hurry, what kind of rates would you offer us?                    Regards,                    Karen
Email 2:
Jose,                    Glad we've touched base.                    I'd like to place a 1,600MT shipment of soya beans in January 2015 to deliver to Antwerp. I'd like to use your ship. Please send me a quote.                    Kind regards,                    Karen

Jose,
Thanks for the quotes! They're in line with our budget, but we'd like to speak to you directly about the details. Please call us at +1 555-555-5555
Warm regards,
Karen


<Email 3>:
Jose,
Great to hear from you! We'd like to book 1,600MT of soya beans on your ship to be delivered to Antwerp in the first week of March 2015. Are you able to provide a written quote?
Best,
Karen

To: kim@shippingco.com
Subject: Availability Inquiry for 12,000 DWT Coaster

Body: Dear Ms. Kim,

Could you please confirm the availability of a 12,000 DWT coaster, and what's the earliest possible sailing date?

Minh

---

From: james@shippingco.com
To: minh@example.com
Subject: Re: Availability Inquiry for 12,000 DWT Coaster
Timestamp: 2023-03-02 10:15
Body: Hi Minh,

Thank you for your email. The earliest available date for the 12,000 DWT coaster is 2023-10-10. The vessel will be ready to load cargo on this date, with the specific loading and discharging ports to be discussed further as needed. However, this time slot might not align with your required timeline. The next available date for booking the coaster would be 2023-11-10.

Please let me know if this fits within your schedule or if you have any other questions.

Best,
James

<Email 4>:

    """
    if ind == None:
        return get_top_thread(0)
    ind_str = str(ind)
    while ind != 0:
        for i in sorted(
            list(Email.get_by_level_ind(ind)[0]),
            key=lambda item: item[1],

Hi Derek,                    We have received an inquiry for the movement of 15kMT of LPG from Spain to Mombasa in July. I would like to know if there is any availability for this shipment, and what your pricing will be. Could you let me know as soon as possible?                    Regards,                    Ajay
Email 2:
We have a possibility of a medium-term charter (about a month). LPG from Spain to Mombasa and TANZANIA. If you can have it please send all pricing, and detailed information regarding the ship and your management conditions. We are looking forward to your reply. Best regards, Joseph Tensu

**djagiad@gmail.com**
**djomson@hotmail.com**

Barter or similar type of shipping would be another way to get product, basically you are trading something for the shipping, typically a product that the shipper wants. 
I have not used this type of transaction so I don't know about the legalities or security in terms of the recipient. 
There are companies that specialize in these types of transactions so I would not recommend going it alone.

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Mr. Peter,                    We have a cargo to ship from Mundra to Long Beach. I do not anticipate any berth congestion in either port, but would you still please confirm that?                    Many thanks,                    Michael
Email 2:
Hi Michael,                  Hope you are well.                      As far as Mundra is concerned, there will be no berth congestion (whether it be monthly or weekly) in any month of this year.                 Regarding the port of Long Beach, the container volume is consistently increasing month on month. It will also increase in the coming month. However, we can see that in February 2019, there were 8 ETDs, whereas in January 2019 there were 7 ETDs. The transhipment movement from West Africa & other major US destinations to Long Beach will increase by more than 10% this year. Hence we may see less berth congestion in the months of January, February & March 2019. However, the probability of berth congestion in April and onward months is very high as long as the CBP do not relax any of their existing regulations to reduce the dwell
Email 3:
Hi Michael, 
    Here is a comparison between January to December 2018 and January to December 2017. 
    To view this email on the web, go to https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=605746.


8 I D        ARRIVAL TYPE         VOLUME (LCL/FCL/EMPTY) JAN 2017   JAN 2018   DIF 
TLG327      OFFD ANCHOR         LCL           185         445     140 
TLG062      OFFD ANCHOR         LCL           112         235     123 
TLG188      OFFD ANCHOR         LCL           100         165     65 
CMACTI      OFFD ANCHOR         LCL           151         165     14 
TML 45      OFFD ANCHOR         L
Email 4:
Hi
Kindly note the following changes in view of the proposed cut off 
· All STS, which were used in the past to eliminate congestion, will cease by end of March 2019. 
· Due to many more factors like larger volume, berth congestion & diversification, the terminal now prefers containers which are loaded on to wagons, trucks, rail heads, special containers (Transponders, Chilled, Refrigerated, etc.) as well as containers which are to be exported via Ocean Terminal, Pier 400, Long Beach Container Terminal (LBCT), ……………… the list goes on. 
· Longer term (year on year), terminal hopes that terminal will be able to achieve more in terms of more Gate out/container return, which is the only way the terminal will be able to handle more volume. 
· With the above changes, the terminal will be able to
output_text:
From: michael@logisticscorp.com
To: peter@portoperations.com
Subject: Query on Berth Congestion at Mundra and Long Beach Ports
Timestamp: 2019-01-01 08:00
Body: Hi Mr. Peter, We need to arrange a shipment from Mundra to Long Beach. Could you please confirm whether there is any anticipated berth congestion at either port? Many thanks, Michael

---

From: peter@portoperations.com
To: michael@logisticscorp.com
Subject: Re: Query on Berth Congestion at Mundra and Long Beach Ports
Timestamp: 2019-01-02 09:30
Body: Hi Michael, Hope you are well. There will be no berth congestion at Mundra throughout the year. However, for Long Beach, the container volume is increasing consistently. The transshipment movement from West Africa and other major US destinations to Long Beach will cause an increase of more than 10% this year. Although there's less congestion expected in the early months, starting from April, the prospects of high congestion are significant unless CBP regulations are adjusted. Regards, Peter

---

From: peter@portoperations.com
To: michael@logisticscorp.com
Subject: Additional Information on Port Operations
Timestamp: 2019-01-03 10:15
Body: Hi Michael, Here is a brief comparison overview of container handling for the previous years at Long Beach, showing a tangible increase in volume. Detailed data cannot be provided here, but you can view it through our official port operations link at https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=605746. Regards, Peter

---

From: peter@portoperations.com
To: michael@logisticscorp.com
Subject: Upcoming Changes at Long Beach Port
Timestamp: 2019-01-04 15:20
Body: Hi, Please be informed of the following upcoming changes at Long Beach Port: All Ship-to-Shore (STS) operations used previously to alleviate congestion will cease by the end of March 2019. The focus will thus shift towards optimizing logistics like using wagons, trucks, and special containers (e.g., Transponders, Chilled, Refrigerated) for exports at Ocean Terminal, Pier 400, and Long Beach Container Terminal. The terminal aims to enhance efficiency and container throughput via improved gate operations. Regards, Peter

Analyze the email conversations to identify the common business activities. Common business activities include:

- Booking and Confirming: This activity involves the process of arranging a charter vessel to transport goods from one location to another. It includes negotiations, contract signing, and the finalization of the charter agreement.

- Rates and Pricing: This activity focuses on the exchange of information regarding the rate and pricing for the charter vessel. It involves discussions and proposals from the ship owner regarding the cost of the vessel, including any additional charges or fees.

- Arrival and Delivery: This activity deals with the transportation and delivery of the charter vessel from the ship owner to the designated location. It includes discussions about the schedule, loading and unloading

From: charles@example.com
To: steve@example.com
Subject: Charles' Proposal
Timestamp: 2023-09-01 08:00
Body: Dear Steve,

I hope this message finds you well. I am reaching out to discuss the potential costs associated with moving our cargo. Please consider the following aspects throughout our communication:
- Carrier
- Charterer
- Ship Type
- Feeder line
- Terms
- Nominated vessel
- Berth
- Draft
- Quantity
- Destination
- ETA
- D/O
- Payment
- Laytime
- Harbour Charges
- L/D Charges
- Line Speed
- Chargeable weight
- Discharge Delivery
- Additional details and context
- Timing considerations

As an economist with extensive industry connections, I'm excited about the prospects of collaborating with you. Looking forward to your insights on how we might proceed.

All the best,
Charles

---

From: rob@example.com
To: charles@example.com
Subject: Re: Charles' Proposal
Timestamp: 2023-09-02 10:30
Body: Hi Charles,

Thank you for your detailed proposal. Everything looks good, but could you please confirm whether your insurance covers what we are looking to do? Additionally, please clarify the pricing and terms associated with the insurance.

Regards,
Rob

---

From: charles@example.com
To: rob@example.com
Subject: Re: Charles' Proposal
Timestamp: 2023-09-03 09:15
Body: Hi Rob,

Thank you for your response. Regarding your query, the insurance policy I am quoting does not cover cargo loss. You can review my policy details here: [Ship the Box Insurance Policy](https://uploads-ssl.webflow.com/5f0f50a4d746a5642fe1f64a/5f4f66f7d957cd00018cd78e_Ship_the_box_Insurance_Policy.pdf).

Please note, as per our agreement, any claims will be the responsibility of you and the broker, while I provide compensation. Regarding the pricing and terms, these areas are agreeable and can be discussed further if necessary.

You have a couple of options:
1. Liaise with the ship's broker for market pricing. Be aware that the favorable pricing might not prompt quick responses.
2. Place the current proposal on your sales sheet and forward it to my agents.

Looking forward to your decision.

Best,
Charles

---

From: charles@example.com
To: rob@example.com
Subject: Re: Charles' Proposal
Timestamp: 2023-09-04 14:20
Body: Hi Rob,

Just checking in on the above. Could you please send a Non-Acknowledgement (NAK) to my agent regarding the current status? Apologies for any delays, and please let me know if there are any unresolved questions or further information you need.

Regards,
Charles

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Ms. Morris,                    We have an enquiry for 13,000MT of rice from Colombo to Matadi. Can you give us a berth congestion forecast and how does your laytime allowance work in case of port delays?                    Many thanks,                    Robert
Email 2:
Matadi is a very busy port with cargoes often backed up at berth. There is no guaranteed transit time to discharge ships. It is typical for ships to be waiting in line from 2-4 days to get to berth and there is not a predictable number of ships in line to discharge as ships can come at any time without warning.
                
                It is typical to run back up and sometimes 2 berths simultaneously. When two berths are available, the berthing order is typically handled by the Terminal based on when the ship can reach the berth. In the event that your vessel can reach the berth on the day that is scheduled for your vessel, your berth time will likely be honored. If you are late due to port congestion and cannot reach the berth that is reserved for you, your berth may be given to another ship and you will have to wait in line for the next
output_text:
From: robert@shippingco.com
To: morris@portauthority.com
Subject: Enquiry: Rice Shipment from Colombo to Matadi (13,000MT)
Timestamp: 2023-03-05 09:15
Body: Hi Ms. Morris,

We have an enquiry for a shipment of 13,000MT of rice, routed from Colombo to Matadi. Could you provide a berth congestion forecast for Matadi? Additionally, how does the laytime allowance work in case of port delays at Matadi?

Many thanks,
Robert

---

From: morris@portauthority.com
To: robert@shippingco.com
Subject: RE: Enquiry: Rice Shipment from Colombo to Matadi (13,000MT)
Timestamp: 2023-03-06 10:30
Body: Dear Robert,

Matadi is frequently busy with cargoes often experiencing congestion. There is no guaranteed transit time for discharging ships, and it is typical for vessels to wait from 2-4 days to berth. The number of ships in line is unpredictable, as vessels can arrive without prior notice. When two berths are open, the terminal typically manages the berthing order based on the arrival timing of the ships. If your vessel reaches the berth as scheduled, your slot will likely be honored. However, if your arriving ship is delayed due to port congestion and misses the reserved berth time, it may be reassigned to another vessel, and yours will need to wait for the next available slot.

Best regards,
Ms. Morris

Robert

---

From: shippingagent@example.com
To: robert@example.com
Subject: Re: Urgent Cargo Shipment Inquiry
Timestamp: 2023-11-01 14:15
Body: Dear Mr. Robert,

Unfortunately, your cargo from the previous shipment could not be loaded due to late arrival at the port, which is not uncommon in our industry. Please refer to the specific reasons in the business documents. The ship and crew, however, are in good condition. Thank you for your understanding and choosing our service.

Regarding your current inquiry, we confirm that we can arrange the shipment of butter on a CIF basis. Our vessel types that are available include Container Ships and Bulk Carriers. The earliest laycan period we can offer is from November 15th to November 20th.
Best Regards,
Mr. Johnson
Shipping Agent

To: robert@example.com
Subject: Updated Shipping Options
Timestamp: 2023-11-01 14:25
Body: Dear Mr. Robert,

1. CIF (cost, insurance, and freight) to New York
2. CLC (cost and large carrier) to New York
3. CFR (cost and freight) to New York

Please let us know your preference so we can finalize the arrangements.
Thank you for your time and choosing our services.
Best Regards,
Mr. Johnson
Shipping Agent

From: lktmlts@csus.com
To: court@federalclaims.us
Subject: Motion to Compel Deposition of United States Attorney
Timestamp: 2019-10-24 09:00
Body: Case Number: LPCYRFFCKtJT

Your Honors,

On behalf of Indian Towers, LLC, we submit this correspondence to express our intentions to compel the deposition of United States Attorney, David Pincus. The deposition has been requested for October 29, 2019. We believe his testimony is crucial for our case, however, we acknowledge that we have not sufficiently demonstrated good cause as required. Consequently, we submit this letter to outline our reasons and seek your approval for said deposition.

---

From: court@federalclaims.us
To: lktmlts@csus.com
Subject: Re: Motion to Compel Deposition of United States Attorney
Timestamp: 2019-10-24 15:30
Body: Dear Kirk M. Stansel, Peter A. Sickels, and Joshua R. Hasty,

We have received your request to compel the deposition of Mr. David Pincus scheduled for October 29, 2019. After an initial review, it is noted that the motion lacks the demonstration of good cause. As such, unless further justification is provided, the motion is likely to be denied.

Email 1:
Hi Yasmina,                    We have 7.4kMT of base oil ready in Malta and is it ready for a shipment to Yemen? How long would it take to prepare the necessary documents and can you accept delivery within 48 hours?                    Yours sincerely,                    Mabena
Email 2:
Hi Mabena,                    Thank you for your email.                    Unfortunately, the Yemen Embassy in Malta does not accept any application. For a visa application, you must go through the company you are working for or a company that will sponsor your trip.                    Yours sincerely,                    Yasmina
Email 3:
```Hi,             

Thanks for the info about the company but there are only two people in Malta and they are both married. For the company, what if I am not working for it? But the company can be the sponsor for me to get the Yemen visa. Can you tell me who to get in contact with? Do you know any sponsor company that I can contact?                    Yours sincerely,                    Mabena
```
Email 4:
Thanks for the info, I’ll go there today and I will also go to the embassy to make some enquiries.                        Regards,                    Mabena
```
Email 5:
```Hi Yasmina,                        

I was in Malta yesterday. I went to the embassy and the people there are kind. They have informed me that I don’t need any sponsor. But to get a visa it costs 118 USD.                            Hope this information helps you.                            Yours sincerely,                        

                            Mabena
```

Yasmina

Yours sincerely,
Mabena

Email 1:
Good day,                    Would you be able to handle a 2,000MT cargo of oil from Singapore to Hamburg next month?                    Thanks,                    Anthony
Email 2:
Good day Anthony,                    Below are some prelim. info for your consideration.                    We are in need of a shipment of Fuel Oil (0.5% Sulphur) with 180day Bunker credit at Hamburg.                    Time charter please for the above.                    Let me have a TEU count please, we may be able to fix a further vessel for containers to follow.                    We would also need following documentation sent by DHL express on the morning the vessel is due to berth:                    a) Invoices for cargo                    b) B/L’s (Blanket basis)                    c) Inspection Certificate                    d) Agency Copy of manifest                    e) Charter Party                    Let me know what you suggest.                    I can be contacted as follows:                    Email:address@hidden                    Or direct by Tel No: +852 2869 2131 (Direct).                    Thanks,                    Anthony
Email 3:
Good day,                    Would you be able to handle a 2,000MT cargo of oil from Singapore to Hamburg next month?                    Thanks,                    Anthony

Came from:                    Anne Dear                  Received by:                    William Lee

Response 1:
Okay..                     2000 MT Fuel Oil @0.5% sulphur for charter to Hamburg with 180 days bunkers credit can be arranged.                     Let me know your detailed charterparty conditions and details.                     For the charterparty conditions, I propose the usual terms and conditions.                     Your vessel must be compliant to the MARPOL 73/78 with equipment for the separation of oily waste and to dispose of waste at sea, alternatively, a system capable of containing, recovering, and subsequently processing the oily residue on board.                     Vessel must be certified as per MARPOL 73/78.                     Your vessel shall be sea worthy
output_text:
From: anthony@example.com
To: william.lee@example.com
Subject: Inquiry for cargo shipment from Singapore to Hamburg
Timestamp: 2023-09-04 08:30
Body: Good day,

Would you be able to handle a 2,000MT cargo of oil from Singapore to Hamburg next month?

Thanks,
Anthony

---

From: william.lee@example.com
To: anthony@example.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry for cargo shipment from Singapore to Hamburg
Timestamp: 2023-09-05 10:15
Body: Good day Anthony,

Thank you for your inquiry. We can arrange the transport of 2,000 MT of Fuel Oil with 0.5% Sulphur on a time charter basis to Hamburg, with 180 days bunker credit. Please provide the TEU count as we might be able to arrange an additional vessel for container shipment.

Furthermore, please ensure that the following documents are sent via DHL Express on the morning the vessel is due to berth at Hamburg:
a) Invoices for cargo
b) Bill of Lading (B/L), blanket basis
c) Inspection Certificate
d) Agency Copy of manifest
e) Charter Party

Please let us know your suggestions and confirm if you agree with these terms.

You can contact me directly at Tel No: +852 2869 2131 or via email.

Best regards,
William Lee

---

From: anthony@example.com
To: william.lee@example.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry for cargo shipment from Singapore to Hamburg
Timestamp: 2023-09-06 09:45
Body: Hello,

Confirming receipt of your proposal. Please provide me with the usual terms and conditions of the charter party. It is imperative that your vessel complies with MARPOL 73/78 regulations, equipped for the separation of oily waste and the containment, recovery, and processing of oily residue onboard.

The vessel must be certified as per MARPOL 73/78 and seaworthy.

Awaiting your detailed charter party conditions.

Best,
Anthony

This is especially important because the vessel concerned has to clear their port of 90,000 tonnes of cargo at the same time as loading the product in question.
As such, it is best to keep the loading plan as close to the current laycan as possible for reasons of space and availability.
That's why I would be keen to get your laycan in a day or so.
Thank you again for your assistance.
Mike

Email 1:
Hi Mr. Pandey,                    For the 15kt shipment of methanol from Rotterdam to Montevideo, can you provide some vessel options basis CFR and provide rate?                    Best regards,                    Andy
Email 2:
If I take Ethanol (44 kg/cu m and 22 cts per lt) 250 MTs cargo; What would be the total cost of freight if I take the cargo out of Moin-Honduras, and the shipping time will be 5 days.                    Can you please give me the figures before today midnight?                    I will wait for your email.
Thank you,
Email 3:
I assume this is for shipping to Montevideo, Uruguay?
[Short answer] Considering the cost of Ethanol at USD 700.00/t, loading at Moin and routing via Mediterranean and Atlantic Ocean, then the FOB Hamburg is USD 420.00/t with a port rotation in Moin, Santos, and Constanza.

[Long answer] We have to send a complete quotation to understand the entire situation and its respective commercial requirements in order to provide a complete and accurate quotation to our client.
Our company can offer competitive shipping costs and services for transporting Ethanol to Montevideo, Uruguay. We are happy to provide more information and a detailed quote upon request.

Based on your information, I can provide you with an estimate for the shipping cost of 250 MT of Ethanol from Moin, Honduras to Montevideo, Uruguay.
Please note that the shipping cost may
output_text:
From: andy@example.com
To: mr.pandey@shippingco.com
Subject: Request for Vessel Options and Rate for Methanol Shipment
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 08:00
Body: Hi Mr. Pandey,

Could you provide some vessel options for a 15kt shipment of methanol from Rotterdam to Montevideo under CFR terms and the corresponding rate?

Best regards,
Andy

---

From: andy@example.com
To: mr.pandey@shippingco.com
Subject: Inquiry About Ethanol Shipment Terms
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 09:15
Body: If we consider a 250 MT cargo of Ethanol (44 kg/cu m density and 22 cents per liter), transported from Moin, Honduras; What would be the total cost of freight, and the shipping time if it is 5 days?

Can you please provide the figures before midnight today?

Thank you.

---

From: mr.pandey@shippingco.com
To: andy@example.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry About Ethanol Shipment Terms
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 17:45
Body: I assume this is for shipping to Montevideo, Uruguay.

Based on the given data, and assuming the routing via Mediterranean and Atlantic Ocean, our preliminary assessment suggests a freight cost estimate of USD 700.00 per ton for Ethanol loading at Moin. The mentioned FOB in Hamburg rate of USD 420.00 per ton would apply with a port rotation in Moin, Santos, and Constanza.

For a detailed and accurate quotation covering all your commercial requirements, please allow us to send a complete proposal. We are happy to provide more information and discuss competitive shipping costs to transport Ethanol to Montevideo, Uruguay.

Best regards,
Mr. Pandey

Patrick

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Zara,                    Hello. We can load the gasoline at Jubail April 15th. What can you do about voyage charter terms?                    Regards,                    James                    NOTE: A typical voyage charter (demurrage) contract has 24 hours as the benchmark for demurrage/laytime (load time to commence). Beyond this point the charterer becomes liable for demurrage for each day over the 24 hour benchmark.                    Now reply to Email C in the same style.                    Email D:                    Dear Captain Ford,                    I have noted your early availability and am trying to find if any interest at this time for gasoline from Jubail. What’s your freight?                    Regards,                    Mona                    NOTE: Fuel oil is 100% payment by letter of credit, so the freight clause has no significance.                    In the next step, you’ll learn about the typical documentation
Email 2:
Email 2
We can deliver the gasoline on a 35 day FOB basis but can supply a voyage charter at 35 days’ notice for what we can supply. Our freight is 3,000 to 3,200 free on board Rotterdam.                    I await your response.                    NOTE: The 3,200 FOB figure is a way of saying they can load the fuel oil at Jubail April 15th (35 days’ notice from your date) for a freight of 3,200 free on board Rotterdam (3,200 $per metric ton from Jubail to Rotterdam), provided they are given a voyage charter (time charter for fuel oil). The 35-day notice FOB is your way of saying they cannot get a voyage charter or that it takes 35 days to get a voyage charter. 3,200$ fob Rotterdam would only be a loading
Email 3:
Email 3
We would like to confirm the price of the gasoline of 80,000 metric tons CIF Rotterdam at 7,000$per metric ton. What is your availability for the gasoline? Regarding the freight and voyage charter, we can arrange this later, if you accept the price. Please advise, my colleague wants to confirm your price and he expects to hear from you soon. NOTE: You want to confirm the price of the gasoline, which you did by saying “80,000 metric tons CIF Rotterdam at 7,000$ per metric ton.” By offering “What is your availability for the gasoline?” you are showing that you are serious about the gasoline. You are also giving the impression that it is the principal who is asking, and thus playing into the principal’s ego, which you did by saying, “My colleague wants to confirm your price and he expects to hear from
Email 4:
Dear Mona, We are sorry to learn that you cannot arrange our gasoline supply via FOB Rotterdam. We understand your position and are willing to load the gasoline in 35 days and on a voyage charter for what we can supply. However, to meet your request, our principal would like to buy the gasoline on a 25 day FOB basis, but we would like to know that you will accept the price of 7,000$per metric ton. You may offer CIF Rotterdam in place of FOB Rotterdam at no increase in freight. Our principal expects to hear from you soon and prefers payment by letter of credit. We have noted your availability for April 15th. NOTE: At the start, you’re again trying to show that you’re serious about the gasoline by saying “We are sorry to learn that you cannot arrange our gasoline supply via FOB Rotterdam,” “We have noted your

Best regards,
James

Regards,
Mona

---

From: captain.ford@shippingco.com
To: mona@brokeragefirm.com
Subject: Freight and Charter Information
Timestamp: 2023-03-13 10:15
Body: Dear Mona,

We can deliver gasoline on a 35-day FOB basis and provide a voyage charter with 35 days' notice. Our freight rate ranges from $3,000 to $3,200 per metric ton, free on board Rotterdam.

I await your response.

Best regards,
Captain Ford

---

From: zara@tradingcompany.com
To: james@shippingco.com
Subject: Confirmation of Gasoline Purchase CIF Rotterdam
Timestamp: 2023-03-14 08:20
Body: Dear James,

We would like to confirm the purchase of 80,000 metric tons of gasoline CIF Rotterdam at $7,000 per metric ton. Could you confirm your availability? We will discuss freight and charter details subsequently.

Please advise soon as my colleague is keen to confirm this price.

Best regards,
Zara

---

From: james@shippingco.com
To: zara@tradingcompany.com
Subject: Re: Confirmation of Gasoline Purchase CIF Rotterdam
Timestamp: 2023-03-15 12:40
Body: Dear Zara,

We regret to inform you that arranging the gasoline supply via FOB Rotterdam is not feasible at this time. However, we are prepared to supply the gasoline in 35 days and on a voyage charter. We could alternatively supply CIF Rotterdam at the same freight rate of $7,000 per metric ton, overcoming the FOB limitation.

Please confirm that this arrangement is acceptable. Our principal would like to proceed with payment via letter of credit.

We await your prompt response.
Best regards,
James

Email 1:
Afternoon Mr. Saeed,                    We have a 5,000MT parcel of equipment to move from Montevideo to Isla Margarita, could you send a freight quote for me?                    Regards,                    Lacey
Email 2:
Hi Lacey!                                A good afternoon to you,                            As you see, we have received the message from
Peter regarding this move.                            We are now working on this.                           As soon as the details are ready we will send you the quotation.
                            Sorry for the delay, we are in the middle of a short holiday.
                            We will be happy to offer you the best solution for your cargo.
                            Best regards
                            Joseline
Email 3:
Hi Lacey!
I attach the quotation for your review.
Best regards.
You will remember that I sent you a quotation some days ago for
the shipment from Montevideo to the Vargas Free Zone (Isla Margarita,
Venezuela). I attach it for your review.
As I explained to you, your freight forwarder is using the
transportation of a passenger vessel for which they charge you a huge
amount of money (of course with a very high margin of profit for them).
However, we could suggest an alternative which could be very convenient
for you. The following is the technical background:
As you probably know, a number of passenger ships go from South America
to the Caribbean; among them is the MS Francy, which normally operates
between Brazil and Venezuela. This ship was specially chartered by a
tour operator from Dubai who asked us for help
Email 4:
Hi Lacey,
As a follow up of the quotation sent to you yesterday, I attach
here the quotation we did for the voyage from Montevideo to Isla Margarita
for your consideration. This voyage is scheduled to leave on 22 July with
estimated time of arrival 25 July in Isla Margarita, and there is a high
probability that it will be chartered. This vessel was used by a tour
operator from Dubai, who asked us to help them with the organisation of the
operation. I will ask them to contact you to give you all the details. This
operator was looking for containers, but we have done the calculation and
we see that there is no need to use containers, because the cost would be
too high in relation to the volume. So the only way would be by 20' pallets,
using the forkl
Email 5:
Hi Lacey,
the voyage scheduled from Montevideo to Isla Margarita (arrival 27 June) is
sold out and another vessel will be used for this operation. We have arranged
with a very good cargo vessel which will be leaving from the port of Valparaiso
on 24 July and arriving in Isla Margarita on 27 July. This cargo vessel will be
chartered by the tour operator for this voyage. We suggest the option by 20' flat
racks (pallets) to be loaded on the decks of the vessel and also by trucks to
be driven aboard and carried in the hold of the vessel. This will be the cheapest
way to move your cargo. Please let me know if you would like us to quote on this
proposal. The itinerary of the ship is as follows:
*Dep. Montevideo

Email 1:
Dear Mr. John,                    Could you please give a freight quote for loading 4,800MT of isopropanol from Houston to Cartagena?                    Regards,                    Markus
Email 2:
---------- Forwarded message ----------                    From: Markus Leidinger <markus.leidinger@*****.com>                    To: John <xxxxxxxxx@*****.com>                    Sent: Thu, Oct 21, 2021 at 2:12 PM                    Subject: RE: Isopropanol quote for Houston to Cartagena                    Dear Mr. John,                    Thank you for your reply.                    Could you please give us a freight quote for loading 4,800MT of isopropanol from Houston to Cartagena.                    I am waiting for your reply.                    Regards,                    Markus Leidinger
Email 3:
Hi Markus, I would like to have your assistance on this matter.
I have been in communication with an agent in Cartagena and he had informed me that isopropanol is extremely dangerous to transport and he is trying to deter us. He had offered an alternative product for the price you had provided.
The supplier is directly from the US and I think there is no reason for any third party to be involved in the transaction.
To be honest with you, the suppliers are not even prepared to sell the product at the prices you had quoted. For this reason, I don’t think we will be able to do business with you and appreciate if you will be kind enough to refund the advance payment of 1,200USD.
Thank you for your assistance in this matter.
Best Regards,
Mahesh Nambiar

Your shipment requirement are as below,                     Loading: 4800MT Isopropanol 99.9%                     FOB Price: 0.44USD/MT                     Origin: Houston                     Port of Destination: Cartagena                     Payment: TT advance 20% and balance against copy of B/L upon arrival.                     If you could provide your Bank details I will issue an Invoice on your name for advance payment.                     Regards,                     John (Eriq) Xu

Email 2:
Hey Mark,                    Hey Mark, thanks for your email, that looks good! How do we get these fixed dates confirmed? Is it best to enter them into your TMS directly?                    Cheers,                    Maria

<Email 3>:
Hey Maria,                    Hey Maria, the way I'd suggest it, we keep our chat about our fixed laycans and then forward it onto our IT guys. They would then be able to add this into the system for us, so that we both have fixed dates in place. Let me know if that’s ok?                    Cheers,                    Mark

- "Hey" starts email, it gives a sense of familiarity (e.g. you are communicating with a colleague, and not a complete stranger). See Habib and Miron (2014)

- 15

- "Hey" starts email, it gives a sense of familiarity (e.g. you are communicating with a colleague, and not a complete stranger). See Habib and Miron (2014)

 Hey Maria,                    Hey Maria, you know we always say we should make an effort to start the sentences with Hi or something similar, and avoid starting with Hey?                    Cheers,                    Mark

- Start emails with "Hey", "Hi", "Hey Maria", "Hello Maria", or any similar greeting.
- End emails with "Cheers"

                    Dear Mr. Bush,
                    Thank you for your inquiry.

                    In order to make an offer we would need to know the date of shipment, vessel, and cargo type. If the vessel is not chartered we can suggest the estimated rates.

                    If the vessel is already on charter and the vessel type is known then we can suggest the freight rate.

                    In the above two cases, an offer is being provided but it is not a fixed rate.

                    If the vessel has already been loaded, then a time charter rate must be negotiated.

                    In the case of a time charter, the vessel owner may expect at least 2 voyages to break even.

A booking reference number is a unique number that is given to a customer when they make a booking for a product or service. The number is used to identify the customer's booking and to keep track of it. The number may be given to the customer in a confirmation email or letter, or it may be printed on the customer's booking form. The booking reference number is typically used to look up the customer's booking when they call or email to ask a question or make a change to their booking.

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Mr. Thomas,                    We’re looking to move   some dry bulk cargo from Apapa to Durban on short notice. Could you share your earliest loading window?                    Regards,                    Janelle
Email 2:
Dear Colleagues,      Our kind team is invited to London for IMO/SGS market hearing. Looking for your meeting schedule or collective guidance from DCS. What is your opinion for SGH support project?                            Regards,                    Ria

Answering both of these emails at the same time is often not possible. Even with the help of tools, like Changelog.io , can save time. 
Typically, you would need to spend some time each day, looking through the emails you’ve gotten, and only answer the ones you can actually answer, saving the others for later. 

A chat bot can also do that. With a Machine Learning and NLP model, the bot can answer the questions that it has answers to, or store them to answer later, and reply to your other colleagues later, with their questions still in place. 

If the first question above is related to
Email 3:
Dear Sir,
            We have procured the following machine tools & equipment for shipping to Japan / South Korea
                   <inquired item and price>
            could you let us know, what is the space that you can accommodate these machines?
                            Regards,
                            David.
Email 4:
Thank you for the kind offer. We need some more details to plan out for the work. Please fill out the following form: 
<...>
                Regards,
                Victor.

the bot would reply back with the appropriate answers, and then be able to answer similar questions in the future, as it trains its model.

                <Name>

the bot would reply back with its

input_text:
Email 1:
Mr. Silver,                    We’re looking for a 500 ton cargo of corn from Quebec to Tokyo. Could you provide a freight quote under CFR terms, and can your vessel sail before the 20th?                    Best regards,                    Gordon
Email 2:
Silver Shipping
Mr. Silver,
Thank you for your reply. We have already loaded on a vessel and made the transportation contract. However, the transportation company asks for the following documents: a set of bills of lading, a certificate of insurance and a set of commercial invoices. I would appreciate your advice.
Yours sincerely,
Tom

The problem of Cargo Document is tricky because it involves the dispute on whether the transportation company should be considered as the agent of the seller.

Business background:
The first email shows that the buyers have agreed on an acceptance to offer (letter of acceptance, cf. § 1384, Italian Code of Commercial law (Codice Commerciale)) and made a transportation contract for the 500 ton cargo of corn with a third party. As for the Seller, the second email shows that the Seller still thinks that the transportation company is his agent and the Buyers are not
Email 3:
Dear Gordon,
Silver Shipping, Inc. is currently arranging the shipping for you. It will be more convenient if you could tell us the name of the third party or the transportation company to deal with the shipping contract. We are looking forward to getting your email. Thank you very much.
Yours sincerely,
Michael Silver, President Silver Shipping, Inc.
</Email 3>

The main issue:
For the transaction to be a sale with CIF clause, at the moment of conclusion of the contract of sale, the Seller and the Buyers have to agree on the destination port and the Seller have to insure the goods for the Buyers. If the Buyers do not have a transportation contract, the Seller must comply with this CIF clause to fulfill the contract. Otherwise, the Seller should not promise the contract with the Buyers at all, which is the same as Article 6 § 1 (c) of the ICC
Email 4:
Gordon,
Mr. Silver would like to know where you have got the buyers of the corn. We have already got buyers but you asked for the freight and insurance costs. We do not understand why. As we agreed, you are responsible for the sale, insurance and transportation of the corn. We expect to see a written transportation contract from you within the next 3 days. Please forward to Mr. Silver a copy of the transportation contract.
Yours sincerely,
Bill
</Email 4>
The point is that the Seller has not decided what destination port the Buyers are going to choose yet. It seems that the Sellers have fulfilled all the CIF obligations in this case. Thus, it is unnecessary to involve any transportation company. If there is no such transportation company that the Seller and the Buyers both use, the contract of sale cannot be considered as a CIF contract. Therefore, the Sellers should not

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Kathy,                    Has the grounding of the Seablue had any impact on your crude fixing level for the short term?                    Thanks,                    Blayney
Email 2:
Hi Blayney,                    Not at all.                    Seablue is a crude vessel and almost all crude cargoes have been fixed by the other time-chartered tankers coming out of  Chinese yards.
As I mentioned previously, if Seablue did not come out in China, other tankers would come out of the dock and China would be fixed.                    These tankers would operate at a price level set by the most competitive time charter tanker which is the drydocked Seablue and therefore the price level at which China is fixed would not be different even if Seablue was out of the drydock.
LPG cargoes are different since we can not use LPG in the crude tankers and crude cargoes are not as easy to fix as LPG, since many producers are contracted and certain prices are set.
The next drydocked Seablue is in
Email 3:
1. Sent 6:45PM
2. Sent 7:03PM

3. Dear Mr. Mann, We are starting to use one of our new internal chat systems and will not have emails automatically sent to our inbox. I am not using my email for this chat system and would appreciate you sending a copy to my email for my records. This particular email is simply copying one of the other texts I have received. Best Regards, Daniel
output_text:
From: blayney@shippingco.com
To: kathy@shippingco.com
Subject: Impact of Seablue Grounding
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 09:15
Body: Hi Kathy, Has the grounding of the Seablue had any impact on your crude fixing level for the short term? Thanks, Blayney

---

From: kathy@shippingco.com
To: blayney@shippingco.com
Subject: RE: Impact of Seablue Grounding
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 09:30
Body: Hi Blayney, Not at all. Seablue is a crude vessel and almost all crude cargoes have been fixed by the other time-chartered tankers from Chinese yards. As I mentioned previously, if Seablue did not resume operations in China, other tankers would compensate by departing Chinese docks. These tankers would operate at a price level set by the most competitive time charter, which is the drydocked Seablue. Therefore, the price level at which cargoes are fixed in China would not differ even if Seablue was operational. LPG cargoes are different since we cannot use crude tankers for them, and crude cargoes are more complex to arrange as many producers have set contracted prices. Best, Kathy

---

From: daniel@shippingco.com
To: blayney@shippingco.com
Subject: Email Communication
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 09:45
Body: Dear Mr. Mann, We are starting to use one of our new internal chat systems and will not have emails automatically sent to our inbox. I am not using my email for this chat system and would appreciate you sending a copy to my email for my records. This particular email is simply copying one of the other texts I have received. Best Regards, Daniel

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi John,                    Our Singapore client would like to transport 2,800MT of naphtha from Baltimore to Dahej, but we don’t have enough funds on hand for the margin fee. Could you spot us?                    Hope you can help.                    Kim
Email 2:
From: John G                 Sent: 23 February 2012 18:00                 To: Kim T                 Subject: Spot us?                 Not a chance! Hope you can spot my answer.                 John

Problem

A recent widespread email spam campaign targeted the energy and commodities trading industry with messages claiming that their customers wanted to use their services to buy crude oil and related products from reputable traders in the market. Some traders were approached in a very business-like manner, allegedly by major oil firms. The email subject line would indicate that the email was from a trusted business partner, such as a large energy firm or similar corporate client.

The email requests are easy to read but hard to understand. A foreign sounding person claiming to be an executive from a respectable company in a similar industry wants to “spot” some “margin fee” – what? An explanation for what these terms mean may have come attached
Email 3:
Dear John,                    Thank you for your reply.                    Our Singapore client is Singapore Energy, one of the leading trading and logistics companies in Asia Pacific. They represent a major Japanese refiner, Osaka Gas.                    It’s true that this is a complicated trading project and we have to pay a relatively high margin fee of USD 1,000.000.                    If you don’t mind, I can arrange to send you the contract and payment procedure, so that you can fully understand the situation.                    Have a good day.                    Kim

When a business receives a large unsolicited order they often feel obligated to make the sale. In this instance, we can probably deduce that our client is confused as to what the client actually wants and also may be uncomfortable with all the business jargon. In both situations, the client should take a step back and evaluate the order. First, the client should
Email 4:
Dear John,                    Thank you for your reply.                    I am really sorry to trouble you. My name is Alihac, Assistant to the CEO of Singapore Energy.                    I’d like to discuss with you about the details of the project.                    Please let me know when you are free.                    Best regards,                    Kim

As the requests are unsolicited and we have not received any communication with our buyer in the past, it would be a good idea to contact them directly to confirm their intent. We could ask the buyer for more information and maybe arrange to speak with the buyer directly. When speaking with the buyer, it would be important to ask them to provide more information about the deal. The buyer may have a reasonable explanation for their request. However, it is important to keep in mind that a reasonable explanation does not necessarily mean the request is legitimate.

Conclusion

This type of email scam

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Reza,                    I’d like to schedule 40,000MT of molasses from Santos to Jawahar Nagar. We’re open to spot charterers, but this cargo may require some creativity in terms of planning. Could you please let me know if you are open to this size charter?                    Thank you,                    Rosalind
Email 2:
Hi Rosalind                    Just sent you a revised LSA with the same details.                    Best regards                    Reza

Thanks, Reza

Below is Rosalind's reaction to Reza's invitation.
Email 3:
You are good, its working perfect :)

All the best,
Rosalind

So she already appreciated the role of Reza’s proposing concrete example as shown in the second email above.

For general reference, a LSA is a LOI (letter of intent) document.

Introduction

The use of “Email 1” as an example is taken from a popular LinkedIn post of Sam Nara on the subject of using a working example when making a proposal (source: Linkedin).

I have learned a lot from Sam’s post, and I think the post helps provide an excellent practical starting point. In this post, I will provide further explanations to highlight more subtle points not included in Sam’s original post, and also discuss how these points are implemented in our Lean Email.

Email 1 is a typical email. Its objective is to propose a working example to a recipient.

In practice, Rosalind
Email 4:
Thank you so much!
<...>
I do need your help here to review and submit the revised LSA to admin for approvals!

In this example, Rosalind first thanked Reza for sending her a revised LSA, then reminded Reza that she required his help to proceed with the transaction.

Based on this email, Reza needs to do two things to support Rosalind in closing this transaction:

• Review the LSA before submitting the LSA to Rosalind’s admin for approvals.
• Submit the LSA to Rosalind’s admin for approvals.

Reza can do these two tasks simply by using Lean Email by clicking the buttons as shown below. Clicking on the Review button will pop-up a Review/Submit page, which contains a Review tab, and a Submit tab.

Clicking on the Review tab, Reza can simply enter a quick review note, and
output_text:

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Ms. Armitage,                    Want to discuss options for a scheduled bulk chartered from Singapore to Jakarta, loading 15,000 MT of rice.                    Thanks,                    Sally
Email 2:
Ms. Armitage                    Hi Sally,                In reference to your email, we may consider to organize a chartered out of Singapore with loading to be completed by around 20 to 22 Nov, with delivery ETA expected to be around 10 to 12 Dec. For your reference, I have attached the chartered info and telex release copy.                If you are interested, I will keep you posted when we have further update.                Regards,                Tony

</Email 2>

# Word Problem

### Solution 1

From the email the relevant facts are:

• The farmer wants to charter a ship to transport 15000 mt of rice to Jakarta.
• According to Ms. Armitage, the loading can be completed by around 20–22 November with delivery ETA around 10–12 December.

We know the ship will depart Singapore to Jakarta but
Email 3:
Hi Sally,                There will be another chartered starting from Singapore to Jakarta, departing on 18 Nov.                If you are interested, please advise latest by 15 Nov.                Regards,                Tony

</Email 3>

The sender mentions in Email 3 that the ship will leave Singapore to Jakarta on 18 November. That means there will be a time difference between 18 November and 20 November. So this information is not consistent with the information given in Email 2, which is the main source of information.

One reason for inconsistency could be the mistake in Email 2, when Ms. Armitage wrote 22 November instead of 20 November. Or one may assume that when Ms. Armitage sent Email 2, she didn't know about the departure date on 18 November.

Let us consider the following situation:
Email 4:
Hi Sally,                There will be a chartered departing on 18 Nov, with delivery ETA expected to be around 10 to 12 Dec.                Please advise if you are interested by 15 Nov.                Regards,                Tony

</Email 4>

In Email 4, we assumed that Ms. Armitage may have made a mistake in Email 2, and corrected it in Email 4. So let us analyze this situation.

Assume the ship leaves Singapore on 18 November and arrives at Jakarta on 10 December. This means the ship will take 22 days to reach Jakarta.

So, if loading is completed on 20 November, it will take a minimum of 2 days to complete the loading. It may take longer.

• So the loading will take place between 18 and 20 November.
• Then, if the

Email 2:

                    ETA                       Port                  Days at Port

In principle it is every two weeks from Europe (Netherlands, Belgium, Germany) with transshipment to Vladivostok once per month. You can also order grain from these ports for the transshipment in the United States.                    3. Body: Hello Mr. Cooper,

Thank you for the schedule. Could you please clarify the following:

1. What does the above schedule imply for transit times?
2. How many times per year can you load at New York?
3. Can you accept transshipments of grain from Europe (Netherlands, Belgium, Germany)?
4. How many times per year can you transship from Europe to Vladivostok?

From: cooper@vesselops.com
To: marina@shippingco.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry on Grain Transshipment from New York to Vladivostok
Timestamp: 2023-03-04 14:20
Body: Hello Marina,

Apologies for the delay. Here are the answers to your inquiries:

1. The average transit time is approximately 4 weeks.
2. We can handle up to 52 loadings per year at New York.
3. Yes, we can accept grain transshipments from Europe, with departures every two weeks.
4. We transship to Vladivostok once a month from Europe.
5. Our services include grain transshipment from the United States and Europe to Vladivostok. 
6. Our vessels can store bulk products.
7. We do not have terminals in New York or Vladivostok.
8. Our transshipment capacity is 70,000 tons.

Best regards,
Cooper

2. Your average transshipment capacity in Europe

Best regards,
Marina

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Mr. Woo,                    Could you please provide a 7-day freight estimate for 25,000MT of oil from Copenhagen to Lagos.                    Thanks,                    Felipe
Email 2:
Dear Felipe,                 25,000 tons of oil from Copenhagen to Lagos in a seven-day freight?                    That's quite a bit of oil, Felipe. I assume you need to ship it by sea.                    You see, the oil trade operates on a just-in-time inventory management model, whereby oil is shipped to tankers as needed. This provides a stable supply and demand, eliminates inventory storage costs and prevents oil from degrading over time.                    Since your request involves shipping 25,000 tons of oil in seven days, my freight quote estimate would exceed what is available.                    Please confirm that your request is for 25,000 tons of oil in a seven-day freight and I can provide a quote to the maximum that is available to my company.                    Thanks,                    Perry

<Email 3>:
Dear Perry,                 Yes, my request is for 25,000 tons
Email 3:
Dear Perry,                 Yes, my request is for 25,000 tons

<Email 3>:
 For shipping in seven days to Lagos in the Nigeria.                 Could you please provide a quote?                    Thanks,                    Felipe
<Email 4>:
Dear Felipe,                 Again, shipping 25,000 tons in seven days is an unusual request.                    If you are shipping this amount of oil in an outbound tanker, then the only companies capable of doing so are Shell, Chevron and Exxon. I don't have contacts with these companies.                    If you're shipping by sea, then you'll need a port in Copenhagen to load onto a tanker. I've emailed my contacts in the seaport of Copenhagen. They'll be in touch with me in the morning.                    If you're shipping by road, then the quantity would need to be in 45 liter plastic oil drums. The storage space and legal limitations of this option would be impossible to organize in such a short time frame.
Email 4:
Dear Felipe,                 Again, shipping 25,000 tons in seven days is an unusual request.                    If you are shipping this amount of oil in an outbound tanker, then the only companies capable of doing so are Shell, Chevron and Exxon. I don't have contacts with these companies. They'll be in touch with me in the morning.                    If you're shipping by road, then the quantity would need to be in 45 liter plastic oil drums. The storage space and legal limitations of this option would be impossible to organize in such a short time frame.

<Email 4>:

If you insist, I'll let my seaport contacts know to contact you, but don't expect a reply.                    I'm sorry, but I simply don't have the resources to fill your request. I'm going to have to recommend you submit your request to one of the three large oil companies I mentioned before.                    I'd like to thank you for your business.                   Regards,                   Perry

<Email 4>:
Dear Perry,                 I am absolutely okay with you contacting the seaport in Copenhagen.                    I understand that you don't have the resources to fulfill my request.                    I will be submitting my request to an oil company.

Thank you,                   Perry

Subject: Freight Estimate and Options

Body: Dear Felipe,
Shipping 25,000 tons in seven days is quite unusual. For such a significant shipment via sea, you would need to load onto a tanker at a port in Copenhagen. Additionally, arranging transport by road in such a short timeframe is impractical due to storage space and legal constraints.
I suggest submitting your request directly to one of the large oil companies. I've also contacted the Copenhagen seaport and will inform you once I receive their response.

Email 2:
Hi Katherine,
The following rates apply:                    - Spot: $50 per mt over 20% IFM + 30/5/20 (laycan 7-10 days),                      - Extended: $40 per mt over 20% IFM + 30/10/20 (laycan 10-14 days)                    - Longer: $30 per mt over 20% IFM + 30/15/20 (laycan 14-21 days)                    - The above includes fixed delay rate (FDR) of$5 per day for the first 7 days, then $10 per day per day over the first 7 days to be paid on arrival (i.e. if vessel delayed 8 days, FDR is$70 - ($5x7) + ($10x1))                    - The above does not include accelerated discharge charge ($0
Email 3:
Hello Katherine,                     Thanks for your inquiry and interest in working with us.
I'd like to point out a few things that may be useful for you to consider when doing business with us:
* **Additional charges**: Please note that, the above rates do not include Accelerated discharge charges for +35 days cargo to be paid by Seller.   You will need to bear this cost in mind when considering the above rates.
* **Availability of vessels**: I'm afraid, the vessel availability may be very limited in this trade during April-May 2023 due to busy Season. We have a few vessels that we can offer at the above rates but they are all loaded already in their previous trades and are due to return to Russia after discharging and we'll require 20-30 days notice from you to fit a ballast leg. Hence, you may consider booking a vessel now at the above rates
output_text:
From: katherine@importexportinc.com
To: lewis@shippingco.com
Subject: Inquiry about Freight Rates for Oil Seed Cake from Saint Petersburg to Seoul
Timestamp: 2023-04-01 09:30
Body: Hello Mr. Lewis, Can you confirm the rates for transporting 7,500MT of oil seed cake from Saint Petersburg to Seoul? Additionally, could you provide details on the length of laycan and any additional costs associated with accelerated discharge? Regards, Katherine

---

From: lewis@shippingco.com
To: katherine@importexportinc.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry about Freight Rates for Oil Seed Cake from Saint Petersburg to Seoul
Timestamp: 2023-04-01 13:45
Body: Hi Katherine, The following freight rates apply: 
- Spot: $50 per mt with IFM over 20% for a laycan of 7-10 days, 
- Extended: $40 per mt with IFM over 20% for a laycan of 10-14 days, 
- Longer: $30 per mt with IFM over 20% for a laycan of 14-21 days.
The rates include a fixed delay rate (FDR) of $5 per day for the first 7 days, then $10 per day thereafter (e.g., if vessel delayed 8 days, FDR totals $70: $5x7 + $10x1). These rates do not include charges for accelerated discharge.

---

From: lewis@shippingco.com
To: katherine@importexportinc.com
Subject: Additional Information
Timestamp: 2023-04-01 14:00
Body: Hello Katherine, Thanks for your inquiry and your interest in working with us.
Please note that the above rates do not include charges for accelerated discharge for cargo overdue beyond 35 days, which would need to be paid by the Seller. Additionally, I must inform you that vessel availability is quite limited during April to May 2023 due to the busy season. We do have a few vessels that can offer these rates but they are already committed in their previous trades and would need a 20-30 days notice to arrange a ballast leg back to Russia. I would recommend considering booking a vessel now to secure these rates.

Hi Mr. Perez,                    The refinery has decided to raise their bunker surcharge. Can you confirm this has been included in the quotation for 100,000mt of crude to discharge by June 10th in Amoco?                    Regards,                    Zoe Cortez
Email 2:
Hi Zoe,                       I don't see the word 'bunker' in the quote so can you please confirm if this has been raised on 100,000mt of crude to discharge by June 10th in Amoco?                    Regards,                    Pablo Perez

<Email 3>:
Hi Pablo,                     Not yet, that's what I'm asking. Can you confirm the change has been made on this shipment?                     Regards,                     Zoe Cortez

<Email 4>:
Hi Zoe,                      Sorry, I missed the e-mail. Yes, the bunker surcharge has been changed and reflected in the price.

Email 5:
Hi Pablo,                     The refinery has not increased their surcharge. Could you please review this email exchange and revert?                     Regards,                     Zoe Cortez

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Min,                    How flexible are you on the nailing and also lashing at Montevideo?                    Thanks,                    Scott
Email 2:
(Answer)                     Dear Scott                     Montevideo is flexible on this issue provided the    requirements of the church history museum are    met. The church history museum is actually     constructing a rock wall with hand hewn     timbers for the base to hold up the rocks.     This entire wall will be constructed inside    the museum to display this room. They will     then hang two of our timbers from the inside    of this rock wall with chain. The nailing    requirement for these timbers will be strictly    adhered to in the construction of the     display. The museum has asked that the side    facing the rock wall be prepared to display     it with some sort of protective material for     display. But it would be the museum that would    decide on the type of protective coating that    would be used. The only nailing that would    have to be done at the Museum
Email 3:
We are taking the timber to Denmark. I was wondering about shipping them? Or should we just carry them across Europe in a pick up truck.                             If you can advise me on this I would really appreciate it.                             Thanks                             Bob
                 We would recommend that you bring the timbers.  We have included some additional information below in hopes of answering some of the questions you have sent us in email.  We need to know if you are interested in the display materials we have available for your timber and also the additional display material that your representative from us in Denmark has recommended.

You can find our current brochure at the following website.  This has all of the prices and descriptions.  Also in the attachments you will find a form you can fill out and return to us with payment.  One of the timbers can be sent via FedEx which will cost approximately 1,000 Danish Kron
output_text:
From: scott@example.com
To: min@example.com
Subject: Flexibility Inquiry for Timber Lashing and Nailing at Montevideo
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 08:45
Body: Hello Min,
How flexible are you on the nailing and lashing at Montevideo for the timber project? Thanks,
Scott

---

From: min@example.com
To: scott@example.com
Subject: Re: Flexibility Inquiry for Timber Lashing and Nailing at Montevideo
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 12:30
Body: Dear Scott,
Montevideo is flexible on this issue provided the requirements of the Church History Museum are met. The museum is constructing a rock wall with hand hewn timbers for the base to support the rocks. This wall will be constructed inside the museum for display. They plan to hang two of our timbers from the inside of this rock wall with chains, and the nailing requirements for these timbers will be strictly adhered to for the display. The museum has requested that the side of the timber facing the rock wall be prepared with a protective material. However, the museum will ultimately decide on the type of protective coating to be used. Best, Min

---

From: bob@example.com
To: scott@example.com
Subject: Timber Transportation to Denmark Inquiry
Timestamp: 2023-03-02 09:15
Body: Hello Scott,
We are planning to take the timber to Denmark. Could you advise on the shipping options? Alternatively, would transporting them across Europe in a pick-up truck be feasible? If you can provide guidance on this, I would really appreciate it. Thanks, Bob

---

From: scott@example.com
To: bob@example.com
Subject: Re: Timber Transportation to Denmark Inquiry
Timestamp: 2023-03-02 11:00
Body: Hello Bob,
For transporting the timbers to Denmark, we recommend shipping over driving across Europe in a pick-up truck. Our current brochure on timber transport options, including pricing and descriptions, can be found on our website. Additionally, you will find an order form in the attachments which you can fill out and return to us with payment. Arranging the transport via FedEx will cost approximately 1,000 Danish Kroner. Please let us know if you are interested in the display materials we have available as well as the additional display materials recommended by our representative in Denmark. Regards, Scott

To: kosar.shipping@example.com
Subject: Inquiry about Vessel Chartering from Puerto Quetzal to Yantian
Timestamp: 2023-07-10 09:30
Body: Hi Mrs. Kosar,

I would like to hire your capsize vessel for a trip from Puerto Quetzal to Yantian in late July. Could you confirm your rate and availability?

Best regards,
Henrik

---

From: kosar.shipping@example.com
To: henrik@example.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry about Vessel Chartering from Puerto Quetzal to Yantian
Timestamp: 2023-07-10 14:20
Body: Hi Henrik,

We are delighted to assist you with your shipping needs. Our capsize vessel is available for your specified dates. Please find the relevant rate offer in the attached document, which includes all pertinent details to start our agency relationship.

Best regards,

---

From: henrik@example.com
To: kosar.shipping@example.com
Subject: Clarification Required on Shipping Charges
Timestamp: 2023-07-11 08:45
Body: Hello Mr. Kosar,

Thank you for sending over the details. I am ready to proceed but need clarification on the spreadsheet. It lists a charge of $2.3 million for the voyage, along with additional charges like Bunker Adjustment Factor (BAF). Also, there is a weight limit of 150 tons. Could you explain these details in simpler terms?

Best regards,
Henrik

---

From: kosar.shipping@example.com
To: henrik@example.com
Subject: Re: Clarification Required on Shipping Charges
Timestamp: 2023-07-11 12:30
Body: Hello Henrik,

Thank you for your inquiry. The transportation costs are divided into three sections: freight ($2.3 million), BAF (which covers fluctuating fuel prices), and other surcharges. The weight limit of 150 tons applies to the maximum safe operational capacity of the vessel. Please let me know if you need further details or clarification.

Best regards,
Sergey

Hello Ian,                    We need to ship 3,000MT of corn from Wilhelmshaven to Xiamen on a barge. Can we arrange for delivery from Xiamen, and do you have any price information?                    Regards,                    Sally
Email 2:
Hi, we have a Corn order from Paul Bunyan Farms in South Carolina. The first shipper from the Barge is Hamburg, and they want to deliver it to Xiamen. Can you let us know if the shipping price is available?                    Regards,                    Sally

I've now two of the same emails. At the first sight you'd think they are from different people, but they are not. Same email, same name, and same contact information. I have received these two e-mails from three different people now, and each person is a real customer of mine, so that means I have probably more e-mails out there looking for a response. I haven't answered yet because I have not been able to figure out how to reply. That's because this e-mail is not actually in my email inbox. It is on a webpage. It is a phishing attack, and this is
Email 3:

Oops. I changed it to:

From: officeupdate@company.com
To: all@company.com
Subject: Branch & Office Closures and Notice
Timestamp: 2010-09-03 09:00
Body: Dear All,

Please be informed that our branches in Bengaluru and Chennai, as well as the Sales Office in Kolkata, will be closed on account of the Ganesh Chaturthi Festival and Independence Day, respectively. The Sales Office in Chennai will resume operations from 10th September.

Due to unprecedented and widespread rains triggered by the southwest monsoon in Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, and Kerala, all transport to and from these regions has been suspended until further notice. We have notified our customers in these areas that we are currently unable to source consignments due to the ongoing floods.

Regards,
Team

Email 1:
Hi Ken,                    Looking to ship a tanker of 80,000MT LPG from Dahej, India to Busan, Korea. We need a laycan of about 15th May, and are flexible on cargo quality.                    Let me know what you think.                    Regards,                    Anthony
Email 2:
Hi Anthony.  We'd be happy to offer you a vessel on this delivery.  What kind of vessel are you looking for, new or secondhand?  What about a firm charter?                    I'll ask our local manager in Singapore to see if we can offer anything.  Can you please let me know if your clients want us to submit FOB or CIF.  And can you please confirm your clients are looking for a Chinese registry vessel, or if they are open to other registries.                    Thank you,                    Anthony

<Email 3>:
Thank you for your reply.  Our client has given us the following details.                    The vessel should have a certificate of comliance.  They prefer a newbuild vessel.  They want a firm charter, not a time charter.  For the charter party they would like to use Norwegian shipbrokers standard form.
output_text:
From: anthony@shippingco.com
To: ken@vesselprovider.com
Subject: Inquiry for LPG Shipment from Dahej to Busan
Timestamp: 2023-04-25 09:30
Body: Hi Ken,

I'm looking to arrange the shipment of about 80,000MT of LPG from Dahej, India to Busan, Korea. We need a laycan starting around 15th May, and we are somewhat flexible on cargo specifications. Please let me know your thoughts.

Regards,
Anthony

---

From: ken@vesselprovider.com
To: anthony@shippingco.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry for LPG Shipment from Dahej to Busan
Timestamp: 2023-04-25 15:45
Body: Hi Anthony,

Thank you for reaching out. We would be happy to assist with your delivery needs. Could you specify whether you prefer a new or secondhand vessel, and confirm whether your clients require a firm charter? Additionally, could you clarify if your clients would like us to handle the logistics on a FOB or CIF basis, and if they have a preference for a vessel registered under Chinese registry or if other registries are acceptable?

I will discuss potential options with our local manager in Singapore and await your detailed preferences.

Thank you,
Ken

---

From: anthony@shippingco.com
To: ken@vesselprovider.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry for LPG Shipment from Dahej to Busan
Timestamp: 2023-04-26 10:15
Body: Hi Ken,

Thank you for your prompt response. Our client prefers a newbuild vessel and a firm charter. For the charter agreement, they would like to use the Norwegian Shipbrokers' Standard Form. It would be best if you coordinate the shipment on a CIF basis, and they are flexible regarding the vessel's registry.

Looking forward to your proposals.

Best regards,
Anthony

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Ms. Anderson,                    The vessel will leave Porto Velho on 24th April. Can you confirm berth allocation?                    Regards,                    Kim                Sample email 1
            Communication is key to having a successful voyage. This is why there are six key elements to an email.
            The First Element - Greetings
            Emails are business documents, so you should use formal language. This includes starting the email with a formal greeting. Formal greetings can be used with someone who you are not familiar with. Some formal greetings include:
            Dear Mr Xander,
            Greetings Ms. Anderson,
            To whom it may concern.
            The Second Element - Subject Line
            Use a descriptive subject line. One you give your email a descriptive subject line, you will increase your chances of being read. It will also prevent your emails from being mistaken for spam or getting lost in your recipient
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Simon,                      The vessel will leave Porto Velho on 24th April. Can you confirm berth allocation?                    Regards,                    Kim
    Elements of an Email
    The Third Element - Body of the Email
    The body of your email should include:
    Introduce yourself to the recipient. If it is your first time contacting the recipient, introduce yourself in your first email. An introduction should include:
    Why are you writing?
    Why do you think the recipient would be interested in your email?
    Include an appropriate closing for your email. To find a list of appropriate closings, see below.
    Sincerely,
    Cordially,
    Regards,
    Best regards,
    Kind regards,
    Best,
    Finally, it is recommended that you proofread your email before you send it. It is important that your email is clear, concise, and professional.
