Email 1:
Dear Mr. Maier,                    Hope you’re well. Could you please tell me what the freight idea is for a cargo of palm oil from Calabar to Santa Marta, with a mid-June laycan?                    Thanks,                    Gary
Email 2:
Mr. Maier,                    Thanks for that. You should read the other section of the email.                    Gary
Email 3:
Mr. Maier,                    Thanks for the help, but that is incorrect. We are buying palm oil from Calabar not Brazil. Please read the email again.
Once again, my valued guest and the popular ‘humourous’ founder of the humour site Fuleminess  has raised a very important issue. With the growing influence of multinational business and the Internet, there is a danger of being misunderstood. Particularly when it comes to asking someone a question. With the ever growing number of emails and phonecalls being made globally every second of the day, it is important to ensure your request is heard. 

When sending an email with a question, it is also very important to include a sign off such as “Best Regards” or “Kind Regards” this is because at times a person can read the email very fast and can be assumed that the person sending the email is actually sending them
Email 4:

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Betsy,                    We’re expecting 6,600MT of household chemicals to leave Antwerp on Friday. If you could advise your final freight rate, we can accept it.                    Thank you,                    David
Email 2:
Hi David,                    I can confirm that the rate I quoted you earlier still stands: US$2.00 per ton FOB Antwerp, plus US$10 per package in case the packages are of different dimensions.                    Should you require additional details please let me know.                    Best wishes,                    Betsy

<Betsy to her husband, Dave>:
Here we go again! This is the third request for a quote in one day, and David seems to have given a full quote in his original email. Why do I have to explain this to him every time?
What are some reasons for replying to an email twice?
Paragraph 2 (this one) gives specific reasons in the writer’s first email. Her husband’s email serves to remind her that David is not as familiar with the company’s rates as she is.

Explain how this form of explanation might serve to establish greater rapport
Email 3:
Hi Dave,                    Why don’t you just offer the rate per ton and let David accept it or suggest alternatives?                    Do you remember in our training course, we learnt that the purpose of most email communications is not just to reply with ‘yes’ or ‘no’, but to help others make a decision?                    David’s just a little reluctant, but he will accept it and agree to it if you can help him to make a decision by making your rate specific enough.                    Best wishes,                    Betsy
<Betsy to her husband, Dave>:
Dave, I wrote you an email in the last section. Please tell me how you replied.

Email 1:
Dear all,                    I’d like to charter a multipurpose vessel from Fujairah to Dar es Salaam, around 2,000MT. Can you advise availability and rates?                    Regards,                    Yanyan
Email 2:
Globmarine Chartering.
Dear Sirs,       We hereby wish to kindly remind you that after the info shared with you in your first inquiry, We informed you about the available vessel and some alternative vessels as well, after having the availability of both, we can’t get your approval for the vessel S & P. The reason is that the owner does not provide the Vessel’s P&I and therefore you will need to cover the cost. We can find an alternative vessel for you however, therefore please contact us for further details and your approval. We apologize for the inconvenience. Please note, the charterer may choose between TCE only or TCE+P&I that can also be offered to them. Thank you for your cooperation.      With Best Regards,      Amr El-Garhy      Sales Department      Company Information  Globmarine Chartering Limited is a Dubai based
output_text:

To: info@globmarine-chartering.com
Subject: Charter Inquiry - Fujairah to Dar es Salaam
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 09:30
Body: Dear Globmarine Chartering, I am seeking to charter a multipurpose vessel for approximately 2,000MT from Fujairah to Dar es Salaam. Could you please provide availability and rates? Looking forward to your prompt response. Regards, Yanyan

---

From: amr.elgarhy@globmarine-chartering.com
To: yanyan@example.com
Subject: Re: Charter Inquiry - Fujairah to Dar es Salaam
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 15:45
Body: Dear Yanyan, Thank you for your inquiry. We have shared details previously about the availability of the vessel 'S&P'. However, the owner has not provided the vessel's Protection & Indemnity (P&I) insurance, which means any associated costs would need to be covered by you. We can look for alternative vessels if required. Please let us know how you would like to proceed. Apologies for any inconvenience caused. We can offer Terms and Conditions (TCE) only, or TCE combined with P&I. I look forward to your decision. Best regards, Amr El-Garhy Sales Department Globmarine Chartering Limited

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Mr. Ferris,                    My name is Samuel. I’m currently the vessel broker of a Chinese bulk carrier currently in Chittagong, Bangladesh.                    We have 3,800MT of heavy plates to load. Destination is Port Louis, Mauritius. We have been given the following port dues and fees to be deducted from the cargo:                    * General Cargo Port Dues: USD 3,256.00                    * Coast Guard Charges: USD 164.00                    * MFAF (Mauritius Free Airport Fee): USD 112.80                    * Port Corporation: USD 159.84                    * Generator Rental: USD 0.16/ Hour * 12 Hours = USD 1.92                    * Empty Tank Cleaning: USD 10.00 * 2 Tanks = USD 20.00                    Could you kindly take this into account when submitting
Email 2:
Dear Samuel,
Thank you for your email. Unfortunately it is not appropriate for you to pass charges like this on to the cargo owners without their consent. If you are able to provide evidence that this is the owners’ responsibility (e.g. a bill of lading with a clause allowing the carrier to deduct port dues from the cargo), we might be able to discuss a rate increase to cover these expenses, but if you are just making up charges to pay your agency then it is unethical and we will not pay you.
Thank you,
Alain Ferris
PS: We also need a few more details on the cargo (origin, grade, product code), which will enable us to get a more accurate quote for the freight.
PPS: The more information you are able to provide in your emails, the faster we can give you an answer, and the less likely it is that you will have
output_text:
From: samuel@vesselbroker.cn
To: alain.ferris@cargoimporters.mu
Subject: Port dues and additional charges for cargo loading
Timestamp: 2023-08-15 09:30
Body: Dear Mr. Ferris,

I hope this email finds you well. My name is Samuel, and I am currently the vessel broker for a Chinese bulk carrier in Chittagong, Bangladesh.

We have been assigned to load 3,800 MT of heavy plates, destined for Port Louis, Mauritius. We were informed of several port dues and fees, including:

- General Cargo Port Dues: USD 3,256.00
- Coast Guard Charges: USD 164.00
- MFAF (Mauritius Free Airport Fee): USD 112.80
- Port Corporation: USD 159.84
- Generator Rental: USD 1.92 (USD 0.16/Hour for 12 hours)
- Empty Tank Cleaning: USD 20.00 (USD 10.00 per tank for 2 tanks)

Could you kindly consider this breakdown when submitting your invoice? We'd appreciate acknowledging these charges in our agreement.

Best regards,

Samuel

---

From: alain.ferris@cargoimporters.mu
To: samuel@vesselbroker.cn
Subject: Re: Port dues and additional charges for cargo loading
Timestamp: 2023-08-15 15:45
Body: Dear Samuel,

Thank you for your detailed email.

It is important to clarify that passing on such charges to the cargo owners requires their prior consent. If there is documentation (e.g., a bill of lading with a specific clause) that assigns these charges to the owners, we can consider these in our rate discussion. Otherwise, unauthorized charge transfers are not permitted.

Additionally, to provide a more accurate freight quote, could you please supply more details regarding the cargo such as its origin, grade, and product code?

The more comprehensive the information you provide, the quicker we can process it, and the smoother our transaction will be.

Kind regards,

Alain Ferris

P.S. Please send the necessary cargo details at your earliest convenience.

As soon as you are ready, please let us know the details for your shipment, and we'll quote you accordingly.                        Thanks!                        Horeb Shipping Captain X

Email 3:

The information you need is as follows:                        Quantity: 30,000MT (weight)                        Type: Soybean meal                        Packed in 50kg jumbo bags                        Packed in 1,200 bags per 40'HC container                        Destination: Shantou                        Port of loading: Chongqing                        In the end of June this year, my company and a dealer made an agreement of selling and buying the above soybean meal at the agreed price of 1,300USD per MT. Our cargo agent has confirmed the rates for 30,000MT of soybean meal from Chongqing to Dalian. The details are as follows:
-	Build Chongqing: $10,000 (Spot period), $9,750 (September delivery)
-	Bunkering at Chongqing: $80
-	FOB Dalian: $60 (Spot period), $75 (September delivery)
-	Bunkering at Dalian: $30
Our vessel is available for September delivery. Please let us know your shipment details whenever you're ready, and we'll quote you accordingly.
Thanks!
Captain X

---

From: sulek@agrotrade.com
To: captain.x@horebshipping.com
Subject: Change of Destination to Shantou
Timestamp: 2023-08-02 10:20
Body: Dear Captain X,
Thanks for your prompt reply. Could you please quote the same shipment but with the destination changed to Shantou instead of Dalian?
Additionally, I would like to book the cargo as per your email, with the following details:
-	Quantity: 30,000MT
-	Commodity: Soybean meal
-	Packaging: 50kg jumbo bags
-	Containers: 1,200 bags per 40'HC container
-	Destination: Shantou
-	Loading Port: Chongqing
In June, my company agreed on a selling and buying price of $1,300 per MT for this soybean meal. Is it still possible to ship at that price in September?
Thanks in advance.
Sulek

---

From: captain.x@horebshipping.com
To: sulek@agrotrade.com
Subject: Re: Change of Destination to Shantou
Timestamp: 2023-08-03 15:55
Body: Dear Sulek,
Unfortunately, the rate you inquired about in July is no longer available. Due to increases in freight costs since your inquiry, the new rate for September would be approximately $12,000 for 30,000MT. This is significantly higher compared to your initial contract price of $1,300 per MT. Selling your soybean meal at this new freight cost may not be economically feasible.
Regards,
Captain X

---

From: sulek@agrotrade.com
To: captain.x@horebshipping.com
Subject: Cancellation of the Shipment
Timestamp: 2023-08-04 08:10
Body: Dear Captain X,
That's unfortunate news. It appears we cannot proceed under these conditions, as the contract price was only $1,300 per MT. Reducing the price further would result in a significant loss. I will need to inform the client and consider alternative cargo options. I appreciate your assistance but will close this deal with the seller.
Thanks for your help.
Sulek

---

From: captain.x@horebshipping.com
To: sulek@agrotrade.com
Subject: Re: Cancellation of the Shipment
Timestamp: 2023-08-04 09:15
Body: Dear Sulek,
It's indeed a pity that we could not proceed. If you change your mind or find alternative solutions, feel free to contact us. We'll be here to assist in any way we can.
Best regards,
Captain X

> Surface rules: They are found on the surface of the sentence as entities that can be mapped onto external data sources.

> Explicit rules: They are not evident from the sentence, and must be explicitly provided by the analyst.

> Implicit rules: They are contained within the linguistic unit that can be extracted from the sentence but require inference to map the linguistic unit onto the external data source.

Email 2:
Hi,                    I also heard about some vessels taking longer than normal to make passage through locks at the Suez Canal. How does that affect my shipments?                    Sincerely,                    Sarah                    --
1. The Suez Canal plays a crucial role in the global shipping industry, connecting the Mediterranean Sea to the Red Sea. However, recent events have caused concerns among vessel operators and shipping companies about delays and increased congestion at the canal.
2. Since the closure of the canal in March due to the Ever Given ship blocking it, operators have been expressing fears of congestion and delays. Despite the reopening of the canal in mid-April, vessels are still facing delays as the backlog of shipping containers and other cargo continues to accumulate.
3. As of May 2nd, there are 67 vessels waiting to enter the Suez Canal, while an additional 55 are waiting to exit. This has led to
Email 3:
Can you tell me what is the status of the Ever Given ship that got stuck in the Suez Canal in March? Is it still there? Also, I've heard about the backlog of vessels in the canal. Do you know if that might affect my shipment?
Dear (Name),
I hope this message finds you well. I understand that you have some questions regarding the Ever Given ship and the backlog of vessels at the Suez Canal. Let me try to address your concerns.
Firstly, the Ever Given ship was successfully dislodged from the Suez Canal on March 29th, after being stuck for almost a week. However, it remains in the canal until it can be re-fueled and towed to another location for repairs. The process of refueling and repairing the ship is expected to take several weeks.
As for the backlog of vessels in the canal, the congestion has

Subject: Impact of Suez Canal Delays on Shipments

From: info@shippingcompany.com
To: sarah@example.com
Subject: Re: Impact of Suez Canal Delays on Shipments
Timestamp: 2023-05-02 10:00
Body: Dear Sarah, Thank you for reaching out. Indeed, the Suez Canal faced severe disruptions due to the Ever Given ship getting stuck in March. While the ship was dislodged on March 29th and cleared from the canal, it is currently being refueled and prepared for towing to another location for repairs. The backlog of vessels has caused some delays, but traffic flow is steadily returning to normal. Please rest assured we are closely monitoring the situation and will keep you updated on any potential impacts on your shipments. Regards, Shipping Company

Email 2:
Hi J. Pye,                    I’m writing you about your question. However, due to some problems with confidentiality, I will have to address this email as being from someone other than me.                    I can handle a late July load date, but you must understand that it may take us a few weeks to secure the necessary permits. You can help speed things along by hiring a third party to find out who the permits are issued to, and to pay them for their services. Your cargo is a noxious substance that has been denied to others in the past, so this must be done delicately. The load window can be as short as 3-4 days, but we’ll have to include that in the permits, too.                    Yours,                    Aqaba

Email 2:
Yes, we can arrange it if you can complete it by the end of this week. We have 30 containers per month so you could benefit from our terms, which means we will collect all your adhesives within 4 weeks of the final load. Please find attached our container size chart. 

The next step will be to take an order for your shipment so we can plan the schedule and confirm price. The full details of how to do this can be found at www.ocean-imports.co.uk – please register and follow the instructions.

Best wishes,
Patrick

Best wishes,
Patrick

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Steve,                    Have a great week! My team and I are in Las Vegas this week for the NFPA Convention, but we'll be back on Monday.                    If you can please send us the routing information for your 5,500MT MGO shipment, we'll arrange for a broker to pick it up and make our arrangements to ship to Pusan.                    Thanks,                    Will
Email 2:
Hey All,                     Because I’m out of the office this week, I’m sending you some interesting projects and news to check out while I’m away!  Here are a few highlights:
* Click here to learn about the Fertilizer Institute’s new Code of Conduct, which includes nine guiding principles for good behavior, including the encouragement of a culture of safety and compliance with the law. "Anyone who works with anhydrous ammonia or other fertilizers must read this, and they must share it with their teams," says Director of Regulatory Affairs Brian Jennings.
* When a group of California manufacturers and distributors went before the California Air Resources Board (CARB) to discuss the 2013 Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) proposed by the U.S. EPA, they did not leave empty-handed. A bill was introduced in the state legislature that would provide a tax incentive to encourage renewable fuel blending
Email 3:
It’s been busy around the warehouses. We are in the process of getting our Fall products ready. We have had some order cancellations so we will have a few spots open. We are reevaluating our shipping schedules. We are now shipping later than we did last year. It appears that the weather is not cooperating. We will keep you informed as we get better weather conditions. Some 20-inch rocks have not made it to the Southeastern states due to weather conditions and we are not sure when we will get them in.

To: steve@transport.com
Subject: Arrangements needed for MGO shipment
Timestamp: 2023-09-04 09:30
Body: Hello Steve,

I hope this message finds you well. My team and I are currently in Las Vegas for the NFPA Convention and will return on Monday. Could you please send us the routing information for the 5,500MT MGO shipment? We need to arrange for a broker to pick it up and ship it to Pusan.

Thank you,
Will

---

From: steve@transport.com
To: office@transport.com
Subject: Updates and Interesting Projects to Check Out
Timestamp: 2023-09-04 14:20
Body: Hey All,

Since I'm currently out of the office, I’ve compiled some interesting projects and news for everyone to look over:

* Learn about the Fertilizer Institute’s new Code of Conduct, featuring nine guiding principles. It's essential for those dealing with anhydrous ammonia or other fertilizers. Director of Regulatory Affairs, Brian Jennings, advises all stakeholders to read this and disseminate it among their teams.

* A recent meeting with the CARB discussed the 2013 Renewable Fuel Standard proposed by the U.S. EPA in California. As a result, a bill was introduced in the state legislature aimed at providing a tax incentive to enhance renewable fuel blending.

Best,
Steve

---

From: will@shippingco.com
To: team@shippingco.com
Subject: Shipping Schedule Updates
Timestamp: 2023-09-05 08:45
Body: Hello team,

We've been encountering some logistics issues around our warehouses, primarily due to weather disruptions. We are reevaluating our fall shipping schedules because of these conditions and some recent order cancellations. As a result, we are experiencing delays in shipping our products, which now includes a delay with our 20-inch rocks to the Southeastern states. We will keep everyone updated as we monitor the weather and adjust our plans accordingly.

Best regards,
Will

Good morning Shahar,                    I wanted to see if we could coordinate our movements to Lyon.. We need 1,300MT of bitumen.. Could you name some vessels and a laycan?                    Regards,                    Caroline
Email 2:
Good morning Caroline,

I have checked with my Bitumen supplier.

### Answer options

The correct answer is C.   We need 1,300MT of bitumen


  • A.  We need 1,300MT of bitumen to Chicago                    • B.  I have checked with my supplier                    • D.  Could you name some vessels and a laycan?                    • E.  I wanted to see if we could coordinate our movements to Lyon


The best thing to do when faced with answer options is to try and make as few assumptions as possible. Although the words "we need" in the original email suggests a second person, you shouldn't immediately assume that there is more than one person at SEEDOR Company.
Try and identify the people who are talking about the 1,300MT.
The correct answer is "we".  So, this 1

Dear Sven,                    We’d like to load 12,000MT of chemicals in Boston next week. Could you confirm the price and your vessel’s partial loading window?                    Kind regards,                    Jake
Email 2:
Dear Sven,                    Please confirm the price of 12,000MT of chemicals.                    Kind regards,                    Jake

In my previous post I introduced how the transformer can be used to set up a casual model using a combination of supervised and unsupervised learning. I wanted to apply this methodology to email correspondence analysis but had no good starting points to learn from. So, I decided to have a go at using a large email data set to set up an email correspondence model. In this post, I’ll describe my method and then evaluate it.
## Previous Work
I found two other email correspondence analyses:
Both papers claimed to have a small error rate (below 5%) but no error rate figures were provided. Their methods included analyzing only the destination of emails and ignoring the subjects and whether the email was replied to or not.
## Data
I got the dataset from Wikipedia and as the

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Scott,                    My name is Stewart and I’m reaching out from Reznor, one of the main vendors of equipment and services for drywall finishing. We’ve just discovered the worksite of the Sillington project on constructionobserver.com, and since this is right in our backyard, I’d love to get a quote for your finishing needs.                    Can you please send me an estimate for your next order of metal lath so we can stay on your radar for next time? Let me know if you have any other questions about our process and we’ll be happy to walk you through it.                    Thanks in advance for your time, and I look forward to speaking with you.                    Best regards,                    Stewart Vanderbloemen                    Reznor, LLC. (410) 455-2060
Email 2:
Hi Stewart!
This email is to let you know the company would like to move on with other bidding processes. As always, thank you for your interest in my business.

<Email 3>
Stewart Vanderbloemen <stewart.vanderbloemen@reznor.com>                 2:32 PM (0 minutes ago)
Sent from my iPhone

Hey Todd, just to follow up, did you ever receive a quote for your metal lath? I know you said you’d go with another vendor, but I wanted to get this completed for our records. Thanks!

From: Todd Sillington <todd.sillington@gmail.com>                 
To: Stewart Vanderbloemen <stewart.vanderbloemen@reznor.com>     
Sent: Thursday, April 16, 2020, 12:33 PM                     
Subject: RE: Metal Lath Purchase
Email 3:
It’s been a while since I’ve been on Construction observer. Do I have to be a subscriber to view pricing for the services? Thanks.

<Email 4>
I love that you and everyone else on the website have no idea what it takes to run a successful business. You think it’s as easy as going on constructionobserver and asking for bids. Just how much it costs for a quote and if there is a minimum number of products you have to buy.
I’d say it’s an education. Like how the Navy discovered it would lose too many crewmen if they started a major war without undergoing combat training first, so they decided to create such training so that every year they would lose fewer and fewer crews. Combat training also provided the Navy with the opportunity to evaluate newly created equipment and armaments.

In short, anyone can be an entrepreneur. You don’t need to be the richest

Dear Messrs Rettig and Nogales,                    I hear that you are in talks to form a new entity, can you confirm this? If so, I think it would be a good time for us to consider increasing our volume on HUB. Email 2:
Dear Ira,                         In answer to your query, we are currently in talks to form a new entity.                         This will be good news for the industry if we can demonstrate a joint offer that provides real added value.                         If so, I think it would be a good time for us to consider increasing our volume on HUB.                         This would require a step change in your handling efficiency, so I'd be interested in discussing your plans for the upgrade.                         Best regards,                         Paul
output_text:
From: ira@example.com
To: rettig@example.com, nogales@example.com
Subject: Potential Collaboration and Business Opportunities
Timestamp: 2023-09-01 08:30
Body: Dear Messrs Rettig and Nogales, I've heard rumors about your discussions to form a new entity and would like to confirm if this is correct. Such a partnership could indeed bring tremendous added value to the industry. Assuming this goes forward, it might be an opportune time for us to consider increasing our activity levels on HUB. However, this would necessitate significant improvements in your operational efficiency. I am keen to understand more about your upgrade plans and how they could support our expanded engagement. Best regards, Ira

---

To: ira@example.com
Subject: Re: Potential Collaboration and Business Opportunities
Timestamp: 2023-09-01 14:15
Body: Dear Ira, Thank you for reaching out. Indeed, we are in advanced discussions to form a new entity that we believe will offer real value to the industry. We appreciate your consideration of increased volumes on HUB and understand the implications for operational efficiency. We are currently planning significant upgrades to our systems and processes and would be glad to discuss how these could meet your needs for enhanced activity levels. Best regards, Paul

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Basil,                    Could you handle 5,400MT of vegetable oil from Aqaba to Mombasa, with full documentation? And how much is your storage fee?                    Regards,                    Sina
Email 2:
From: _Sina?_
To: _Ivan?_
Sent: _Thursday, August 19, 2010 9:17:08 AM_
Subject: RE: Storage

> How much is your storage fee? 


   _> And who will deliver this quantity to our factory?_ 

So, there was this corporation who asked about our storage and delivery cost. First question they asked was about storage cost. I made sure to talk about all different prices based on different quantities and then I explained the storage conditions. I never mentioned that in my price I included free delivery to the factory, in my opinion it is better to ask all questions before talking about details. You do not know what questions they can ask.

When I received the email below, I was a bit shocked about the question. However I managed to answer it quickly as follows:

Sina

From:
Email 3:
> _We can handle your storage in Mombasa. The price is 1.2$/MT on 1 month with total quantity of 5,400MTs. We can deliver the cargo by truck directly to your factory. But the price depends on the distance._ 


> _For example, from Mombasa port to Machakos it is 70 Km. The price is 40/MT. From Mombasa to Athi river it is 50KM. The price is 30/MT._


> _Regards, Basil_ 


Dear Sina, Thank you for your email. We can handle your storage in Mombasa. The price is 1.2$/MT on 1 month with total quantity of 5,400MTs. We can deliver the cargo by truck directly to your factory. But the price depends on the distance. For
output_text:
From: sina@example.com
To: basil@example.com
Subject: Request for Storage and Transport
Timestamp: 2010-08-19 09:00
Body: Hi Basil,
Could you handle 5,400MT of vegetable oil from Aqaba to Mombasa, with full documentation? Additionally, could you let me know your storage fee in Mombasa? 
Regards,
Sina

---

From: basil@example.com
To: sina@example.com
Subject: RE: Request for Storage and Transport
Timestamp: 2010-08-19 10:22
Body: Dear Sina,
Thank you for your email. We can handle your storage in Mombasa. The storage price is $1.2/MT for a month for a total quantity of 5,400MTs. We also offer cargo delivery by truck directly to your factory, and the price varies depending on the distance. For example, from Mombasa port to Machakos (70 km), the price is $40/MT and from Mombasa to Athi River (50 km), the price is $30/MT.
Regards,
Basil

Email 1:
<START EMAIL C>                    Hi Nicole,                    Can you please send a quotation for 15,000DWT vessel on a delivery basis for the early April loading for tanker grade of 0.25% S Furnace Oil?                    Thanks in advance,                    Liam
Email 2:
A: Thanks for the info. It will be around 55.00 cts GTT at your port. Please confirm the vessel is in a condition and class as per samples.                    Nicole

My thoughts
With so much missing information, there was no way I could provide an accurate quote at this stage.

Let’s see how they reply:
<Email 3>:
Hello Nicole,
1) Please confirm that the cargo is gas oil not furnace oil.
2) Please confirm the vessel is in a condition and class as per samples.
Regards,
Liam

Ok, that’s slightly better.

1) We will not accept GAS OIL cargo. We are only accepting FURNACE OIL.

2) Yes, the cargo will be in good class and condition. We only accept high quality petroleum products.

Regards,
Liam

<Email 4>:
Nicole,
1)

input_text:
Email 1:
Good Morning,                    We have a load of 150k MT of crude oil coming out of Vung Tau on 22nd September. The cargo should be shipped in Hapag Lloyd vessel, perhaps with the product name “XONE”.                    Can you advise us if your vessel is available for this cargo?                    We’re grateful for your help.                    Best regards,                    Natalie                    [Your address]
Email 2:
Dear [Your name],                    Our cargo of crude oil “XONE” will come out of Vung Tau in Vietnam on the 20th of September on board the Hapag Lloyd vessel “Venezuela”.                    How can we send you this cargo?                    We are looking forward to hearing from you.                    Best regards,                    [Your name]                    [Your address]

I would like to share with you a couple of situations I have recently experienced regarding sales. The main factor here is that every port of origin in this region has its own cargo’s name that differs from one port to another. Let me give you an example. Vung Tau’s oil is usually known as “XONE”, for example. If the cargo’s origin was not Vung Tau, it would be known as something different. In the first email, the seller is probably from Vung Tau, the port
Email 3:
<3>
Thanks for your email.                    We have an available vessel. Could you please share the port of origin?                    Thanks.                    Best regards,                    [Your name]                    [Your address]

so he doesn’t want to use the common port of origin name, but he wants to use the name of the port where his product originates from.

We have, however, to be cautious when receiving information from an agent, because often it is not completely correct. If the agent wants to sell his cargo by using an incorrect cargo name, it is much easier for him to trick the buyer by giving a name that has a higher profit for him, or a name that is more familiar for the potential buyer. This issue is something that we have to be aware of. We have to make sure that the cargo is what we think it is, and if we’re sure that we know the exact

Please advise your preferred vessels and vessels you are willing to consider. Ms. Ambrose

input_text:
Email 1:
We need to ship 4,000MT of HFO from Fujairah to Dar es Salaam. Are you in the market, and are these port dues included in your rate?                    Best regards,                    Donald
Email 2:
Fujairah/Dar es Salaam. We are ready to pay $1,900/MT CIF Dar es Salaam.                     Best regards,                     Donald
Email 3:
We need to ship 4,000MT of HFO from Fujairah to Dar es Salaam. Are you in the market, and are these port dues included in your rate?                     Best regards,                     Donald


They get a reply to only the last email. There are reasons why they could be having difficulty in getting through to their target. This happens frequently when it comes to end-user targets in emerging markets.
I always leave two days in my inbox to send another follow up email after the first one is sent and then at the end of the day send another one. This seems to work better than the more traditional 3-day/3-email rule.

While we see high open rates, it’s possible that the real target isn’t looking for the product at this time and may not have read the email. You don’t really know for sure unless you get a reply from the target

<Email 4>:
 On Mon, May 20, 2019 at 05:54 PM,  wrote:

* Why the captain and other crew leave the bridge, walk away from the wheel, and forget where the wheel is? Is this typical, or is it just human nature?

 It is not typical. Any crew that is leaving the bridge for more than a few minutes will usually assign a watchkeeper and/or specify exactly where the wheel is. If the owner insists on an automatic pilot watchkeeper, it is up to the captain to comply. But that would not be my recommendation.

* If the vessel is in or near a harbor or channel where there are many vessels and navigating is a challenge, why do the ships leave the bridge and let the ship just drift out of control? Would not knowing exactly where the wheel is be a problem? I am talking about not having a person at the helm ready
Email 5:
Mr. McDonough,

I think your data show that the cost of maritime transportation has dropped significantly over the past three years, although the bunker prices have climbed.

Could you please compare two particular time periods? Thanks.

Best Regards,

Heather

Elliot

input_text:
Email 1:
<WRITE EMAIL C>                    Now email yourself the three emails and compare them. How are they the same? How are they different? Why does it matter?
                                    Write a draft of a short letter you would send to an expert in the field of your career interest. The letter should explain your interest and describe your academic background and experience. Introduce an area of inquiry about the field in which you are interested, and end with a request to speak with this expert about career possibilities in the field. Draft this letter to this week’s guest speaker, Dr.
Email 2:
Dear <NAME>,
I am writing to you because I am highly interested in computer engineering and in designing advanced technology, and I want to know what steps I can take to reach my goal. I want to know what work and learning opportunities are available in computer engineering. I have found out a lot about computer engineering and I have done the research. I want to know what path I need to take to become successful in computer engineering. I have taken a number of classes and learned about the core material that I need for computer engineering.
I want to have more information about computer engineering and what experiences you had in this field. I want to know what steps you took to get to where you are now, and what I need to do to get there. I have done some research, but I do not know what my next step is.
I want to know what classes I should take and what organizations
Email 3:
Dear <NAME>,
My name is <NAME>. I would like to write to you for a few questions that have been bugging me. I have heard of many stories about how to get into a career path I am interested in, and I am wondering which one to follow. I’m interested in psychology as a career and have tried to look into what steps I need to take to get where I want to be.
I would like to know what steps I should take to become successful in psychology. I know that I need to major in psychology and complete my requirements. I also know that there are many other requirements to become successful, like doing internships and taking many more classes. I want to know what your experience was, and what I need to do to get where you are now.
Thank you for your time,

I want to know what steps I can take to reach my goal, including potential work and learning opportunities in this field. So far, my academic journey includes a number of classes focusing on the core material necessary for a career in computer engineering. However, I am uncertain about my next step and would appreciate insights on what additional classes I should take and what organizations I might consider joining. Could you share your experiences and the steps you took to achieve your current position? Any guidance on how to navigate my career path would be immensely helpful. Thank you for your time and consideration.

Email 2:
Gwen,                We've just received your inquiry. We'd be glad to assist you with your cargo and the following is our offer.                MAIZE            PURCHASE PRICE: CIF MYR (Malaysian Ringgit) USD 118 per MT MYR 4,410.00 per MT                FREIGHT COST: FCL BASIS MYR 1.75 per 1,000 KGS MYR 17,500.00 per 10,000 MT (10,000 MT = 10 TONS)                TOTAL: MYR 4,427.50 per MT                    TRANSPORTING VESSEL : MV MING SHENG HAI (CRUISE 0301), 2005 BUILT, IMO 9301712                VESSEL'S STOWAGE CAPACITY : 50,000 MT                CONSIGNMENT : 10,000 MT

- Commodity: Maize
- Purchase Price: CIF Port Klang 
- Rate: USD 118 per MT (equivalent to MYR 4,410.00 per MT)

Transport Details:

- Build Year: 2005
- IMO Number: 9301712
- Stowage Capacity: 50,000 MT

Best regards,
Calvin

output_text:
From: anna@example.com
To: jared@example.com
Subject: Freight Quote Inquiry for Isopropanol Shipment
Timestamp: 2023-09-01 09:30
Body: Dear Jared,

Could you please provide me with CFR and FOB rates for an 80-ton shipment of 94% Isopropanol from Houston to Tuxpan? I appreciate your assistance.

Many thanks,
Anna

---

From: jared@example.com
To: anna@example.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Inquiry for Isopropanol Shipment
Timestamp: 2023-09-01 10:45
Body: Hi Anna,

Regarding your request, I've checked with an IPA trader here in Houston. He was surprised by the requested tonnage; typically he deals with much larger quantities, like 10,000 tonnes. However, we should still be able to arrange something for 80 tonnes.

1) For your other query: Who can prepare an ISCO from Tuxpan to Veracruz promptly?
2) And could you confirm how much per ton you're anticipating for this rate?

Thanks in advance for your responses.

Best,
Jared

input_text:
Email 1:
Good evening Mr. Menéndez,                    We’ll need a calculation for 3,000MT of diesel from Rotterdam to the 13 docks at Aarhus. Does the 24/7 service you provide include all seasonal holidays?                    Kind regards,                    Abbie
Email 2:
Thanks, Abbie,        Here are some details.        Please do your calculations assuming a spread of 5 to 15 days for loading. If you use 10 days, please note that it will make your calculation more conservative.        These are some other terms you need to consider:        – guaranteed loading window 5 days (as a rule, we do 10% out of this time if the barge is ready at the quay or 10% per day extra from our client’s terminal if the barge is not ready at the quay).        – rotation time: 24h maximum        – unloading time: 24h maximum        – total transit time: 48h        – all statutory holidays are considered normal workdays for shippers.        – routing: Oslo-Fredericia-Middelfart-Harsholm-Portland-Jakobsen        –
output_text:
From: abbie@example.com
To: menendez@shippingco.com
Subject: Request for Diesel Calculation and 24/7 Service Clarification
Timestamp: 2023-10-05 18:30
Body: Good evening Mr. Menéndez,

I would like to request calculations for transporting 3,000 metric tons of diesel from Rotterdam to the 13 docks at Aarhus. Additionally, could you please confirm if your 24/7 service coverage includes all seasonal holidays?

Kind regards,
Abbie

---

From: menendez@shippingco.com
To: abbie@example.com
Subject: Re: Request for Diesel Calculation and 24/7 Service Clarification
Timestamp: 2023-10-06 09:15
Body: Hello Abbie,

Thank you for your inquiry. Here are the details for your request:

- Assume a loading spread of 5 to 15 days. For a more conservative calculation, you might consider using 10 days.
- Guaranteed loading window is 5 days. Note that we charge 10% extra of the loading time if the barge is ready at the quay or 10% per day extra from our client’s terminal if the barge is not ready.
- Rotation time is capped at 24 hours.
- Unloading time is also limited to 24 hours.
- Total transit time is estimated at 48 hours.
- All statutory holidays are considered normal workdays for our shipping operations.
- The routing will cover Oslo, Fredericia, Middelfart, Harsholm, Portland, and Jakobsen.

Please let me know if you need any more information.

Best regards,
Mr. Menéndez

input_text:
Email 1:
Mr. Regan,                    Our provider M&N sent us a price of 16.74US/MT to ship jet fuel from Kaohsiung to Daesan via m/v. Do you think this is acceptable?                    Thank you,                    David
Email 2:
David,                         We need to add the price of bunker to shipowners is more expensive than selling bunker, since our agent will pay for all bunker in VETSA trades.                    Also please consider the fact that our ship is selling product from Daesan to India before load jet to Daesan.                    So it will be 16.74 US/MT with bunker at VETSA trades.                    Hope this helps.                    Let me know what you think.                    Eddie
                    
<Email 3>:                      If I understand you correctly you need to make an estimate at load (in this case Daesan) about how much bunker will be consumed until the vessel arrives in discharge port. However, in reality most of the bunker will be consumed when the vessel travels from load to discharge port and you should pay to us the bunker consumed only from discharge port to load. In this case as we see from the
output_text:
From: david@example.com
To: regan@example.com
Subject: Shipping Rate Inquiry for Jet Fuel from Kaohsiung to Daesan via M&N Provider
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 10:15
Body: Dear Mr. Regan,

Our provider M&N has quoted us a freight rate of $16.74/MT to ship jet fuel from Kaohsiung to Daesan via the motor vessel. Could you please confirm if this rate is acceptable?

Thank you,
David

---

From: regan@example.com
To: david@example.com
Subject: Re: Shipping Rate Inquiry for Jet Fuel from Kaohsiung to Daesan via M&N Provider
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 12:30
Body: Hi David,

We should consider that the cost to the shipowners for bunkers is generally higher compared to what we make from selling the bunker in VETSA trades. Additionally, keep in mind that our vessel will be involved in transporting products from Daesan to India before loading jet fuel for Daesan. Therefore, the overall cost including bunker for VETSA trades would be $16.74 US/MT.

I hope this information is helpful. Let me know your thoughts.

Best regards,
Eddie

---

From: david@example.com
To: regan@example.com
Subject: Clarification on Bunker Consumption Costs
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 14:45
Body: Hello Eddie,

If I understand correctly, you're suggesting that an estimate of bunker consumption should be made at the load port (Daesan), reflecting usage only until the vessel arrives at the discharge port. However, it's typical practice that most of the bunker is consumed en route from load to discharge port, and payment for bunker should only cover that segment.

Does this align with our usual practices, or are there adjustments to be made?

Regards,
David

Email 1:
Hi Carlos,                    Could you take on 11,400MT of kerosene from New Orleans to Jacksonville? Any ideas on extra insurance premiums for weeknd deliveries?                    Thanks,                    Vitoria
Email 2:
dave,                    look at the surface tanker jet fuel route chart on the www and do the calculations. The distance is only 275 miles and if you cut through the shallows then it's maybe only 250 miles.                    With the shallowest part 43 feet, a 35,000 ton tanker would only use about 16' of water to float. If a tanker could travel through the route, I'm sure that the insurance premiums wouldn't be a major problem.                    I could not find any such tanker out there right now so it's not a matter of just connecting the dots.                    The insurance companies would calculate that if there is a loss, there is no place for the ship to refuel on the route, so the insurance rates might be higher.                    Bob
Email 3:
Al Williams                    I have loaded this PDF file to "www.surfacetankers.info". Please, let me know if it is working!                    Thanks!                    Bob                    Bob Loeschcke


<Email 4>:
RE: IN/OUT service of 250K+ Tankers between Miami and Rio de Janeiro                    Tuesday, April 5, 2005 6:43 PM                    When I googled "surfacetankers.info" it showed 5 references. The first showed the map of the Ghyben-Herzberg limited water zone - which is what we were looking for!                    If you know anyone that has a 250K bbl tanker (for about 12M gallons) that wants to go to Brazil, I would like to talk to them.                    The reason for wanting this tanker would be to offload it in the Bahamas at the large

From: vitoria@example.com
To: carlos@example.com
Subject: Transport Inquiry: Kerosene Shipment from New Orleans to Jacksonville
Timestamp: 2023-03-10 09:15
Body: Hi Carlos,
Could you handle a shipment of 11,400MT of kerosene from New Orleans to Jacksonville? Additionally, could you provide details on extra insurance premiums for weekend deliveries?
Thanks,
Vitoria

---

From: bob@example.com
To: dave@example.com
Subject: Tanker Analysis for Jet Fuel Route
Timestamp: 2023-03-10 10:30
Body: Dave,
Please refer to the surface tanker jet fuel route chart available online and perform the necessary calculations. The route is approximately 275 miles, shortened to about 250 miles if we navigate through the shallows. With the shallowest part being 43 feet deep, a 35,000-ton tanker would require about 16 feet of water to float. An appropriate tanker traveling through this route should not significantly affect the insurance premiums, although the absence of refueling options along the route could potentially raise the rates.
Unfortunately, I couldn't locate any available tankers that meet these specs at the moment.
Best,
Bob

---

From: bob.loeschcke@example.com
To: al.williams@example.com
Subject: PDF Upload Confirmation
Timestamp: 2023-03-10 11:00
Body: Hi Al,
I have uploaded the PDF file to www.surfacetankers.info. Please check if it's accessible and fully functional.
Thanks!
Bob

---

From: al.williams@example.com
To: bob.loeschcke@example.com
Subject: Re: PDF Upload Confirmation
Timestamp: 2023-03-10 17:43
Body: Bob,
I searched for 'surfacetankers.info' and found 5 references. The first reference displayed the map of the Ghyben-Herzberg limited water zone, just as we needed. If you have any connections with operators of a 250K bbl tanker that wants to go to Brazil, I'm interested in discussing further. Reason being, I'd like to offload it in the Bahamas.
Best regards,
Al

---

From: lchen@example.com
To: george@example.com
Subject: Re: Freight Inquiry for Multiple Cargos
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 17:45
Body: Hello George,

For the cargo arrangements, you can consider:
1. One CIF option if there's direct berthing at the second port, otherwise, two CIF options apply.
2. Two FIO options, noting there is no guarantee (Consideration for a Charter Party may be advisable).

Have a good evening.

Best regards,
Larry

---

From: lchen@example.com
To: george@example.com
Subject: Re: Freight Inquiry - Additional Information
Timestamp: 2023-03-02 10:15
Body: Hi George,

As additional information, Geary Tankers B.V. has limited experience with HFO cargoes. For your reference, here are some previous case examples:
- Malange to Pointe Noire: 1,500 tons HFO, CIF with double nomination in Porto Amboim, earned $34,000 with time charter at $22,000.
- For Rotterdam bookings: HFO dated 9/24/2012, 7,000 tons at USD 33.75/MT, and on 9/20/2012, 4,000 mt HFO.

If these suit your planning goals, let us know how we can assist further.

Best,
Larry

---

From: lchen@example.com
To: george@example.com
Subject: Re: Oil Contract Case Histories
Timestamp: 2023-03-02 15:20
Body: Hello George,

For your reference, Geary Tankers B.V. previously handled two oil contract cases:
1. Oil delivery from Curacao to Pointe-a-Pitre in Guadeloupe.
2. Oil sale from Fort-de-France in Martinique to Pointe-a-Pitre.

The former involved 2,000 mt HFO to M/S Mayflower Bayside under CIF terms with legal complications, and delivery to a named port (Port Louis in Guadeloupe) for Epsilon Tankers Corporation.

Best regards,

From: logistics@shippingco.com
To: gordon@example.com
Subject: Re: Request for Cargo Shipment Details
Timestamp: 2018-07-03 15:30
Body: Dear Mr. Gordon,

Thank you for your inquiry regarding the transportation of 5,000MT of cocoa beans to Belgium. We can accommodate your request. Here are the details of our quotation:

- Loading ports: Accra (ACC) and Tema (TEM)
- Unloading port: Antwerp (ATE)
- Estimated Time of Departure: 13th July 2018
- Vessel Capacity: 45,000MT
- Delivery: 3 days after loading in Accra

Please be informed that our policy requires full vessel loading. For more information or to discuss the freight rate, please contact me on my mobile at +44 1234 567 890.

Thanks and best regards,
Team Logistics Department

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Jack,                    I’m trying to secure a spot for 20,000 MT of iron ore from Virginia to Turkey. After-hours berthing is an option, but we’re flexible. Could you get back to me with some options for the next week and next month?                    Thanks,                    Susanna
Email 2:
Just to follow up, we're still in need of options from Turkey. What do you suggest for a daily service to Turkey, starting next week? This is urgent.
    Dear Susanna,  
        Our liners operate out of Virginia, Houston and Long Beach, and to Istanbul, İzmir, Kütahya, and Antalya. We also have a weekly direct service to İzmir from Savannah. It’s a fast service, it takes about 14 days from loading in the US to discharging in Turkey. If you’re interested in shipping from Houston, it’s an 11 day trip to Antalya. All of these routes can be served from one of our 3 weekly services. For a monthly schedule, please visit our website. We don’t accept individual bookings, so you would need to find a freight forwarder or consolidator to place your booking.
    Jack
output_text:
From: susanna@example.com
To: jack@example.com
Subject: Inquiry: Iron Ore Transport from Virginia to Turkey
Timestamp: 2023-10-01 09:30
Body: Hi Jack,

I'm currently looking to secure transportation for 20,000 MT of iron ore from Virginia to Turkey. We are exploring options including after-hours berthing and are flexible with the schedule. Can you please provide me with available shipping options for next week and the upcoming month?

Thanks,
Susanna

---

From: susanna@example.com
To: jack@example.com
Subject: Urgent: Follow-Up on Shipping Options to Turkey
Timestamp: 2023-10-02 08:15
Body: Hi Jack,

Just following up on my previous email as we urgently need to finalize the shipping options from Virginia to Turkey. What do you suggest for daily services starting next week?

Thanks,
Susanna

---

From: jack@example.com
To: susanna@example.com
Subject: Re: Urgent: Follow-Up on Shipping Options to Turkey
Timestamp: 2023-10-02 14:05
Body: Dear Susanna,

Our liners operate out of Virginia, Houston, and Long Beach in the US, and provide services to Istanbul, İzmir, Kütahya, and Antalya in Turkey. We offer a weekly direct service from Savannah to İzmir which is quite swift, taking just about 14 days end-to-end. For shipments from Houston to Antalya, the transit is approximately 11 days. We provide services three times a week from these locations. For a detailed monthly schedule, please visit our website. Remember that we do not handle individual bookings directly; you will need to engage a freight forwarder or consolidator to manage your booking.

Best regards,
Jack

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Owen,                    Our Australian customer wants to ship some powdered milk from Port Botany in Sydney to Tokyo. The contract says 2,500MT, but they might also require 1,500MT of grain. This order will leave in the first week of July. We need your help.                    How much would shipping 4,000MT of both goods together cost, and do you see any risk of port congestion?                    Many thanks,                    Ivy
Email 2:
Hi Ivy,
Good morning.

The order for 2,500MT should be easy to manage.
Regarding the order for 1,500MT of grain, unfortunately, we do not see any vessel available to fit both cargoes in the same vessel. As we are still in June, there are still some free slots available on July, but as the order size is so big, we have limited choices.
That being said, we can manage to fit 1,000MT of milk powder and 1,500MT of grain in the same vessel with the owner of a 10,000dwt M/V which is due to discharge the previous cargo in July. All details about the vessel are as follows:

M/V T1
Type    General Cargo
Flag    Liberia
Call    MOYO
Deadweight    8,600MT
Built    1996
Hold No
Email 3:
Regarding the risk of port congestion in Australia, I'm afraid the situation is getting worse and that it may be difficult to find a slot for such a big order. Also, the railway terminals are overloaded as well.
I know the situation seems very bad. I can only offer you the best available. If you are willing to wait till October, I can offer you a better slot with more space. This way, you will be able to fit more products, or reduce the price.
What do you think?
Email 4:
Thank you for your help. The information you provided is very useful to us. 
We want to ship the 4,000MT cargo in early July. We do not have enough storage capacity, so if we delay the delivery, it may lead to the depreciation of our goods, so I'm afraid we can only choose the original plan.
Also, we will have more orders to deliver in July. Can you please help us?
Waiting for your reply!
Regards,
Ivy
Best regards,
Martin
Email 5:
Hi Ivy,

I understand that you have to deliver the order at the earliest opportunity, and that you can't wait till October. I'll look for a slot in September for you.

Please find attached a quotation for 3,000MT and 4,000MT. We can ship 1,000MT in July and 2,000MT or 3,000MT in August. I can fit 2,000MT on a 6,000dwt M/V which is due to discharge in September and 3,000MT on a 6,500dwt M/V which is due to discharge in September as well.

Do you have a choice of milk powder or grain as the cargo to be shipped in August?
Thank you.

Regards,
Martin
output_text:
From: ivy@clientcompany.com
To: owen@shippingco.com
Subject: Shipping Order Query for July - Urgent
Timestamp: 2023-06-15 09:30
Body: Hello Owen, Our Australian customer is planning to ship 2,500MT of powdered milk and possibly an additional 1,500MT of grain from Port Botany, Sydney to Tokyo. This shipment is scheduled for the first week of July. We need a quotation for shipping a total of 4,000MT. Could you also advise on the risk of port congestion at this time? Many thanks, Ivy

---

From: owen@shippingco.com
To: ivy@clientcompany.com
Subject: Re: Shipping Order Query for July - Vessel Availability
Timestamp: 2023-06-15 12:45
Body: Hi Ivy, Good morning. We can certainly handle the 2,500MT of powdered milk. However, fitting both cargoes in the same vessel poses a challenge due to their combined size. We have the M/V T1, a general cargo vessel flagged in Liberia (Call sign MOYO, DWT 8,600, built in 1996), which could accommodate 1,000MT of powdered milk and 1,500MT of grain. Let me know if this suits your needs. Best, Owen

input_text:
Email 1:
<BEGIN EMAIL C>                    Ms. Stevens:                    I will be at your office tomorrow for 30 minutes. Please let me know if you're free or if you want to meet elsewhere.                    Sincerely,                    Nastya
Email 2:
<BEGIN EMAIL C>                    I'm totally free tomorrow. See you tomorrow!                    Sincerely,                    Nastya

One of my workmates asked me how to answer this email. I am not sure myself. I've answered questions like these one here, but they were much more easy:

1)  Say good night to Mommy!
2)  Well, take your time!
3)  Of course I'll help you. When and where?
4)  That sounds great! I'll bring the umbrella.
5)  I know. It is not important.

What is the correct way to answer to Nastya in this email?

There is a pattern for this type of 2-part email that I've observed in some specific contexts:

1. The first part is like a sign-off: "Sincerely, Nastya". 2. The second part is the
Email 3:
<My name here> looks forward to your response.
<Email 4>:
<My name here> looks forward to speaking with you further.
<Email 5>:
<My name here> looks forward to meeting with you.
<Email 6>:
<My name here> looks forward to your call.
<Email 7>:
<My name here> looks forward to learning more about your situation.


This usage appears to be common in the auto industry, with online car reviews.

Here is a blog post on this, which cites a data-driven analysis from a company called Radian6:

https://hbr.org/2013/01/the-secret-language-of-email

If we take that at face value, then one possible answer to the email in the question is:

[EMAIL 8]
Please let me know if you're free or if you want to meet elsewhere.
[EMAIL 9]
Email 4:
<My name here> looks forward to speaking with you further.
<Email 5>:
<My name here> looks forward to meeting with you.
<Email 6>:
<My name here> looks forward to your call.
<Email 7>:
<My name here> looks forward to learning more about your situation.

Please let me know if you're free or if you want to meet elsewhere.
[EMAIL 9]

 We look forward to learning more about your situation.

Email 2:
Hello, George
I have received your e-mail. Thanks for asking us for this enquiry.
This is my first reply to you.

First of all, can you give me the type of coal you plan to ship (NSC, ARA, etc.) and also the port of loading at Barry (BPT, UKCOAL, etc.)

The best way is to proceed with time charter.
Most of shipping companies are hard to find the right vessel because of a lack of high specification open cargo handlings. However, I can check and suggest you to you.
I will try to provide you the following details:
1. The vessel that is available in market
2. The cost estimate

Please feel free to contact me anytime and I will be delighted to be of assistance.
Thank you very much.
Kind regards,

Noah

Cape Shipping Ltd.

However, we may be able to find a vessel that suits your requirement.

If it is no problem, can you give me the delivery port of discharge (namely, the name of the country of discharge).

And also, can you specify the size of the vessel you are looking for?

Waiting for your reply.                            Noah

I can do both.
A port of discharge is Alexandria. I need a vessel of 80,000MT DWT, plus 10,000

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Ms. Ghosh,                    My group is sourcing 25,000MT of rubber from Shanghai to Salem. We can be very flexible on loading, but need to know your thoughts on two possible shipping methods:                    1. 50/50 via Hoegh Autoliner 85 and Maersk Ode. How much extra would be this compared to a typical voyage at your current market price?                    2. 33/67 via Golden Highway and Damleev. Is there any discount available if we book these voyages for 2016 as well?                    Sincerely,                    Sarah
Email 2:
Dear Sarah,                        Glad to get your inquiry. Actually, I have just sent an email regarding the new liner service through Hoegh Autoliner 85 and Maersk Ode to VRS China. Let me know if you get that. I am not sure about the sea transport to India since I am not from that dept. But I would like to go for the FCL rate of Hoegh Autoliner as there is an attractive rate by these carriers.                    One of my friends of Taiwan is also very interested in this carrier. She will go for 10/20 cbm containers. But they were waiting for the government’s final approval. Anyway, please wait for our China dept’s advice.                    Any other queries please contact me at any time.                    Have a nice day!                    Yours faithfully,                    Rita Lee


This email exchange reveals the organizational culture at logistics
Email 3:
Subject: 50/50 via Hoegh Autoliner 85 and Maersk Ode?
Rita,   I got your message about Hoegh Autoliner 85 and Maersk Ode. Thank you for the offer! Do you have any indication on the timing of the service? In addition, do you think I should consider 33/67 via Golden Highway and Damleev as well? I did not include those carriers in the original email because my thinking was that they are more suitable for 2016. Still, the volumes will be the same for both years. Sarah


In this email exchange, Sarah was mainly interested in the future developments of Hoegh Autoliner 85 and Maersk Ode. She also mentioned that she wanted to discuss an alternative carrier, Golden Highway and Damleev.

<Email 4>:
Subject
output_text:
From: sarah@example.com
To: rita.lee@vrslogistics.com
Subject: Inquiry about Shipping Methods for Rubber from Shanghai to Salem
Timestamp: 2023-03-05 09:30
Body: Dear Ms. Ghosh,

My group is currently looking to source 25,000MT of rubber from Shanghai to Salem. We are quite flexible on the loading schedule but are exploring two possible shipping methods:
1. A 50/50 split shipment via Hoegh Autoliner 85 and Maersk Ode. Could you please provide how much extra this option would cost compared to a typical voyage at your current market rate?
2. A 33/67 split shipment via Golden Highway and Damleev. Can we avail any discount if we opt for this for 2016 as well?

Looking forward to your guidance.

Sincerely,
Sarah

---

From: rita.lee@vrslogistics.com
To: sarah@example.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry about Shipping Methods for Rubber from Shanghai to Salem
Timestamp: 2023-03-05 14:45
Body: Dear Sarah,

Thank you for your inquiry. I have forwarded your request to our China department for detailed advice as it pertains to the use of Hoegh Autoliner 85 and Maersk Ode, as I recently handled a similar query for another client. As for the sea transport to India, although it's not my direct area, I would recommend considering the Hoegh Autoliner for competitive rates.

I shall update you once I receive a response from our China department. Feel free to reach out with any additional queries in the meantime.

Have a great day!
Yours faithfully,
Rita Lee

---

From: sarah@example.com
To: rita.lee@vrslogistics.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry about Shipping Methods for Rubber from Shanghai to Salem
Timestamp: 2023-03-06 08:20
Body: Dear Rita,

I received your message and appreciate the update on Hoegh Autoliner 85 and Maersk Ode. Could you also let me know the anticipated timing for this service? Additionally, should I also consider the Golden Highway and Damleev routes for both 2015 and 2016, given that the volume requirements would remain the same for both years?

Thanks,
Sarah

Hi Jeremy,                   Thank you for the detailed information. The Port of Elizabeth is basically a bit “rustic”. Most of the coal is stored at berths which are up the hill or out of the water in a kind of side-loading facility. The coal berths are essentially ash ponds that are filled from barges, loaded from stockpiles, or loaded by rail. In any case, the coal must be transported in some way and the loading will depend on the coal berth. The average loading rate is between 600-800 mt/h, and with no draft restrictions or berthing limitations, we are expected to load at an average rate of 1500 mt/h. We can also do up to 2,000 mt/h if the coal can be delivered to the berth quickly and easily.

Be advised that in March, the water in the port will be very low. Because of

Timestamp: 2023-02-24 12:45
Body: Hi Jeremy, Thank you for the details. The Port of Elizabeth mostly uses side-loading facilities which are somewhat rustic. Most coal is stored up the hill or by the water’s edge. The loading is facilitated from ash ponds filled by barges, loaded from stockpiles or through rail. Given this setup and with no draft restrictions or berthing limitations, we expect to load at an average rate of 1,500 mt/h, potentially up to 2,000 mt/h if coal delivery is swift. Be advised, the water levels in the port will be very low in March. Regards, Brian

Yesterday you were looking for suitable vessels for 36,000 metric tonnes of glycol from Mexico to Luanda in Angola.                    I have a ship available.           36,000 MT = 36,000 ton x 1,000 kg/ton = 36,000,000 kg = 3,600 m3 at a density of 1 ton/m3                    The ship can carry 5,500,000 litres.                    5,500,000 litres x 1 m3/1,000 litres = 5,500 m3                    Let me know if this is suitable.                    The shipment costs US$100,000 (can be deducted from the commission that you pay to me)                   36,000 MT = 36,000 ton x 1,000 kg/ton = 36,000,000 kg = 3,600 m3
Email 3:
The price per litre is $10, so 5,500 m3 of ethanol is worth US$55,000.
The net profit for the shippers is US$55,000 - US$100,000 = US$55,000.
Let me know how you feel about this arrangement. 
Best regards,

100% net profit is $55,000

Please send a signed copy of the attached contract.  I will provide a copy for you to sign.
If you have any queries about this arrangement, please get back to me.

Dear Mr Steffes,                      Our Hamburg South America Line was approached by your agents E  \& T             Group to transport iron ore from Indonesia to South America.                 You are hereby invited to send your offers for the transport of 20,000mt of iron ore, with a laycan from 1st August to the beginning of September.                 The main characteristics are as follows:                      - the load will be from the Sumatra region                      - the cargo will be iron ore of Fe 62%                      - the discharge port is to be selected and confirmed by the buyer                 Please send all offers on a non-negotiable basis (ex works) in USD based on the FOB Hamburg price of iron ore (ie, US$78/mt). I understand your cargo will be subject to an inspection at the port of discharge.  Since this is out of our control, you should contact your

We understand your client will be taking full responsibility for their merchandise at the port of discharge. Therefore, they should assume responsibility 
for ensuring that their merchandise clears customs.  We understand that you are working with our agent at the port of discharge to file the necessary documents 
to clear the cargo.  However, if you encounter any problems, please feel
Email 4:

discharge to make sure all of the necessary documents are filed in order to clear the cargo.

for the cargo.

Email 1:
Hello Sir,                    Do you think a big container ship will be built in China? Is it better to own a small ship or to own an interest in a large container ship?                    Thank you,                    Andre
Email 2:
Dear Sir,
Since my last letter, I have been reading a
book on Containership Business and i have a
lot of ideas.
Here is one of them. Will a large container
ship be built in China? Is it a good
investment to own a small container ship or
to own an interest in a large ship? I
believe that the container shipping industry
will get better and better. At this time, the
shipping market is very strong.
Here is the conclusion:
It is better to own a small container ship
than to own an interest in a large container
ship. We should stick to our belief.
Thank you,
Andre
Email 3:
Dear Sir,
Since my last letter, I have been reading a
book on the Container Business and
understanding the idea. After a lot of
thinking, I found a logical solution.
It is better to own a small container ship
than to own an interest in a large container
ship. That is the truth. We can be more
stable in the long run.
Please do not forget what I have said. I am
waiting for your reply.
Thank you,
Andre

To: sir@example.com
Subject: Inquiry about Container Ship Investment
Timestamp: 2023-01-15 08:30
Body: Hello Sir,

I hope this message finds you well. I am curious about the construction of large container ships in China and wish to understand the better investment option between owning a small container ship and owning a partial interest in a larger one.

Thank you,
Andre

---

From: andre@example.com
To: sir@example.com
Subject: Further Insights on Container Ship Investments
Timestamp: 2023-01-22 09:15
Body: Dear Sir,

Following our previous correspondence, I have further educated myself by reading more on the container ship business. This research leads me to ask whether you think a significant container ship project is underway in China. Considering the robust state of the shipping market, I am evaluating the merits of differing investment scales in this industry.

From my readings and current market analysis, I lean towards the recommendation that owning a small container ship is more advantageous than holding an interest in a large vessel. Our strategic focus should continue to rest on this belief.

Thank you,
Andre

---

From: andre@example.com
To: sir@example.com
Subject: Conclusion on Container Ship Investment Strategy
Timestamp: 2023-01-29 10:20
Body: Dear Sir,

Further contemplation and research on our discussion about container ship investments have solidified my viewpoint. Holding ownership of a small container ship presents a more stable, long-term benefit compared to a partial stake in a larger ship. This conclusion stems from both market trends and the strategic positioning it offers.

Please consider my advice as you make future investment decisions in this area. I look forward to your thoughts or any decisions you might lean towards.

Thank you,
Andre

From: omar@example.com
To: vasquez@example.com
Subject: Inquiry About Sourcing Dalian Steel From Karachi to Vietnam
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 09:00
Body: Hi Ms. Vasquez,

I am new to shipping and am looking to source Dalian steel from Karachi for shipment to Vietnam. Could you possibly recommend some options or provide guidance on how to proceed? Thank you for your assistance.

Best regards,
Omar

---

From: vasquez@example.com
To: omar@example.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry About Sourcing Dalian Steel From Karachi to Vietnam
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 09:15
Body: Hello Omar,

Thank you for reaching out. To better assist you, could you please provide more details about the quantity of Dalian steel you intend to ship and any specific logistic preferences you have? This will help me recommend the most appropriate options.

Best, 
Ms. Vasquez

---

From: omar@example.com
To: vasquez@example.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry About Sourcing Dalian Steel From Karachi to Vietnam
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 09:35
Body: Hey Ms. Vasquez,

Thank you for the quick response. I am looking to ship approximately 100 metric tons of Dalian steel. I don't have specific preferences for logistics as I'm quite new to this, so any general advice would also be appreciated.

Thanks again,
Omar

---

From: vasquez@example.com
To: omar@example.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry About Sourcing Dalian Steel From Karachi to Vietnam
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 09:50
Body: Good day Omar,

With the details you've provided, I would suggest contacting Karachi Steel Logistics Co. They are experienced in handling shipments of Dalian steel and can assist in ensuring the steel is shipped efficiently and safely to Vietnam. I'm also forwarding some general shipping guidelines to help you get started.

Best regards,
Ms. Vasquez

---

From: omar@example.com
To: vasquez@example.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry About Sourcing Dalian Steel From Karachi to Vietnam
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 10:05
Body: Morning Ms. Vasquez,

Thank you for the recommendation and the resources. I will get in touch with Karachi Steel Logistics Co. and follow your advice. I appreciate your help in guiding a beginner in the field of shipping!

Best wishes,
Omar

input_text:
Email 1:
T-                        I hope this email finds you well. We have to ship some polymers from Rotterdam to Mexico City at the beginning of August. Will you send us a rate?                    Best regards,                    Thor
Email 2:
--         
   Anne-Marie,           
   I found another company offering sea transport from Rotterdam to Mexico City. Do you think you can still beat their rate?      
   Best regards,          
   Thor          

--         
When you give an estimate, it will give the exact rate. It is correct if the pickup and delivery dates are the same and the amount of goods shipped is 50 CBM. If your pickup date is July 10, 2017, the delivery date is July 20, 2017, and the amount of goods shipped is 25 CBM, you can click the blue icon in the lower right corner. Change your preferred dates and change the amount of goods shipped.
   Our company charges $0.05 per CBM per day, so the extra cost is $25 ($25 CBM*0.05$ per CBM per day*20 days
Email 3:
--         
   Hello,           
   Do you have experience in moving polymers? Do you think your quote is correct? What is your contact information?                    
   Regards,                      
   Anne-Marie            
--         
Hello Anne-Marie, our quote is right. We have been moving polymers for many years. My contact information is below. 
   Contact: Anne-Marie
   Cellphone: 314 567 345
   Email:  [email protected]  aol.com

email 4:
--         
Hello Anne-Marie, I understand that your move is in August, not July. We can make changes to our quote for you. 
   Best regards,                    
   Thor
Email 4:
--         
The quote you gave is for July 10-20. Can you give me a new quote?
--         
Our quote is the same for the whole month of August. If the extra charge is high, you can use two shipping dates.
   Regards,                       
   Thor
   Email:  [email protected]  aol.com

Thor

---

If this has changed, please update your shipment details using the support icon on our site. Our base rate is $0.05 per CBM per day.

Best regards,
Anne-Marie

---

Anne-Marie

Thor

Marco

Best,
Tom

Email 1:
Hello Terry,                    We’re planning to book 7,000MT of cement from Colombo to Port Hedland. Could you provide the latest freight market and last available time charter information?                    Thank you,                    Galika
Email 2:
Dear Galika,                Hi Galika,                    I have spoken with my local freight market colleagues.                 The rate to Port Hedland is not as bad as we expected. Port Hedland rate is currently $10,500. There are 2 very good ships available for booking which are going to Dubai. The names are the SEABOURN PRESTIGE  and the  DOURO.                  Please let me know your available ship's age, safety and technical aspect as well.                 Thank you,               Terry
output_text:
From: galika@cementco.com
To: terry@freightforwarder.com
Subject: Freight Requirement from Colombo to Port Hedland
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 09:30
Body: Hello Terry,

We are planning to ship 7,000MT of cement from Colombo to Port Hedland. Could you provide the latest updates on the freight market and the last available time charter information?

Thank you,
Galika

---

From: terry@freightforwarder.com
To: galika@cementco.com
Subject: Re: Freight Requirement from Colombo to Port Hedland
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 14:45
Body: Dear Galika,

I've consulted with our local freight market experts. Fortunately, the rate to Port Hedland is currently at $10,500, which is better than we initially expected. There are two suitable vessels available, the SEABOURN PRESTIGE and the DOURO, both of which are slated to go to Dubai. Please let me know additional details about the ships' age, safety, and technical aspects that you might require.

Thank you,
Terry

input_text:
Email 1:
We’re thinking of shipping 9,000MT of crude oil from Jingtang to Spain. What’s your earliest availability, and how’s your rate?                    Thanks,                    Tim
Email 2:
Our rate is USD35 per MT, cargo shall load at Jingtang Oil Terminal on 12/15 Dec, ETA Spain on 17/25 Dec, you could confirm the charter today or not later than tomorrow.  Please email back your interest, thanks!

The timer I chose was 5 minutes. And the prompt was:

How did you come up with the shipping contract?

You can use PNP to shorten the time for expression. For example, to say

"we are thinking of shipping X amount of crude oil from A to B", "We'd like to buy X amount of crude oil from A to B", etc.

The PNP here is the “thinking of shipping”, “wanting to buy”, and the rest of the action words.

Since we were looking for clues on who had expressed interest in the cargo (Tim or Spain), this definitely should give you some
output_text:

From: rudolph@shipbroker.com
To: chris@logistics.com
Subject: Vessel Details and Inquiry Responses
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 16:45
Body: Hi Chris, Here are answers to your inquiries: 1. The ship returned in 14 days. 2. The total trip length was 28 days. 3. We chartered a bulk carrier. 4. The vessel's name is 'Ocean Voyager.' 5. ETA of the vessel is March 10, 2023. 6. Expected arrival time is 08:00 AM. 7. There could be a delay of up to 3 days. 8. The delay charges will be discussed upon confirmation of delay. 9. After discharging in the Philippines, the vessel will anchor at Port of Singapore. 10. It will take approximately 5 days to reach our port from there. 11. Q&A What’s the best time to use balticdirties?
When to use balticdirties ? Use balticdirties only if no other time charter data is available (e.g. in freight rate calculations). Typically, the day and time you check are important (e.g. if there is a tidal window). Do not use balticdirties in company charter party clauses if you have a term charter party clause.
