input_text:
Email 1:
I’m looking to ship a 3,400MT cargo of diesel oil from Rotterdam to Dakar. Could you please let me know if you have a vessel free to load at the end of August, and also confirm what your demurrage rates are?                    Cheers,                    Scott
Email 2:
Greetings!                   My name is Mary Wells. As a financial advisor to the Wilson family, I am pleased to introduce this matter to you, especially since you have proven your ability to carry out your operations without much delay.   I wish to inform you that the personal effects of my clients, Mrs.Glenda Wilson and Mr. Michael Wilson were loaded on to your vessel named MT “” and shipped from Southampton to Monrovia, Liberia, dated 10th May 2008.  I wish to inform you that the goods which comprises of one piece of one Rolls Royce and four pieces of Household goods have been detained by the Librerian authorities for the past three years as they claim that the customs documents were not properly filled.  This has forced Mrs. Glenda and Mr. Michael Wilson to incur huge demurrage and storage fees which they cannot afford to pay now. It
Email 3:
Thanks for your email and apologies for my delay in replying. I don’t think that there is an issue with the cargo in Liberia, it is no longer onboard the vessel but I have sent you a scan of a document from the shipping line saying that they can assist with releasing the cargo. It’s my feeling that there is a bureaucratic delay in Liberia and you might have to employ a solicitor to assist, do you have any ideas about that? Best regards, Scott
Email 4:
Ah yes, that explains a lot. We’ve not got any vessels at present. Sorry.
Regards
Steve

<Email 5>:
I have some information for you regarding what I’m sure will be your next job. You need to visit Liberia. I’ve made an arrangement with the Liberia international trade and transportation secretariat to assist you with the release of the cargo.
I’ll send you a document of authority signed by the director of the importation department at the customs department of Liberia. Do you have a representative there who will be able to pick it up on your behalf? If not, let me know and I’ll contact the Liberian secretary.
Don’t worry about the rest, I’ll handle it.
Regards,
Steve

<Email 6>:
We now have cargo in Rotterdam ready to load. It is 450mt and is diesel oil. Do you have a vessel

Email 1:
Hi Capt. Hu,                    We have 6,000 MT of iron ore to ship from Makassar to Surabaya. Please provide the best quote.                    Kind regards,                    Mr. Nguyen
Email 2:
Hi Capt. Hu,                    I have 1,000 MT of iron ore to ship from Makassar to Surabaya. Can you quote for my cargo?                    Kind regards,                    Mrs. Nguyen
Email 3:
Hi Capt. Hu,
I have 1,000 MT of iron ore to ship from Makassar to Surabaya. Can you quote for my cargo?
Kind regards,
Mrs. Nguyen
Email 4:
Hi Capt. Hu,
I need a quotation for the shipment of 1,000 MT of iron ore from Makassar to Surabaya.
Regards,
Mr. Nguyen

The expressions and sentences in each of the four emails are different and so the email might not be a good example of phishing attack.

(You are to decide)
=> i removed the word 4 after 1,000 MT in the email
After doing so, the two first emails have a similar structure and are difficult to distinguish.
=> Could you explain why?
=> Since 4 was removed, the emails could be written by two different persons. So 1,000 MT was not indicative of who wrote the email.
(Something related to Markov Chain and Bayesian networks is used)

• Markov Chains can be used to describe many processes in a way that enables understanding in a mathematical form.
• Markov processes
Email 5:
Hi Capt. Hu,
I have 1,000 MT of iron ore to ship from Makassar to Surabaya. Can you quote for my cargo?
Kind regards,
Mrs. Nguyen

If you click on the blue part, you get a pop-up.
The blue part is an example of something else being put on the Markov Chain.

<Email 6>:
Hi Capt. Hu,
I have 1,000 MT of iron ore to ship from Makassar to Surabaya. Can you quote for my cargo?
Kind regards,
Mrs. Nguyen

In this case, something has been added to the email.

• As a result, there are two ways to solve this problem. 1) It has two distinct topics or 2) It is one topic and is written by two persons.
• First, we find all possible combinations of 3 phrases and use

Thank you,                    Sophie
Email 2:

Thank you for your reply. Can you please send an estimated FOB price and any additional information you might have about laycan, ETA, and IFO price? We would like to discuss this shipment, although we might not need it as soon as you mentioned. But we could also be interested in the earlier date, so please send more details. Thank you,                     Sophie

Email 4:
If you are in direct contact with the buyer, please try to get the material specification. In this case, you need to be direct and say that you cannot send a freight quotation without that document. If they ask about the freight quotation first, share a rough estimate with a mention that it will be updated when you have the material specification. The buyer should realize that this is the only way for you to take an offer. It is your first line of defense against waste of time. Other brokers might not understand that they need to ask for the material specification because they do not have a "ship" yet, so they can only discuss price and laycan. This is very wrong, but I am sure it happens.  If you are an agent, you should receive the material specification from the buyer. If you don't have it, call your counterpart to discuss this. The situation I describe below

Thanks Pauline,

I checked the schedules and I think you mean the Commodore. This is our weekly spot cargo service, loading containers for France.

The Commodore berths at the South Container Terminal but we can't berth there this week. There are no slots available and the berths have to be occupied in a particular order.

South Container Terminal berths are occupied in this order:
5, 1, 2, 4, 7, 3, 6

Email 1:
Hello Mr. Batra,                    We expect to ship 3,000MT of motors from Singapore to Colombo by April 1st. Would your vessel be available for a short term voyage, and are you flexible on ballast condition?                    Best regards,                    Ernest
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Ernest,
                    The "Coastline" is currently berthed at Kakinada on Indian coast and I expect to receive her draft survey report on or about the 25th. Her charterers are currently assessing the bunkers required by the vessel for Singapore, however, we may be able to depart the previous fixture for Singapore as early as the 26th March.
                    As far as ballast conditions are concerned, your charterers could also try "Coastline's" current charterers (i.e. "Sambalino" of the same owners) as they will be arriving from a short haul fixture at the moment and may be in a position to proceed immediately to the loading port in ballast. Alternatively, you may wish to proceed ballast and obtain fuel in advance of loading.
                    Any more information you require please feel free to contact me on the below
Email 3:
Hi Mr. Batra,
                    May I request you to assist us in exploring with your owners the following options for our shipment as below:

1. Send the "Coastline" from Kakinada to your discharge port to arrive in 6 days time;
2. Send the "Coastline" from Kakinada to your discharge port to arrive in 10 days time;
3. Send the "Sambalino" from your discharge port to the Singapore loading port to arrive in 6 days time;
4. Send the "Sambalino" from your discharge port to the Singapore loading port to arrive in 10 days time;

                    As soon as the draft survey is received, I will forward you a copy with the same. In the meantime, if you require further information, please feel free to contact me on the below.

                    Thanks,
                    Ernest
Email 4:
Dear Mr. Batra,
                    Thank you for sending the Sambalino draft survey. I am pleased to inform you that Sambalino would arrive in 6 days. Please revert for futher details. We are expecting to send the draft survey of the Coastline shortly.
                    Best regards,
                    Ernest

Email 1:
Dear Mr. Wong,                    Are you able to give us a freight rate for a 2,000MT shipment of rubber from Guangzhou to Manila?                    Regards,                    Drew
Email 2:
Hi Joseph
Thank you for your mail. Please confirm the following details:
From
Destination
Quantity
Payment Terms
Export License
Delivery time
                    Thanks, 
                    Ting
Email 3:
Dear Ting
Shipment terms and conditions
From
Guangzhou, China
Destination
Manila, Philippines
Quantity
2,000MT (approximately 28,000 boxes, Gross 1000@1.2Tons)
Payment Terms
The exporter shall arrange a Bank Letter of Credit to the order of Kimono Inc. (Korean Export Company).  Cash / Bank Cashier Check in US Dollar at 60% of value in the Letter of Credit.  The balance shall be paid in cash upon confirmation of inspection results at origin.
Export License
Appropriate customs and commercial licenses
Delivery Time
By sea, with 21 days ex-work, 15-30 days by air, as per agreement.
                    Sincerely yours,
                    Drew Wong
Email 4:
Dear Drew
    1.  Your company shall provide a Letter of Credit in favor of Hapag-Lloyd (Shipping line)
    2.  You will be responsible for all taxes / duties and all associated costs including local, state and federal.
    3.  Your company will bear the cost of the shipment to include cost of packing and insurance.
    4.  The cost of the shipment shall be paid on the 10th day of the last month of every quarter.
    5.  Shipping schedule shall be agreed upon between your company and Hapag-Lloyd (Shipping line)
    6.  The shipment shall be delivered 30 days after shipment date.

                    Best regards,                   
                    Ting

P.S.  1000 Box is 2500.00 per tonne
    28,000 Box = 70,000

From: drew@example.com

Subject: Re: Freight Rate Inquiry for Rubber Shipment from Guangzhou to Manila
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 14:45
Body: Dear Ting,

Here are the shipment details:
- From: Guangzhou, China
- Destination: Manila, Philippines
- Quantity: 2,000MT (approximately 28,000 boxes, Gross 1000@1.2Tons)
- Payment Terms: The exporter shall arrange a Bank Letter of Credit to the order of Kimono Inc. (Korean Export Company). Cash / Bank Cashier Check in US Dollars at 60% of the value in the Letter of Credit. The balance shall be paid in cash upon confirmation of inspection results at origin.
- Export License: Appropriate customs and commercial licenses
- Delivery Time: By sea, with 21 days ex-work, 15-30 days by air, as per agreement.

Sincerely yours,
Drew Wong

---

From: joseph.wong@hapag-lloyd.com
To: drew@example.com
Subject: Re: Freight Rate Inquiry for Rubber Shipment from Guangzhou to Manila
Timestamp: 2023-03-02 08:20
Body: Dear Drew,

Thank you for providing the shipment details. Here are our terms:
1. Your company shall provide a Letter of Credit in favor of Hapag-Lloyd.
2. You will be responsible for all taxes/duties and all associated costs including local, state, and federal.
3. Your company will bear the cost of the shipment including the cost of packing and insurance.
4. The cost of the shipment shall be paid on the 10th day of the last month of every quarter.
5. The shipping schedule shall be agreed upon between your company and Hapag-Lloyd.
6. The shipment shall be delivered 30 days after the shipment date.

Best regards,
Ting

P.S. 1000 Box is 2500.00 per ton.
28,000 Box = 70,000

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Lyle,                    We’re considering shipping 35,000 metric tons of lumber from Vancouver to Inverness. Can you advise us about the import restrictions for pine?                    Warmly,                    Logan
Email 2:
Hi Logan.                    Thanks for your email.                    Unfortunately, the shipping of pine from Vancouver to Inverness is banned by law. I’m afraid we’re going to have to pass on your shipment.                    Lyle

### ID or OID for the Importer?

Actually, there’s an alternative – the business needn’t try to find out whether the lumber is in compliance with U.S. law, but simply can certify to that effect. A problem arises in distinguishing between logs and lumber, and lumber that has been cut and sawn and lumber that is not sawn. And even a commitment to pay for a formal inspection would not be sufficient to get past U.S. Customs’ questions. So, when the importing country wishes to assure itself that U.S. law is being complied with, the issuing country may provide an assurance in the form of an import certificate, an export certificate,
output_text:

To: lyle@example.com
Subject: Inquiry About Import Restrictions for Pine Lumber
Timestamp: 2023-03-05 09:15
Body: Hi Lyle, We are considering shipping 35,000 metric tons of pine lumber from Vancouver to Inverness. Could you please provide information regarding the import restrictions for pine in Inverness? Warmly, Logan

---

From: lyle@example.com
To: logan@example.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry About Import Restrictions for Pine Lumber
Timestamp: 2023-03-05 11:02
Body: Hi Logan, Thanks for reaching out. Unfortunately, the shipping of pine lumber from Vancouver to Inverness is currently prohibited by local regulations. Thus, we will not be able to proceed with your shipment as planned. Regards, Lyle

---

From: lyle@example.com
To: logan@example.com
Subject: Alternative Solutions for Lumber Shipment
Timestamp: 2023-03-05 11:25
Body: Following up on our earlier email, there is an alternative approach. Your business could certify compliance with the import regulations without explicit inspection from U.S. authorities, though it requires careful documentation. Common issues arise in distinguishing between logs and processed lumber. Even a commitment to pay for a formal inspection might not suffice to clear U.S. Customs without such certificates. An import or export certificate issued by the country of origin could be a viable way to demonstrate legal compliance. Let me know if you would like more details on this approach. Best, Lyle

Mark

Sven

From: john@example.com
To: james@example.com
Subject: Request for Shipping Quote to Singapore
Timestamp: 2023-01-15 09:30
Body: James,

We are looking to ship about 1000 cubic meters of 3-tonne cardboard boxes to Singapore. Can you provide me with a quote for shipping and inform us of the procedures upon arrival?

Regards,
John

---

From: james@example.com
To: john@example.com
Subject: Re: Request for Shipping Quote to Singapore
Timestamp: 2023-01-15 10:45
Body: John,

Could you specify the dimensions and type of the cardboard boxes? Additionally, please confirm that the boxes are empty and the precise weight and volume.

Thanks,
James

---

From: john@example.com
To: james@example.com
Subject: Re: Request for Shipping Quote to Singapore
Timestamp: 2023-01-15 11:05
Body: James,

They are standard kraft cardboard boxes with side flaps and are currently empty. We need to ship a total volume of 1000 cubic meters weighing 3 tonnes.

Regards,
John

---

From: james@example.com
To: john@example.com
Subject: Re: Request for Shipping Quote to Singapore
Timestamp: 2023-01-15 14:20
Body: John,

The price will depend on the container size you need. I would need to calculate the space utilized and the additional costs of securing the cargo. Could you tell me your preferences regarding the container dimensions?

Thanks,
James

---

From: john@example.com
To: james@example.com
Subject: Re: Request for Shipping Quote to Singapore
Timestamp: 2023-01-15 15:45
Body: James,

Thanks for the update. Could you send me a list of available container sizes along with their maximum weight and volume capacities? This would help me decide the most suitable option.

Regards,
John

---

From: james@example.com
To: john@example.com
Subject: Re: Request for Shipping Quote to Singapore
Timestamp: 2023-01-16 09:00
Body: John,

For your cargo, you might consider using the 20-foot containers, each can handle up to 5 tonnes. We can discuss further if this option suits your needs.

Best,
James

Oliver Moussa

Email 1: Dear Ms. Mohamed, It’s been almost a month since we last communicated. I was hoping you might be able to help me secure a tanker for a methanol shipment from S Korea to New Zealand. The tonnage required is 8,000 dwt, and can be loaded from mid to late May. Let me know if you need further details and I can send across some more info. Regards, Brad Email 2: Dear Mr. Thompson, Thank you for your email. We are an organization with a network of trading companies. We are willing to supply fuel to New Zealand for the time being. If there are no conflicting interests, would you consider us a partner in this? Please let me know if I can provide you with any other details or other information. Regards, Khadija ============================================ Note: No response from Ms. Mohamed. Email 3: Dear Khadija, We are interested in offering you our services, but we do have some questions first. Have you sent this email to anyone else? If yes, can you please share the number of receivers? Also, please note that it has come to our notice that you might be engaged in illegal activities. We have zero tolerance for such dealings, and are now trying to verify this information. If it turns out to be true, we will block your email account, and take the necessary action against you. Best regards, Alice

**Note: The responses given by email were not of a friendly nature and in some cases were unprofessional, and came across as unappreciative. So, we used the support department to get a second opinion and see what we can learn from this.**

We used GPT-3 to
output_text:
From: brad.thompson@example.com
To: khadija.mohamed@example.com
Subject: Request for Transport Services – Methanol Shipment
Timestamp: 2023-04-01 09:30
Body: Dear Ms. Mohamed,

This charterparty refers to a CBM charge of $1.20 per CBM as the basis of calculation for a FCN charter. output_text:
From: cassie.manwell@shippingco.com
To: james.parkin@freightlogistics.com
Subject: Freight Estimate Inquiry for LNG Shipment in July
Timestamp: 2023-06-01 09:30
Body: Dear Mr. Parkin,

Can you please provide a freight estimate for 6,000MT of LNG from Mopan in the US Gulf to Antwerp in July? Is port rotation compulsory for this service?

Kind Regards,
Cassie Manwell

---

From: james.parkin@freightlogistics.com
To: cassie.manwell@shippingco.com
Subject: Re: Freight Estimate Inquiry for LNG Shipment in July
Timestamp: 2023-06-02 14:15
Body: Dear Ms. Manwell,

Thank you for your enquiry. We have provided you a proposal for the movement of 6,000MT of LNG from the US Gulf to Antwerp in July. The price for this cargo is based on a fixed FOB rate. We can also offer this cargo with FCN, calculated at a CBM charge of $1.20 per CBM based on the declared volume. Both scenarios have a fixed CIF rate, with cargo delivered to the discharge port the same day. Port rotation can be arranged at the shipper's request, subject to agreement from all parties involved.

Please review the proposal and revert with your acceptance or discussion about the commercial terms (C/P or C&F).

Best regards,
James Parkin

---

From: david@shippingco.com
To: dalschaert@londonoffice.com
Subject: Inquiry Concerning GCM/Voyage Charterparty Terms
Timestamp: 2023-06-04 08:45
Body: Dear Mr. Dalschaert,

With reference to our recent e-mail communication, I am writing to inform you that our chartering division has raised an inquiry concerning the provisions of the GCM/Voyage charterparty as drafted by BIMCO, specifically about the CBM charge of $1.20 per CBM for a FCN charter. Our client, Shell, will not proceed with this arrangement unless the CBM charge for their LNG shipments is amended to less than $0.90 CBM. We are requesting an amendment in the wording of this provision from BIMCO.

Kind regards,
David

---

From: david@shippingco.com
To: dalschaert@londonoffice.com
Subject: Proposed Amendment to GCM/Voyage Charterparty
Timestamp: 2023-06-05 16:20
Body: Dear Mr. Dalschaert,

Following our previous communications, please find attached a proposed amendment to the GCM/Voyage Charterparty that BIMCO is considering. The amendment is as follows:

'18.30.1 Freight shall be calculated at $1.20 per CBM based on the CBM declared by the cargo'

This would be effective for cargoes delivered after January 1, 2003. Please let us know if this amendment is agreeable, and we will proceed with BIMCO.

Many thanks,
David

- Setup

1. Setup

2. Train Data


- Table: 11

| Index | company_name | last_name | email | case | product | claim_value | status |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 0 | Clean Energy Future | Armaud | ruby@ciean-energy-future.com | 1 | Oil | 5000.00 | 2 |
|
Email 3:
Dear Armaud,
Do you have your next ETA in Fujairah? Please advise with your schedule. Thank you.
Best regards,
Yang Jianbin
Sales Support
|


After reviewing this sample case, we can identify that some of the entries are in Chinese, such as  claim_value (which is 5000.00), and status (2) and email (ruby@clean-energy-future.com). Using the universal character set( UCS) and big5 characterset to decode, it turns out that the actual claim value is 50,000 RMB, and the status of the case is closed and the email contains a typo (email address should be ruby@clean-energy-future.com).


After doing an analysis of the data, we have 94,649 lines with 11 columns.

Data can be downloaded from the [official website](https://github.com/yw
Email 4:

Can you please advise with your best freight rate.
If your ship is ready for chartering kindly send us a complete charterer's party, period of notice, etc.
Warm regards,
Komal Singh
DSV Scandinavia

The following email is a new test dataset for the neural network. This email has 4 entities.

Notice how the email itself doesn't go into the input? That's where everything gets tricky. If you're using input with the type of email, then you should just do the following:

For starters, if you're using Angular 2, you'll want to import FormsModule.

Like so: import { FormsModule } from '@angular/forms';
Next, you'll need to add FormsModule to the imports array in the @NgModule declaration.

Like so: imports: [ BrowserModule, FormsModule ],

And you'll need to add [email] to the input tag.

This will give you an input that looks something like this:

At the end of the day, I found it quite trivial, and I suspect that most people would, too.

output_text:
From: developer@techcompany.com
To: support@angular.io
Subject: Difficulty with FormsModule in Angular 2
Timestamp: 2023-01-25 08:45
Body: I'm having trouble implementing the [email] type in my input fields using Angular 2. I've already imported FormsModule as per the installation guide, but I'm unsure how to correctly declare it in @NgModule and the actual input tag.

---

From: support@angular.io
To: developer@techcompany.com
Subject: Re: Difficulty with FormsModule in Angular 2
Timestamp: 2023-01-25 09:15
Body: To integrate the FormsModule into your Angular 2 application, you need to import FormsModule from '@angular/forms' first. Then, include FormsModule in the imports array within your @NgModule declaration, as such: imports: [ BrowserModule, FormsModule ]. Finally, ensure your input tag is correctly formatted, for example, <input type='email'> which sets the input’s type to email.

---

From: developer@techcompany.com
To: support@angular.io
Subject: Re: Re: Difficulty with FormsModule in Angular 2
Timestamp: 2023-01-25 10:00
Body: Thanks for the quick reply! I followed your instructions and updated the @NgModule declaration with FormsModule and confirmed the type of the input tag is correctly set to 'email'. However, I'm still experiencing issues. Is there any additional configuration that I might be missing?

---

From: support@angular.io
To: developer@techcompany.com
Subject: Re: Re: Re: Difficulty with FormsModule in Angular 2
Timestamp: 2023-01-25 10:30
Body: It sounds like you've followed all the necessary steps correctly. Make sure there are no typos and rebuild your project. If the issue persists, could you provide more details about the error message you are receiving? It will help us diagnose and solve your issue more effectively.

From: vladimir@gl.com
To: phyllis.nunes@almat.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry for Gasoil Transportation
Timestamp: 2005-05-26 08:14
Body: Dear Phyllis, It appears you are seeking quotes for the shipment of 30,000MT of gasoil from Houston to Singapore. The latest quotation for a Suezmax vessel from Houston to Singapore as of April 28, 2005, is as follows: Vessel holds up to 130,000 m3, with a deadweight tonnage at 0.8 Tpc, sulphur content of 4.2% and a maximum of 130 ppm S, viscosity not exceeding 60 ppm. input_text:
Email 1:
I was interested in your article about refelective materials in Nature.                                         You had two equations for refractive index in the article.                                         I am trying to find a proof or derivation of one of those (the one that uses lambda and n) and wanted to see if you knew of a reference for it.                                         Thank you,                                         Daniel
Email 2:
Subject: f2=1-2n

Hi!

Thank you for your message. The equation n=1-sqrt(1-f)/2 is a very general one. It can be found in most books on electromagnetism and optics. I wrote down the reference where I first came across this equation in my Nature paper. Have a look at page 3. But you can also find it in more recent books on plasmonics. For example in a book by Jain.

Daniel
Email 4:
Subject:  Re: f2=1-2n

Hi Daniel,

Your question is not directly related to this particular website, therefore I think I'll reply in an email.

The only literature I can think of are two references you probably already have found yourself:

(1)  P. Drude, Handbuch der Radiologie, Leipzig: Barth, 1922 (p. 369)

(2)  N. Jain, C. J. Kryzhanovsky, and C. H. Chen, Excitation and Detection of Surface Plasmons on Gold Films. In: T. Zimmermann, and A. Berger, eds., Coherence, Statistics, and Quantum Optics IV (Springer, 2005) 146-165

Drude's book is basically the bible on metallic materials in

You can use "This is" to introduce your message. You can say something like "This is a song my friend Kevin sings." "This is an email I sent my friend Kelly last week." You can ask a question and talk about a movie like this: "How was the movie about the cat with a magic ability? It sounds interesting." <Body>:
I appreciate your <email 1> dated [date]. We still are analyzing our options and have reached no final conclusion. The timing of our acquisition of the remaining 15% is part of that analysis. In the meantime, the rest of our business remains as before and the Board of Directors of [ABC] will continue to oversee its management.

RBC Capital Markets
_______________________
Jason McGroarty
(416) 842-6293
Email 3:
[RECEIVED AT TIME OF EMAIL]
RE: [ANOTHER EMAIL OF THE SAME SUBJECT MATTER] - REMOVAL OF ASSETS FROM CONTROLS OF ABC

Dear Ms. Flippo,

I was copied on your email yesterday to Mr. Frank and Messrs. Calloway and Vaughn. Please be advised that pursuant to Section 14.4 of the Purchase Agreement dated November 4, 2004, we have placed certain assets that are subject to the asset transfer agreement that you recently sent over to us in our depository at 15 York St., in Toronto, to await the return of those assets to ABC. These assets are detailed in a list attached to our email of December 14, 2004, (see attachment A). I assume these are the assets that are under your custody. If you have any objections to this deposit, you must advise us
Email 4:
[RECEIVED AT TIME OF EMAIL]
Dear Mr. McGroarty,
Thank you for your email. Please be advised that we have no objections to the list you provided to us. However, the list in question has not been previously reviewed by the Board of Directors of ABC and therefore we are unable to provide you with any information regarding the specific assets. It is our understanding that our list does not conform to the requirements of the Sale Agreement, particularly since the list reflects that we are permitted to retain certain files and information despite the fact that we are prohibited from using or retaining any ABC Confidential Information, as set out in the Sale Agreement. This is a concern to our Board of Directors.

Please be advised that your proposal to place certain of our assets in a depository pending return to ABC is inappropriate and contrary to the terms of the Sale Agreement. Specifically, Section 2.1(a)
Email 5:
I just spoke with Martin but I was copied on the email below. 
    Today is December 17th, 2004 and we continue to have no approved and executed sale agreement. In the meantime, ABC is purging all of our assets and information, and sending same to various unidentified third parties and law firms. 
     We simply cannot accept these proposals in light of ABC's wrongful purging of our assets. All of the discussion contained in your email is irrelevant in light of the purging. Please provide us with a confirmed list of all assets that have been sent to third parties and their names. 
<Email 6>:
Dear Mr. McGroarty,

<Body>: You must withdraw any claim that ABC has breached the purchase agreement. You are not our trading partner; you are our custodian, holding assets that belong to ABC until such time as the transaction is closed

I appreciate the discussion pertaining to our current analysis of business options and the potential acquisition of the additional 15% stake. Kind regards,
Jason McGroarty
RBC Capital Markets

To: jason.mcgroarty@rbccm.com

Body: Dear Mr. McGroarty,

I was copied on your email yesterday to Mr. Frank and Messrs. Calloway and Vaughn. Please be advised that pursuant to Section 14.4 of the Purchase Agreement dated November 4, 2004, we have placed certain assets, which are subject to the transfer agreement you recently sent over, in our depository at 15 York St., Toronto. These assets are listed in our attachment from the email dated December 14, 2004. Should you have any objections to this storage, please inform us accordingly.

---

From: jason.mcgroarty@rbccm.com
To: ms.flippo@abc.com
Subject: Re: Analysis of Acquisition Plans and Current Business Operations - REMOVAL OF ASSETS FROM CONTROLS OF ABC
Timestamp: 2004-12-17 10:30
Body: Dear Ms. Flippo,

Thank you for your prompt response. We acknowledge no objections to the listed assets. However, it has come to our attention that this list has not yet been reviewed by ABC's Board of Directors. It appears some files and information retained may not comply with the Sale Agreement's stipulations. Further, your proposal to place these assets in a depository pending their return raises concerns about the adherence to the Sale Agreement, specifically Section 2.1(a).

Please clarify these points at your earliest convenience.

---

From: ms.flippo@abc.com
To: jason.mcgroarty@rbccm.com
Subject: Urgent: Breach of Sale Agreement and Asset Mismanagement

Following our earlier correspondence and a discussion today with Martin, I need to express serious concerns. As of today, December 17, 2004, ABC is unlawfully distributing assets and information to various third parties and law firms without an approved and executed sale agreement. This approach cannot be accepted. Please provide a detailed list of all assets and the names of third parties involved immediately.

Subject: Final Notice: Asset Handling and Compliance with Purchase Agreement
Timestamp: 2004-12-17 17:30
Body: Dear Ms. Flippo,

In light of your concerns, it is imperative to clarify that RBC Capital Markets is acting solely as a custodian, not a trading partner, holding ABC's assets until the transaction concludes. Any claim that ABC has breached the purchase agreement is unwarranted. I urge ABC to cease transferring assets and to rectify any actions contrary to our agreement.

Best regards,
Jason McGroarty

Email 2:
Hi Sally,                Yes, we've seen significant delays and cancellations due to the industrial action.                Kind regards,                Joseph

<Email 3>:
Hi Joseph,                  Do you have any idea how long these delays will continue for?  Just wondering if it's worth waiting and seeing what happens or if we should already be looking at alternative routings.                  Best regards,                  Sally

<Email 4>:
Hi Sally,                With the strikes still continuing, it's difficult to say for sure when cargo movements will return to normal. However, it's worth considering alternative routings, as delays and cancellations are likely to persist in the short term.                Kind regards,                Joseph

input_text:
Email 1:
Good morning Mr. Gonzales,                    Our team has been reviewing the contract for freight containers between Rotterdam and Naples for some weeks now.                    Do you have any further business questions or suggestions to our market analysis?                    Regards,                    Christa
Email 2:
Morning Christa,                    If I remember correctly, that contract included only containers shipped by steam ship, but I now know that steam ships have been replaced by modern container ships.                    I'd like to amend that contract for all types of modern container ships, with an expiration date.                    Regards,                    Hugo

<Email 3>:
Hi Hugo,                    I've found some documentation from the 1970s that state there was still a fair amount of containers transported by steam ship, despite being a less economical way to transport containers.                    What do you think?                    Regards,                    Christa

<Email 4>:
Hi Christa,                    That is no doubt true. Steam ships are extremely dangerous for the containers, even the newest containers. The vibrations produced by the steam engines, and the leaks from the boilers, damage most of the containers in transit.                    That is why we
output_text:
From: christa@email.com
To: hgonzales@email.com
Subject: Reviewing Freight Contract: Rotterdam to Naples
Timestamp: 2023-09-01 08:30
Body: Good morning Mr. Gonzales,

Our team has been reviewing the contract for freight containers shipped between Rotterdam and Naples for some weeks now. Could you please share any further business questions or suggestions related to our market analysis?

Regards,
Christa

---

From: hgonzales@email.com
To: christa@email.com
Subject: Re: Reviewing Freight Contract: Rotterdam to Naples
Timestamp: 2023-09-01 09:15
Body: Morning Christa,

If I recall correctly, the original contract specified only containers shipped by steam ship. However, considering steam ships have largely been replaced by modern container ships, I'd like to amend the contract to include all types of modern container ships, and address an expiration date for this change.

Regards,
Hugo

---

From: christa@email.com
To: hgonzales@email.com
Subject: Re: Reviewing Freight Contract: Rotterdam to Naples
Timestamp: 2023-09-02 10:20
Body: Hi Hugo,

Indeed, this is a valid concern. I've reviewed some historical documentation from the 1970s that states steam ships were still a common mode of container transport, despite their inefficiencies and higher operation costs. It's an important aspect to consider.

What do you think? 

Regards,
Christa

---

From: hgonzales@email.com
To: christa@email.com
Subject: Re: Reviewing Freight Contract: Rotterdam to Naples
Timestamp: 2023-09-02 11:00
Body: Hi Christa,

That observation is accurate. The operation of steam ships, especially the vibrations from steam engines and potential leaks from the boilers, presents a high risk of damage to most containers in transit. This underlines the necessity of transitioning to modern container ships for better safety and efficiency.

Best,
Hugo

Email 2:
Dear Mr. A,                         It is understood that you have an ethylene export vessel currently positioned on the US Gulf Coast and that you are seeking a charter. We understand that your current vessel may need to bunker bunkers in Houston or be repositioned to Houston. The below details are for a voyage from Houston, USGulf Coast to Antwerp, Belgium. It is understood that this cargo will be discharged within 21 days and loading of this cargo is to be completed within 24 hours of the vessels arrival in Houston. The vessel will be available to be loaded up to April 25. 
            Our ethylene specialists will require the following documents to begin your voyage quotation.
- Bunker delivery Note
- Documentation allowing for 2 bunkers at Houston
-  Vessel details for identification
-  Recent drydock certificate
- Current SGS dry cargo logbook
-
output_text:
From: mariam@exportcompany.com
To: edmonds@shippingcompany.com
Subject: Inquiry for Ethylene Shipment from Houston to Antwerp
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 09:15
Body: Dear Mr. Edmonds,

We plan to send 8,600MT of ethylene from Houston to Antwerp. Could you please provide a quotation for this shipment? We would also like to know if there is flexibility in your vessels' scheduling. Thank you for your assistance.

Best regards,
Mariam

---

From: edmonds@shippingcompany.com
To: mariam@exportcompany.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry for Ethylene Shipment from Houston to Antwerp
Timestamp: 2023-03-02 10:30
Body: Dear Ms. Mariam,

Thank you for your inquiry. Your plan to export ethylene via a charter from the US Gulf Coast to Antwerp has been noted. The vessel can be positioned in Houston and will be available for loading until April 25. Loading must be completed within 24 hours of the vessel's arrival and the discharge in Antwerp is expected within 21 days. 

To proceed with the voyage quotation, please provide the following documents:
- Bunker Delivery Note
- Authorization for two bunkers at Houston
- Vessel identification details
- Recent drydock certificate
- Current SGS dry cargo logbook

Looking forward to your prompt response.

Best regards,
Mr. Edmonds

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello,                    We are shipping 200CTNs of T-shirts from Shanghai to Paris. Do you have space this month and how soon can we get a price?                    Regards,                    Jean
Email 2:
Hi Jean,
Thank you for your email. I would like to ask you some information regarding your shipment of t-shirts:
1) What is the mark or brand of the t-shirts?
2) What type of t-shirt is it? Tank, tube, long sleeve, short sleeve?
3) Is the t-shirt knitted or woven?  And what kind of knit or weave?
4) Does it have any decoration on it? What type of decoration?
5) What type of fabric is it?  What is the denier, threads, and fiber count?
6) What is the weight of a t-shirt?
7) Do you want us to pay for the cost of freight, or do you want us to put it on your invoice?
8) How many items in one package?
If you have any questions, please feel free to ask.
Best regards,
Yue
output_text:

Subject: Enquiry about Shipping Capacity and Pricing for T-shirts

---

From: yue@shippingltd.cn
To: jean@parisfashion.co
Subject: Re: Enquiry about Shipping Capacity and Pricing for T-shirts
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 13:30
Body: Hi Jean, Thank you for reaching out. Before I can provide a detailed quote, could you please provide some additional information regarding the T-shirts? Specifically: 1) Brand/Mark of the T-shirts? 2) Type (Tank, Tube, Long Sleeve, Short Sleeve)? 3) Fabric (Knitted or Woven) and the type of knit or weave? 4) Any special decorations? Type of decorations? 5) Fabric specifics such as denier, threads, and fiber count? 6) Weight per T-shirt? 7) Payment preference for freight costs – do you want it on your invoice or will we handle it? 8) Number of items per package? Feel free to reach out with any questions. Best regards, Yue

Email 1:
Dear Mr. Walters,                    We have cargo for 12,000MT of urea from Pengerang to Las Palmas in September.                   BAF should be around $120/mt (based on old fix as BAF has changed dramatically), however if a GdW is used please be aware the vessel will likely be late when BAF is calculated. 
About this post:                   It’s useful to think about what someone needs to know (what information they need) and how you can present it to them (the style you can use).                    This helps you to produce emails that are both concise and comprehensive.                    It helps you to be consistent in your writing, and the person receiving your email will feel reassured by the consistency of style (if you can remember to use it!)                    And, if you use the same style for several emails to the same person, it
Email 2:
Dear Mrs. Walters, 
               We are still in contact with our vendors in Nanded and are anticipating a price at the end of next week for up to 20,000MT of various types of urea. As the quantities can change daily, we would like you to provide the last two digits of your credit card number. 
               I will call you later today to discuss this and to arrange for a flight to Mumbai. As you know, we need to be flexible on the types of urea and quantities, but please feel free to send a list of your requirements. We are anticipating that we may receive it in three or four shipments, so that may be something to consider. Please also provide us with a list of the vessels that you have available. 
               We are looking forward to seeing you. 
               Hope this helps, thanks, Jane 
About this post:
output_text:
From: jane@example.com
To: mr.walters@example.com
Subject: Cargo Shipment Proposal: Pengerang to Las Palmas
Timestamp: 2023-09-01 10:30
Body: Dear Mr. Walters,

We have a cargo of 12,000MT of urea that needs shipping from Pengerang to Las Palmas in September. Historically, the Bunker Adjustment Factor (BAF) was around $120/MT, but due to recent changes, we expect variances. Please be advised that if a vessel with high Gross DeadWeight (GdW) is used, it will likely impact the schedule and might cause delays.

Please let us know your preferences or any other specifics you need. Looking forward to your prompt response.

Best Regards,
Jane

---

From: jane@example.com
To: mrs.walters@example.com
Subject: Continued Discussion on Urea Purchase and Shipping Requirements
Timestamp: 2023-09-02 15:45
Body: Dear Mrs. Walters,

We are still coordinating with our vendors in Nanded and expect to finalize pricing for up to 20,000MT of various types of urea by the end of next week. As market conditions are volatile, the quantities may fluctuate daily. We request you to share the last two digits of your credit card for verification purposes. Additionally, I will contact you later today to discuss potential travel arrangements to Mumbai and further details of the urea types and quantities required.

We anticipate organizing the shipment in three or four batches. Please share a list of available vessels and any specific requirements you might have.

Looking forward to our meeting.

Best Regards,
Jane

When the following vessel calls in Gdynia for loading, can it come back to Liverpool and unload the same day?                    Regards,                    Noa                    Choose between any two of the three email styles when writing your email to tell us how you will use the template. If you have a preferred style then mention it, or say you’re indifferent.
Pilot services from Sulzheim and Ettlingen are mandatory for tankers. On all other tank terminals in the Rhine region, pilot services are mandatory for vessels over a certain draft. Pilot services are mandatory for tankers and those vessels that do not have a ship’s master certified for the canal.
The minimum towage rates of the EUROTUG pilots are for short draft vessels. EUROTUG reserves the right to calculate the pilotage fees differently. Should you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to contact the Pilots
Email 2:
When the following vessel calls in Gdynia for loading, can it come back to Liverpool and unload the same day?                    Regards,                    Noa                    Choose between any two of the three email styles when writing your email to tell us how you will use the template. If you have a preferred style then mention it, or say you’re indifferent.
Pilot services from Sulzheim and Ettlingen are mandatory for tankers. On all other tank terminals in the Rhine region, pilot services are mandatory for vessels over a certain draft. Pilot services are mandatory for tankers and those vessels that do not have a ship’s master certified for the canal.
The minimum towage rates of the EUROTUG pilots are for short draft vessels. EUROTUG reserves the right to calculate the pilotage fees differently. Should you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to contact the Pilots
output_text:
From: noa@example.com
To: operations@example.com
Subject: Inquiry about Vessel Operations between Gdynia and Liverpool
Timestamp: 2023-10-03 09:30
Body: Dear Operations Team,

I would like to inquire if the vessel scheduled for loading in Gdynia can return to Liverpool and unload on the same day.
Please advise if this is feasible considering the operational hours and transit times.

Additionally, I would like to be informed about the mandatory pilot and towage services as required for tankers in Sulzheim and Ettlingen, and other terminals in the Rhine region. Could you also clarify if the pilotage fees by EUROTUG are different for vessels with shorter draft?

Looking forward to your guidance.

Best regards,
Noa

---

From: operations@example.com
To: noa@example.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry about Vessel Operations between Gdynia and Liverpool
Timestamp: 2023-10-03 10:45
Body: Hello Noa,

Thank you for reaching out with your questions.

Regarding your query about the vessel's operations from Gdynia to Liverpool, it is generally not feasible for a vessel to complete both loading in Gdynia and unloading in Liverpool on the same day due to the transit time required. Please let us know if there are specific dates or arrangements you are considering.

As for the pilot services, it is correct that pilots are mandatory for tankers in Sulzheim and Ettlingen. Additionally, in all Rhine region terminals, pilot services are required for vessels over a certain draft or without a canal-certified ship's master. Regarding the EUROTUG pilotage fees, they vary based on the draft length of the vessel. We suggest contacting EUROTUG directly for the most accurate fee estimate.

Please do not hesitate to get back to us with any further queries or specific vessel details.

Best regards,
Operations Team

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Mrs. Michelotti,                    I’m inquiring about a shipment of 10,000MT of latex for export to Valencia. Your 2013 vessel performance seems strong, and I’d like to see if we can get your ship again.                    Sincerely,                    Gianfranco
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Gianfranco,                    The staff has been working hard to find out if we can get you the vessel for the required time. We can have the ship at Valencia on August 12, but this will force us to delay your departure time to August 18. Let us know if this is acceptable, and then we can close the deal.                    Warmly,                    Nicoletta

Since then, Nicolas has been waiting for an answer. When should he send a follow-up email?

## What the Social Norms Suggest

I asked 100 people the following question: Is it acceptable to wait for more than 10 days after an email is sent and not hear back? 35% of people said yes, 65% said no. So, what should he do?

## What the Stats Show

The text analysis service I use, Linguamatics, returned
Email 3:
At a first glance the email looks like the perfect email to send for this scenario; however, this is not the case as it is not very friendly. This could lead to someone feeling undermined, which could lead to the email recipient ignoring this email in hopes of less negativity from the sender. Which is the opposite of what we want. If we were to send this email to a sales person in hopes of securing the sale we would be sabotaging our chances of getting the sale because the person we are sending this to, may feel undermined and will respond less happily than if we had sent the second email. As well as providing a better response, the second email provides all of the information needed to complete the transaction and then asks for the decision. This shows professionalism and a desire to complete the transaction on both ends. In both cases the email offers the promise of a future reply, this may be the
Email 4:
I have been wondering when I will hear back about the shipment of latex for Valencia. August 12 is the deadline, so we need to make a decision soon. Please let me know if the August 18 date for departure is acceptable, and then we can close the deal.                    Warmly,                    Nicolas
@source_envisage: How long would you wait to get a response to an email?

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Ms. Patel,                    I need to send 1,000MT of maize from Poti to Zelenodolsk before the end of this week. What is your earliest loading date? And what kind of dispatch incentives do you offer?                    Best regards,                    Rudolf
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Tofts,                I can offer you the cheapest shipping options from Poti to Zelenodolsk: the transit time is only 5 days. Please check our webpage: https://baltshipping.net/en/shipping-port-poti/                    I will be very glad to see you soon in Poti!                    Best regards,                    Rudolf

The first email describes a negotiation for the sale of a commodity (in this case, maize). This kind of email, which we refer to as a negotiation email, is an important genre for a business that engages in negotiation with potential buyers and sellers. 

You can use such a negotiation email as an inspiration for your own, when you negotiate with a partner company. In the following paragraphs, I will discuss the parts of the above example email, showing you how they were composed, why they are important, and what the pros and
Email 3:
Dear Ms. Bellichi,                Please take a look at our offers and choose a suitable one. The earlier you confirm, the better discount we can offer. Thanks for your attention.                    Best regards,                    Antanina

This is the reply to an inquiry email, i.e. an email that responds to a potential customer's inquiry about the products and services offered by a company. It contains all the information the recipient needs and provides enough context for her to make a decision, including the pricing and the delivery terms.
Email 4:
Dear Ms. Samsya,                     We will send you a quote shortly. Have a nice day.                    Best regards,                    Ido

Hello!
Thank you for your request!
Your quote will be with you very soon.
Have a nice day.
Yours,
The Fones team

This is the end of the email, which is as important as its beginning. If the body of an email ends with a formality, it feels nice and appropriate to the recipient. However, if the ending part of the email contains information that does not pertain to the topic of the email, it may be confusing.
Email 5:
Hello!
Thank you for your request!
Your quote will be with you very soon.
Have a nice day.
Yours,
The Fones team

From: liam@shippingco.com
To: george@example.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry for Petcoke Transport from Kandla to Mathura
Timestamp: 2023-07-05 11:45
Body: Hi George,

We only have one vessel in the Gulf that could arrive in Mumbai within your timeframes. It will be in Lasbela (Mub) on 11th July and can be ready to load on the 13th or 14th July. Liam

Please let me know if you are still interested and I will check if there are other vessels that could load at Mumbai.

Best Regards,
Liam

Email 1:
Hi Mr. Pal,                    Could you please advise if we can deliver your import under EXW terms?                   If so, could you provide a copy of the bill of lading as soon as it is available, and make sure you've sent a pre-arrival notification of the cargo and owner's details, so that we can facilitate berth preparations and other documentation.                   Looking forward to hearing from you,                   Yi-shen
Email 2:
Hi Yi-shen,                           We can deliver your import cargo under EXW terms, in fact, our suppliers can sell our product under CIF terms, but our cargo are already loaded, and I think our transportation cost under CIF may be higher than ex-works.                           I would like to ask you if we can provide you with a copy of B/L before arrival, could you advise on whether this will be a problem for you.                           As for other documentation, we are not sure how to fill it in, because we only supply high technology component, and your export will be the final user.                           Many thanks for your kind assistance.                           Regards,                           Terry

<Email 3>:
Hi Terry,                         We do require a copy of the bill of lading to be sent to us before arrival.                           As for the final user, we don't mind, but we will need the
Email 3:
Hi Terry,                         We do require a copy of the bill of lading to be sent to us before arrival.                           As for the final user, we don't mind, but we will need the

<Email 3>:
 (Continued)                                       information on the final user on the bill of lading, and we would like to know the manufacturer of the products as well, which I will need you to provide us with.                          Regards,                          Yi-shen
Email 4:
(Continued)                          Hi Yi-shen,                          Thanks for your reply.                          We are very sorry, but I am afraid we are unable to provide you with the final user, because the purchase of our product is for internal use only.                          As for the name of the manufacturer, we are afraid that we are not allowed to disclose such information.                          We are very sorry that we cannot help you.                          Best Regards,                          Terry

We are very sorry, but I am afraid we are unable to provide you with the final user, because the purchase of our product is for internal use only. output_text:
From: yi-shen@example.com
To: terry.pal@example.com
Subject: Request for Bill of Lading and PRE-Arrival Notification Details
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 09:15
Body: Hi Mr. Pal,

Could you please confirm if we can proceed with the EXW delivery terms for your import? If possible, kindly provide a copy of the bill of lading as soon as available. Please ensure you have also sent a pre-arrival notification including the cargo and the owner's details, to help us prepare the berth and manage the required documentation efficiently.

Looking forward to your prompt response,
Yi-shen

---

From: terry.pal@example.com
To: yi-shen@example.com
Subject: Re: Request for Bill of Lading and PRE-Arrival Notification Details
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 11:30
Body: Hi Yi-shen,

Thank you for your email. We can indeed deliver the import cargo under EXW terms, though our suppliers can also handle CIF terms. However, since our cargo is already loaded and considering the potential increase in transportation costs under CIF, we prefer EXW for this shipment.

Regarding the bill of lading, could you specify whether providing a copy before the cargo's arrival poses any issues? Additionally, as we are supplying high-technology components and your export will be the final user, we are unsure about how to complete the other documentation.

Thanks for your assistance,
Terry

---

From: yi-shen@example.com
To: terry.pal@example.com
Subject: Re: Request for Bill of Lading and PRE-Arrival Notification Details
Timestamp: 2023-03-02 08:45
Body: Hi Terry,

We do require the bill of lading to be sent to us before the cargo's arrival. It is essential to include information regarding the final user and the manufacturer of the products on the bill of lading. Please provide this information at your earliest convenience.

Regards,
Yi-shen

---

From: terry.pal@example.com
To: yi-shen@example.com
Subject: Re: Request for Bill of Lading and PRE-Arrival Notification Details
Timestamp: 2023-03-02 10:20
Body: Hi Yi-shen,

Thank you for your reply. Unfortunately, we are unable to disclose the details of the final user, as the purchase of our product is for internal use only. Additionally, we are not permitted to reveal the manufacturer's name.

We regret any inconvenience this may cause.

Best Regards,
Terry

<SEND EMAIL C> ``` Import a Shipping Email dataset  Select  EMAILS in the  Model   section in the menu bar.  If you haven't done so yet, save your file by selecting the first tab in the bottom section of the view menu. After that, click on the plus button and select Import Dataset .  Finally, you will be directed to choose a file. This is a good point to download the dataset from the FISAI_22 assignment page and select the file Shipping Emails.xlsx .   When the upload is finished, you can check your data. Each shipping email will be represented by two different elements: ```   (Value, Time of writing, Sender, Recipient, Port of Departure, Port of Arrival)   <Value> <Time of writing> Mr/Ms <Sender> [Hamburg] Hi <Recipient>,              <Message>

From: support@fisai.com
To: user@example.com
Subject: Instruction to Import Shipping Email Dataset
Timestamp: 2023-02-01 08:00
Body: To import a Shipping Email dataset, please select EMAILS in the Model section on the menu bar. If you have not saved your file yet, begin by selecting the first tab in the bottom section of the view menu. Then, click on the plus button and select 'Import Dataset'. You will then be directed to choose a file. At this point, a good action is to download the dataset from the FISAI_22 assignment page and select the file named Shipping Emails.xlsx. Once the upload is completed, you can check your data. Each shipping email in the dataset will be represented by two different elements:\n(Value, Time of writing, Sender, Recipient, Port of Departure, Port of Arrival)\n(Value) (Time of writing) Mr/Ms (Sender) [Hamburg] Hi (Recipient), (Message)

If the next trip is too late, please consider the Tuna/Excelsior/Metal which are not ideal but are at least 3/4 capacity as we have yet to book Africa with Metocean.                    Regards,                    Tim
                    
This email was handed to me on my second day working in the Middle East. It was by far the biggest amount of confusion and annoyance that I had to deal with. I was originally meant to receive the request and push the execution to the Trade desk. However, I thought this was a time sensitive request and without any knowledge of weather and Middle Eastern conditions, I decided to respond via email. This was my first mistake.
            Considering that the deadline was mid-April, 6 weeks away

Email 1:
Hello Ben,                    We’re looking to ship 20,000MT of steel from Paldock to Monrovia. Could you send us your fcl rate and ETA? Also, is it possible to do a post-dated bill of lading?                    Thanks,                    Grace
Email 2:
Hi Grace,                    Attached you will find our quotations for Paldock to Monrovia for your steel cargo.                    We will send your cargo within three days of receipt of your irrevocable letter of credit in our account in London.                    Could you confirm that the steel can be shipped in containers? If not, do you have other requirements (such as barge?); and do you have any requirements for the steel?                    We can carry the bill of lading either to bearer or to the order of your bank, as you require.                    If you would like us to carry the bill of lading to bearer, please let us know when to expect the irrevocable letter of credit in our London account.                    You will find our payment terms at the bottom of the quotations.                    Please confirm your requirements and send us a draft irrevocable letter of credit to enable
Email 3:
Thank you very much.                    The cargo will be shipped in 20 foot containers, with 400 pieces per container. The cargo will be steel bars.                    Please deliver the bill of lading to bearer.                    I have forwarded the irrevocable letter of credit.                    Best regards,                    Grace
Email 4:
Hello,                    We have received your request.                    We will charge you USD 700 per 20 foot container.                    We will deliver the bill of lading as follows:                    We will issue the bill of lading to bearer.                    We will send the bill of lading and the other shipping documents to you within five days of the date that we receive the irrevocable letter of credit in our account in London.                    Best regards,                    Ben

Grace

---

To: grace@example.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry for Shipping Steel from Paldock to Monrovia
Timestamp: 2023-02-01 13:15
Body: Hi Grace,

Attached you will find our quotations for shipping from Paldock to Monrovia for your steel cargo. We can meet the provided cargo requirements and the FCL rate is outlined in the attached document. Estimated time of arrival (ETA) is within 20 days from the date of departure.

Please confirm if the steel can be shipped in 20-foot containers. Additionally, we can issue the bill of lading either to bearer or to the order of your bank, as you require. Please advise on which option you prefer and when to expect the irrevocable letter of credit in our London account.

Told the man the date and he said "you can do better with a stop over in Honolulu on the return" 

but he never sent me any new price? 

RMA


@RichardMillington - Here's what you got as a reply to an inquiry from a California attorney. He included the $1,000 retainer... and apparently never had the retainer sent or received a confirmation. 18 years of training lawyers not to charge for consults isn't being applied. @lawyer.twitter.com <1> @lawyer.twitter.com <2>
__________________________________________________
Email 4:

A new retainer agreement will need to be signed by both parties and sent to our office within two days from today with the $1,000 retainer fee. If it is not returned within two days I will assume you are no longer interested in representation.
Ok to proceed? If you have any questions regarding my fees, please let me know.

@lawyer.twitter.com - Thank you for your reply. I will start working on a list of questions for you, which may take me another day to prepare. Once I'm ready to move forward I'll send you an email.  Please let me know if this sounds ok.

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello X,                    We want to charter a vessel to transport 2k MT of petroleum coke from Baku to Qingdao, China. Do you have any ship open in November?                    Regards,                    [name]
Email 2:
Hello,                    Best Price on spot by sea transport:                0,19 $/MT + 0,05$/MT bunker.                Subject: bunker..................  1/5 charter party done on GLS 2/5 cargo -petroleum coke - 20k MT 3/5 B/L paid - 100 % 4/5 sailing November 5/5 From - Baku, Azerbaijan to - Qingdao, China                Best Regards, [name]

What is the task?                    The task is to find an empty container, go to China (pay 0.19$/MT + 0.05$/MT bunker) and bring petroleum coke to Azerbaijan (20k MT, 100% B/L paid, sailing in November).

The main question for this task is, does the company have a vessel available to take the cargo?

What technique(s)
Email 3:
The main trick is to make this task look like it is for open charter. This makes the victim pay attention to the price, believing it is actually lower than the price of the chartered ship (by the way, let's make it 0.19$). By saying that you will pay 0.05$/MT for bunker, the victim thinks you are buying bunker, while you are actually renting the vessel.

    Also note that the shipping cost (0.19$) is given to the nearest part of the fourth decimal place, which might look suspicious if the sender and receiver have different countries. It is a very good trick to make such mistakes, as I did in email 2, or even in email 1 if the victim is inexperienced. It makes the victim think he is comparing two similar offers, which they are not, and look bad for not noticing it. Finally

Michael

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Sir/Madam,                    We’d like to transport 2,900MT of cotton to Ghent from Huangpu. Could you let us know your best available rate, and do you work on a FCA basis?                    Thank you for your time,                    Henry
Email 2:
Dear Henry,                        Thanks for your mail. And I will try my best to find out the info from our cargo department. Best regards,                        Clark Chen
Email 3:
Dear Clark Chen,                     I am glad to hear from you. You could try any carrier please. If they have empty sailings, they would be happy to carry our goods, for our cargo is different from other goods, we transport it through containers instead of using trucks, so our goods are more sensitive.                     Let me know if you have questions or suggestions.                     Thank you!                     Henry
<Email 4>:
Dear Clark Chen,                     Thanks for your reply. Could you tell me which is the best choice? Our cargo usually transports at least 100,000 tons at a time. Is it better to transport by the whole container or shipper’s owned container?                     Please let me know if you have questions or suggestions.                     Thanks for your time!                     Henry
<Email 5>:
Dear Henry,                        Thanks for your mail. Sorry for my delay.                        By
output_text:
From: henry@exportcompany.com
To: clark.chen@shippingagency.com
Subject: Freight Quote Inquiry for Cotton Transport
Timestamp: 2023-01-10 09:15
Body: Dear Sir/Madam, I am seeking to transport 2,900MT of cotton from Huangpu to Ghent. Could you please provide your best available rate? Furthermore, do you offer services on a Free Carrier Agreement (FCA) basis? Thank you for your time, Henry.

---

From: clark.chen@shippingagency.com
To: henry@exportcompany.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Inquiry for Cotton Transport
Timestamp: 2023-01-11 10:35
Body: Dear Henry, Thank you for your email. I will consult our cargo department to obtain the necessary information and revert shortly. Best regards, Clark Chen.

---

From: henry@exportcompany.com
To: clark.chen@shippingagency.com
Subject: Additional Information on Cargo Handling
Timestamp: 2023-01-12 08:50
Body: Dear Clark Chen, Thank you for your swift response. Just to clarify, we typically transport our cotton in containers rather than using conventional trucking methods, due to the sensitive nature of the goods. Please feel free to consider any carrier that may have available space. Let me know if you have any questions or need further details. Regards, Henry.

---

From: henry@exportcompany.com
To: clark.chen@shippingagency.com
Subject: Clarification on Container Usage
Timestamp: 2023-01-13 14:25
Body: Dear Clark Chen, Thanks for your continuous assistance. Could you advise whether it is more optimal for us to ship using full containers or shipper’s owned containers, especially considering the volume (at least 100,000 tons annually)? I appreciate your guidance. Sincerely, Henry.

---

From: clark.chen@shippingagency.com
To: henry@exportcompany.com
Subject: Re: Clarification on Container Usage
Timestamp: 2023-01-14 16:10
Body: Dear Henry, Thank you for following up. Apologies for the delayed response. I will gather the specifics concerning container options and revert as soon as possible. Best regards, Clark.

Hi,                    We would like to ship some rice from Vietnam to Mombasa, about 30,000MT, ASAP. The destination's preferred method is for a lump sum delivery price.                    Best regards,                    Tina
Email 2:
Thanks for your quote. Some further information:                    The rice would be shipped over a number of months but we would like the price to be fixed for all of the months.                    Also, the port at the destination is likely to change, so we would need the FOB price to be from either Ho Chi Minh City, Da Nang or Cai Mep ports (but not Vung Tau port).                    The dates are subject to change but we would probably want to start loading in September and the rice will be delivered over a number of months.                    Best regards,                    Tina

This communication is purely fictional but the type of communication between a prospective buyer and seller can easily be observed. Hi Tracy,                    Thanks for the Purchase Order. We will need a pre-booking of USD 15,000, refundable once we have executed the contract and to cover our expenses and your insurance. Your estimated delivery is March 14, 2017. We would be pleased if we can quote you our normal FOB laycan, demurrage and dispatch.                    Kind regards,                    Miguel

Hi Miguel,                    We have sent you a purchase order and we expect you to send us a draft.                    Thanks,                    Tracy

Your invoice, including the commission of USD 15,000, will be sent to our bank today. Please note that we have been quoted an insurance of USD 500 by XYZ Insurance Company. Could you inform us whether you are using XYZ Insurance Company? We are informed that they are a reputable company but that they are paying out large claims in many cases.                    Thanks,                    Tracy

                    So in today’s game, no one knows the rules and, in the middle of the game, the rules change and everyone is confused and, as a result, everyone plays like idiots and loses. Therefore, when someone comes into a port, they don’t know if the price for that port is set or floating, and there isn’t anyone on the other side of the table

Email 1:
Morning Mr. Smith,                    I need 1500 m3 of crude oil from New York to London by August 1st. Also, what would your demurrage rate be if we’re 15 minutes late?                    Regards,                    James
Email 2:
Hello Mr. Smith,
         I’m working for American Fuel Corporation from New York and I need to receive 250 m3 of crude oil from you on July 25th.
         In addition, what would your demurrage rate be if we’re one hour late? Thanks.
         Regards,
         Lisa
         ----------------------------
         Day 8
         Hi, Lisa,
         Thanks for your email. Please fill in the following blanks and then return to me.
         What is your port name?
         _________________________
         How many m3 of crude oil will you send? 250 m3
         _________________________
         Where is your loading date? July 25th
         _________________________
         What is your discharge port? London
         _________________________
         If the ship is one hour late, how much do you have to pay?
         ______________________
Email 3:
I would like to know that the distance between New York and London by water is around 4550 miles. From your blanks, you will need about 64 hours to reach London if the ship moves 100 miles per day. In this case, we can conclude that if the ship arrives in 65 hours, it will be one hour late.
Regards,
Mark
[Note: It took one day for Mark to give the answer, which took his client only 10 minutes.]

As requested, I am including a snapshot of our web portal as it appears today. It contains information about the markets in which Karen trades, and the freight rates for each trade. The portal also shows how certain factors, such as market volatility, can affect rates. Each sector displays a current snapshot of freight rates for each of the areas that Karen can trade, and a visual map indicating rate fluctuations. Also, freight rates appear in a moving graph which shows trends over the last 30 days. This is quite beneficial for traders who have to make decisions based on live market conditions. 

Another important function is the ship and route selector. When a ship trader selects a specific ship, the system shows in green or red the rates and savings for that specific ship on each route. This helps traders determine which ship and which route to select.

To: operations@shippingcompany.com
Subject: RE: Request for Demurrage Rate
Timestamp: 2015-02-23 08:15
Body: Good morning, Thank you for your inquiry dated 19th February 2015 regarding demurrage rates for our vessels at Bandar Abbas. For clarification, the information you requested was for Bandar Mahshahr. Details as follows: Date of Arrival: 08/02/2015; Position of Vessel: Offshore of Bandar Mahshahr, waiting for tug; Type of Vessel: 105,000 DWT, Crude Oil Tanker; Draft of Vessel: 15.50 meters. Please note that our rates apply when a vessel is delayed while awaiting services such as tugboats. Regards.

---

From: operations@shippingcompany.com
To: support@portauthority.org
Subject: RE: Request for Demurrage Rate
Timestamp: 2015-03-01 10:05
Body: Thank you for your response. With reference to your email dated 23/02/2015, I would like to add that we are concerned about potential delays and the quality of service. As per the Authority of Iran Ministry of Maritime & Ports letter No X dated 23/02/2015, local service providers such as KOTTE are responsible for maintaining service quality as per international standards, especially for handling vessels like ours with a draft of 15.50 meters and 105,000 DWT. Best regards.

---

From: support@portauthority.org
To: operations@shippingcompany.com
Subject: RE: Request for Demurrage Rate
Timestamp: 2015-03-03 14:20
Body: We acknowledge your concerns outlined in your email and the referenced letter from the Ministry of Maritime & Ports. Rest assured, KOTTE is responsible for upholding contract obligations for navigational services and the standards thereof. This includes handling of vessels up to 120,000 MT+ deadweight. Thank you for bringing this to our attention. Best regards.

Email 1:

The freight rate? Maybe $10.5, definitely not$11.

<Email 3>:
Email 1:
Nick,

That's good news. 15,000MT of EVA resin from India to Taiwan. It sounds much better.

But we have a problem: I just learned that the customer in Turkey and the customer in Taiwan are the same. It's just a customer's secondary office. I don't think they will need that much EVA resin in both places at the same time. If it's like 15,000MT, I'm afraid they will cancel the order.

Email 1:
Good morning Mr. Sardesai,                    We’re hoping to find a vessel to carry 2,000MT of ethylene dichloride from Karasburg to Salalah. Do you think that you can accommodate us on such a tight deadline, or should we look elsewhere?                    Yours truly,                    Karen
Email 2:
Good morning Ms. Klein,                    You made a valid point when you said that ships are very expensive to operate.  So, if we were to provide the food, would that drop the price?                    Your obedient servant,                    Karen
The letter writer is trying to establish the availability of a service from a potential supplier. To do so, she needs to ask questions.
If you choose the service, the supplier may not think that you are interested in the product.  That is why Ms. Klein tells you that ships are expensive to operate and, thus, puts you in a more interested position.  On the other hand, you may not think that the service is suitable for your product.  This is why Ms. Klein suggests that you could provide the food.  In this case, the product is the food.  The product is the basis for the discussion.
Either Ms. Klein
Email 3:
Dear Ms. Smith,
At the moment, our vessel is not ready for transport, and we’re afraid that it won’t be until the 10th of next month.  Of course, that will depend on how quickly repairs can be carried out.  Our most recent repairs were completed on the 1st of March.  Ms. Klein, my supervisor, says that we may be able to reschedule for the 12th of next month, but that you must let us know by the 7th of next month.
Yours truly, 
   Krishna

From: al@freightshippingco.com
To: zara@importscorp.com
Subject: Quote for Bulk Corn Starch Shipment
Timestamp: 2023-01-10 09:30
Body: Dear Zara,

Glad to provide you with a quote for your bulk corn starch shipment from Bangkok to Haiphong.

Seafreight CFR Haiphong: $1081.25 /MT
Demurrage rate: $150.00 / day

Can you let me know your exact size, quality, Expected Time of Arrival (ETA), and type of packaging?

Looking forward to working with you,
Al

---

From: zara@importscorp.com
To: al@freightshippingco.com
Subject: Advance Payment and Shipment Details
Timestamp: 2023-01-12 14:15
Body: Dear Al,

Please provide your bank details so that I can transfer $15,000 as an advance payment. This amount resonates with my desire to honor my late mother's philanthropic legacy by ensuring our business commitments are met promptly.

Thank you,
Zara

---

From: al@freightshippingco.com
To: zara@importscorp.com
Subject: Acknowledgment of Advance Payment
Timestamp: 2023-01-13 08:50
Body: Dear Zara,

What a thoughtful gesture! I appreciate your desire to continue your mother's philanthropic work through your actions. Your advance payment of $15,000 is much appreciated and will be allocated towards the transportation costs of your shipment. Please be assured that your shipment will be handled with utmost care and delivered to you promptly and safely.

If you have any questions or concerns, feel free to reach out to me. Looking forward to a long-lasting and fruitful business relationship with you.

Best regards,
Al

---

From: zara@importscorp.com
To: al@freightshippingco.com
Subject: Change of Delivery Point and Updated Booking Number
Timestamp: 2023-01-14 16:05
Body: Dear Al,

I would like to request a change in the delivery point of our shipment to Ho Chi Minh City instead of Haiphong. Additionally, the booking number for the shipment has been updated. Please let me know if this adjustment can be accommodated.

Thank you,
Zara

---

From: al@freightshippingco.com
To: zara@importscorp.com
Subject: Challenges with Changing Delivery Point
Timestamp: 2023-01-15 10:20
Body: Dear Zara,

We're having a hard time switching the delivery point. I've consulted with the shipping line, and the only solution they offered is to send the shipment back to Bangkok, so it can be re-routed correctly to Ho Chi Minh City. Unfortunately, this incurs a significantly high cost.

Please advise on how you would like to proceed.

Best regards,
Al

---

From: al@freightshippingco.com
To: zara@importscorp.com
Subject: Update on Delivery Point Change
Timestamp: 2023-01-16 11:30
Body: Dear Zara,

After further negotiations, the shipping line has agreed to make the necessary changes to the shipment so it can be directly delivered to Ho Chi Minh City instead of Haiphong. However, please be aware that the cost of this adjustment is still quite high. We need to discuss how to handle these additional costs.

Looking forward to your guidance.

Best regards,
Al

Best regards,

Johnathan

---
