Kind regards,

Johnathan
Johnstone Foods Ltd.

Email 1:
Hi Ms. Li,                    We have a cargo of 6,000MT to be loaded in Malabo. It must be delivered in Cape Town by 11 May. Would your company be interested in tendering?                    Thanks,                    Kris
Email 2:
Subject: Re: (RE: TENDER FOR 6000MT MALABO TO CAPE TOWN)                    Thanks for your inquiry. Our rate for this shipment is USD1,500.                    Looking forward to your reply.

Answer 1:
Subject: RE: (RE: TENDER FOR 6000MT MALABO TO CAPE TOWN)                    The rate is okay with us, but there is a problem with the transit time. Could you check your ETA for my customer? We are willing to pay more, if it will arrive earlier. Thanks

Answer 2:
Dear Alice,                    Unfortunately, we are not sure if we can achieve the ETA. Our vessel has a good speed, but if it is ballast in Malabo, it will take at least 16 days. If the cargo is loaded in Malabo, it will have to wait for our ship

Subject: Re: TENDER FOR 6000MT MALABO TO CAPE TOWN

---

From: kris@example.com
To: ms.li@shippingco.com
Subject: Re: TENDER FOR 6000MT MALABO TO CAPE TOWN
Timestamp: 2023-04-15 11:20

Subject: Re: TENDER FOR 6000MT MALABO TO CAPE TOWN

We have 6,000MT of bitumen from IADC to Maputo. Could you share your available windows and dispatch incentives?

Best regards,
Harry

---

From: jelena@example.com
To: harry@example.com
Subject: Re: Bitumen Shipment Inquiry
Timestamp: 2023-01-10 14:45
Body: Dear Harry,

Hi, I apologize for any confusion but our trade limits only allow us to work with a small network that includes petroleum engineers strictly within our company hierarchy. From: harry@example.com
To: jelena@example.com
Subject: Re: Bitumen Shipment Inquiry
Timestamp: 2023-01-11 10:05
Body: Dear Jelena,

Sincerely,
Harry

To: harry@example.com
Subject: Clarification Regarding Bitumen Shipment

Regards,
Jelena

Nitin Singhal

Timestamp: 2020-01-04 10:30

My client has requested an 11,000MT dry bulk vessel for loading at Bremer River and discharging at a Brazilian river. Please view the potential vessels via the links below:
- https://www.seasearcher.com/vessel/5429
- https://www.seasearcher.com/vessel/10676
We prefer vessels in excess of 1000MT DWT, and please note the correct spelling is 'GRANE' not 'GRANY'. Unfortunately, this current budget is constrained, hence we will not proceed with the vessel.

Best regards,
Nitin

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Michael,                    What are your terms for delivering 15,000MT of Palm oil from Rotterdam to a refinery in Manila on June 28?                    Best,                    Eva
Email 2:
Hi Michael,                    We can load 12,000MT in May and 3,000MT in June for delivery to Manila on June 28.                    Best,                    Eva

**Q1** is why did he add "on June 28" in his response to her email?
**A:** He's going to make a mistake in the June delivery date. He misremembered the date or didn't pay close enough attention to her original email.

**Q2** Do you need to read all of the emails to make that assumption?
**A:** Yes. You need to see the mistake in order to assume that. What's more, since he said something about June 28, there must have been another email asking about the delivery date.

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Mr. Flores,                    I would like to inquire about 4,700MT of naphtha from Istanbul to Zarafshan.                    If you are interested, we can begin negotiations based on your offer.                    Thank you,                    Susan
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Flores,                    According to your offer for naphtha, if you still have stock, we can negotiate based on your price.                    Susan

If the business person that you're trying to negotiate with sends an email that says, "Hello Susan," but it's really a spam bot that has auto-generated an email to look like it's from a human, the spam bot won't use your name in the reply.

According to your offer for naphtha

You can negotiate based on your price

We can begin negotiations based on your offer.

Therefore, if we see text in the email reply that doesn't match what we would expect a human to say in a negotiation reply, that's a good clue that it's a bot.

We didn't see any of that in your test cases, however. That's why I said the bot looks good. In fact, it looks
Email 3:
From: Dear Mr. Flores, I would like to inquire about 4,700MT of naphtha from Istanbul to Zarafshan. If you are interested, we can begin negotiations based on your offer. Thank you, Susan

<Email 4>:
From: Dear Mr. Flores, According to your offer for naphtha, if you still have stock, we can negotiate based on your price. Susan

much more complex than most bots out there, which usually just randomly grab a word from your email and reply with it.
Email 4:
From: Dear Mr. Flores, According to your offer for naphtha, if you still have stock, we can negotiate based on your price. Susan

much more complex than most bots out there, which usually just randomly grab a word from your email and reply with it.

<Email 4>:
 From: Dear Mr. Flores, According to your offer for naphtha, if you still have stock, we can negotiate based on your price. Susan

This would be an easy detection system for anyone who was trying to determine if an email reply was generated by a human or by a bot. It's not perfect (or rather, it's not "perfectly perfect"), but it is a way to detect spam bots.

However, what we're looking for is not just whether an email reply is generated by a bot, but whether the person that sent the email actually wrote that reply. Or in other words: Is the email genuine? Does this person exist? Is it really my friend or colleague that's sending me these messages?

What you should do to test if the email is genuine

To test whether an email is genuine, you should check two things:

1. Does the email reply
Email 5:
From: Susan

According to your offer for naphtha, if you still have stock, we can negotiate based on your price. Susan

If you're sending emails back and forth with a bot, you're probably using some sort of reply template. A human would never send an email back and forth using exactly the same template.

2. Is there any other information in the email that could be used to validate that it's really the person sending it?

To start with, you should look for:

This is a topic that I cover in more detail in my article on spotting bots.

The key here is that you can't just rely on one factor to validate whether an email is genuine. You have to combine multiple factors together. You have to ask yourself: How strong is each of these factors? How confident am I that this email is genuine? Am I still worried that it might be a

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi,                    Do you have any spares of ... model batteries??? And, would you be willing to freight them from Hong Kong to Los Angeles???                    Let me know.                    Best,                    Amin                    A sample inquiry email may take several different forms depending upon the client???s objectives. Most inquiries to a shipping company are in respect of transporting goods. In most cases, this involves the movement of relatively high volumes of goods at low prices. Examples of products such as petrol and grains fit this description. For this type of inquiry, it is most likely that the client will have prepared an extensive set of formal requirements such as sailing schedule and conditions for carriage which will accompany the inquiry letter. In this case, the inquiry letter will be the equivalent of the written statement sent to the real client.                    Now, write an email to a potential client who is enquiring about your company???s
Email 2:
My reply.                    If a company were to open a trade account with us, then we could extend credit up to $500,000. However, if a company were to open a commercial account with us, we could offer them credit of$5 million. This account is for trading products between companies, not individuals.
                    We do provide this service from both Hong Kong and Los Angeles. Also, we have offices in Sydney and Auckland. Please see our websites for more details.
                    Please feel free to contact me if you have any further questions.
                    Regards,
Email 3:
Hi Rob,
                    I am enquiring as to your ability to transport grains from your Sydney port to ours in Seattle. We would want to use your containers to ship approximately 40,000 tons of grain.
                    Could you advise me of the approximate cost and timing of delivery. Could you also supply me with a copy of the relevant carriage conditions? Please also include a contact number, name and fax number.
                    Thank you.
                    Regards,
                    Jill

<Email 4>:

                    Container service: 55,000.00
                    Insurance of goods: 25,000.00
                    Total:

Dear Ms Slater,
                    Thank you for your enquiry on the transport of grains from Sydney to Seattle.
                    As you requested, I have enclosed a schedule and conditions of carriage.
                    The estimated cost for the shipment of 40,000 tons from Sydney to Seattle is as follows:
                    Container service: 55,000.00
                    Insurance of goods: 25,000.00
                    Total:

<Email 4>:
 Total: 60,000.00
                    This total is for the cost of the shipping as well as for the cost of insuring the goods.
                    For insurance purposes, we do need a complete list of the goods to be shipped, together with an approximate value of the goods and an approximate quantity. We can then insure these goods for a fixed price. To clarify, this does not include a freight charge; the freight charge is paid by you directly to the shipper.
                    The insurance company can then quote you for the insurance of the goods.
                    We use the following insurance company:
                    A Insurance
                    New York.
                    Also, the estimated time of arrival is 1 month from the date of departure.
                    If you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to contact me.
                    Regards,
                    Sally
Email 5:
Dear Ms Slater,
                    Thank you for your request for a quote for shipping 40,000 tons of grains from Sydney to Seattle.
                    Unfortunately, we are unable to supply a firm price at this stage due to certain missing details. Specifically, the goods to be shipped are not specified, and no approximate value has been provided.
                    Also, no fixed quantity has been advised.
                    Once you provide us with these details, we will be able to give you a firm price.
                    Please provide this information at your earliest convenience.
                    Regards,
                    Sally

<Email 6>:
Dear Ms Slater,
                    We are pleased to advise you that we can offer you the shipping of 40,000 tons of grains from Sydney to Seattle.
                    The approximate cost of shipping the goods, inclusive of insurance, is $50,000.
                    To ship these goods, a quantity must be specified.

From: alice@example.com
To: zou@example.com
Subject: Inquiry for Rice Shipment from Manila to Qingdao
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 09:30
Body: Hi Mr. Zou, I am looking to ship 2000MT of rice from Manila to Qingdao. Can you give me a loading rate for the next two weeks, and does your liner include daily demurrage? Thanks, Alice

---

From: zou@example.com
To: alice@example.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry for Rice Shipment from Manila to Qingdao
Timestamp: 2023-03-02 10:15
Body: Hi Alice, The loading rate for rice from Manila to Qingdao is roughly 65 to 70 USD/MT. Please note that this rate is approximate. Our liner does not include demurrage. If you have any other questions, please feel free to ask. Sincerely, Zou

---

From: zou@example.com
To: alice@example.com
Subject: Update on Loading Rate due to New Regulations
Timestamp: 2023-03-03 15:20
Body: Hi Alice, Due to the new regulation on rice import to China, the loading rate for rice from Manila to Qingdao must be increased to around 80 USD/MT. Please let me know if you have any updates from your side. Sincerely, Zou

---

From: alice@example.com
To: zou@example.com
Subject: Requirement for Additional Shipment
Timestamp: 2023-03-04 08:00
Body: Hi Zou, We have already secured a shipment from Nantong, but we need one more shipment. The cargo will be loaded in Qingdao in June. Could you please let me know if you can provide this service? Also, could you send me a quotation as soon as possible? Thanks, Alice

---

From: zou@example.com
To: alice@example.com
Subject: Quotation for Additional Shipment from Qingdao
Timestamp: 2023-03-05 11:45
Body: Hi Alice, Thanks for your information. The rates for loading in Qingdao are as follows: 65 USD/MT with demurrage included, and 80 USD/MT without demurrage. Please confirm which option suits you best. Sincerely, Zou

Jin:      Thank you so much for your fast reply. We’re very happy to know your co-operation and support. Also, it is really great to see the favorable price of oil. Jin

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Ms. Chen,                    We have urgent need for a ship, 50,000dwt size, with good dry-bulk and / or ore carrier experience for transportation of between 20,000 and 25,000 MT of iron ore from Dampier to Yuan Island. Please confirm your vessel’s availability, draft and size, and also availability of exisiting Ballast water; when can you have your vessel at sea, and does it accept 'dumping' of cargo in the event of strike?                    We would be most grateful if you could provide a detailed specification of your vessel, including crew, safety records, and insurance policy information, by 7th August.                    We will contact you regarding further details after this date.                    Yours faithfully,                    Richard Vernon
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Vernon,            Thank you for your enquiry.            We are pleased to inform you that we have an 87,000dwt ocean-going ore carrier on our register. The vessel is 12 years old and has passed rigorous safety inspections.            She has been chartered to oil company for past 3 months and is now available from 15th August.            In the event of a strike, the vessel has the capability of ‘dumping’ her cargo.            We would be most grateful if you would advise the load port, discharge port, estimated cargo quantity, loading time, and estimated number of loading / discharging crew.            We look forward to hearing from you soon.            Yours faithfully,            Mr. Chen

<Email 3>:
Dear Mr. Chen,            Thank you for your swift reply.            With your permission, I enclose an outline of the
Email 3:
Dear Mr. Chen,            Thank you for your swift reply.            With your permission, I enclose an outline of the

<Email 3>:
 Dear Mr. Chen,            Thank you for your swift reply.            With your permission, I enclose an outline of the proposed charter, which covers the period 10th September to 31st October 2011.            In addition, I enclose a Letter of Inquiry, which we have requested from Dampier Iron Ore and from Port Walling.            I would be grateful if you would check these and advise on any corrections that you require.            I trust that the agreement will meet with your approval, and look forward to hearing from you soon.            Yours faithfully,            Richard Vernon
Email 4:
Dear Richard,            I have reviewed your letter, and I confirm that our vessel will be ready at sea by 15th August, so your preferred dates are acceptable.            With regard to the charter, the only changes that I require are the amounts and unit prices for port, light, and insurance; and the percentage of each these that are to be deducted from the charter.            I trust that these amendments will be acceptable to you.            I will revert with confirmation and insurance policy documents once we have both agreed on the terms.            Yours faithfully,            Jin Jing

<Email 5>:
 Dear Mr. Chen,            The amendments to the charter agreement are acceptable to me.            I enclose a signed copy of the charter agreement, together with a draft insurance policy.            I would be most grateful if you could confirm that the vessel is ready for loading by 17th August,
output_text:
From: r.vernon@logisticsco.com
To: ms.chen@shippingline.com
Subject: Urgent Requirement for a Bulk Carrier
Timestamp: YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM
Body: Dear Ms. Chen,

We urgently require a ship, around 50,000 DWT, experienced with dry bulk or ore, for transportation of 20,000 to 25,000 MT of iron ore from Dampier to Yuan Island. Please confirm your vessel's availability, its draft and size, including the availability of existing ballast water. Additionally, we need to know the earliest date your vessel can be at sea and whether it permits 'dumping' of cargo in event of a strike. A detailed specification of your vessel including crew, safety records, and insurance policy information is requested by 7th August.

Looking forward to your prompt response.

Yours faithfully,

Richard Vernon

---

From: ms.chen@shippingline.com
To: r.vernon@logisticsco.com
Subject: Re: Urgent Requirement for a Bulk Carrier
Timestamp: YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM
Body: Dear Mr. Vernon,

Thank you for your enquiry. We are pleased to inform you that we have an 87,000 DWT ocean-going ore carrier available, which is 12 years old and has recently passed rigorous safety inspections. It has been chartered to an oil company for the past 3 months and is available from 15th August. The vessel is capable of 'dumping' her cargo in event of a strike.

Please provide the load and discharge ports, estimated cargo quantity, loading time, and estimated number of loading / discharging crew. We look forward to your details.

Yours faithfully,
Mr. Chen

---

From: r.vernon@logisticsco.com
To: ms.chen@shippingline.com
Subject: Ship Charter Details for Ore Transportation
Timestamp: YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM
Body: Dear Mr. Chen,

Thank you for your swift reply. Enclosed is an outline of the proposed charter covering the period 10th September to 31st October 2011, inclusive of a letter of inquiry we've requested from Dampier Iron Ore and Port Walling. Please review these documents and advise on any necessary corrections.

I trust the terms meet your expectations and I await your response.

Yours faithfully,
Richard Vernon

---

From: jin.jing@shippingline.com
To: r.vernon@logisticsco.com
Subject: Re: Ship Charter Details for Ore Transportation
Timestamp: YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM
Body: Dear Richard,

I have reviewed the proposed charter and can confirm our vessel will be ready at sea by 15th August, and your preferred dates are acceptable. However, I would require amendments regarding the amounts and unit prices for port charges, light dues, and insurance, including their deductions from the charter.

I hope these changes are satisfactory. Once agreed, I'll send the confirmation and insurance policy documents.

Yours faithfully,
Jin Jing

---

From: r.vernon@logisticsco.com
To: jin.jing@shippingline.com
Subject: Final Confirmation of Charter Agreement
Timestamp: YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM
Body: Dear Mr. Chen,

The amendments to the charter agreement are acceptable. Enclosed is a signed copy of the charter agreement, along with a draft insurance policy. Please confirm that the vessel will be ready for loading by 17th August.

Thank you.

Yours faithfully,
Richard Vernon

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Mr. Jones,                    We are looking to ship 1,100MT of shoes from Rotterdam to Boston. Can you confirm your earliest available sail date, and can you let me know if you have a regular schedule?                    Kind regards,                    Anne
Email 2:
Anne,                    We would be happy to help with your shipment. Our regular weekly sailing is on the 23rd of the month. This shipment will sail on the 25th of March. Please confirm your delivery address and let me know if you have any further questions.                    Best regards,                    Don

Anne wrote back:
Hi Don,                    Yes, I think that works for us. The final destination for the goods will be Boston, MA. We will be clearing the goods through Port Newark, NJ.                    Thank you for your help!                    Anne

Later on, a similar conversation:
<Email 1>:
Hi Don,                    I’m following up about the shipping to Boston, MA. I spoke with our customs broker who said they will need to ship from NJ. Can you let me know if that will be a problem?                    Thanks,                    Anne

<Email 2
Email 3:
Hi Anne,                    NJ is not a problem. The vessel leaves from Rotterdam, then stops in Houston and NJ, before going to Boston. The final destination for the cargo is Boston, and you will clear the cargo in Boston, so that is fine.                    Please let me know if you have any further questions.                    Don

I personally hate being in this kind of situation.
- Does it matter if you clear your cargo in NJ or Boston?
- Is the stop in Houston worth including in the quote? If we talk about ports-of-call, does it mean we are talking about trans-shipments?
- What does it mean when Don said "final destination for cargo" was Boston?
In this kind of case, the shipper has spoken with their customs broker. They have consulted their maritime lawyer. They know the procedures to follow. That is why they ask you if you can handle the
Email 4:
Anne,                    The carrier for this shipment will be ZIM Lines. They will export from Rotterdam, and stop in Houston, before sailing to Boston. All shipments are delivered FCA (Free Carrier). This means the carrier will deliver the cargo at their warehouse in Rotterdam, from where you will be responsible for paying for the cargo and the customs duties. You will also be responsible for unloading the cargo, or arranging for that to be done.                    Please let me know if you have any further questions.                    Regards,                    Ed

<Email 5>
Anne,                    Can you please let me know if you have any questions about our quote? We’ve already run out of our weekly quota, so we will have to sell your cargo at market price.                    Regards,                    Don
output_text:
From: anne@shippingco.com
To: djones@freightforwarders.com
Subject: Inquiry About Shipping Schedule and Availability
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 09:30
Body: Hello Mr. Jones,

We are looking to ship 1,100MT of shoes from Rotterdam to Boston. Can you confirm your earliest available sail date, and do you have a regular sailing schedule we can align with?

Kind regards,
Anne

---

From: djones@freightforwarders.com
To: anne@shippingco.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry About Shipping Schedule and Availability
Timestamp: 2023-03-02 10:15
Body: Hi Anne,

We would be happy to assist with your shipment. Our regular schedule includes weekly sailings on the 23rd of each month. However, for your shipment, we can arrange a sailing on the 25th of March. Please confirm your delivery address in Boston, MA and let me know if you have any more questions.

Best regards,
Don

---

From: anne@shippingco.com
To: djones@freightforwarders.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry About Shipping Schedule and Availability
Timestamp: 2023-03-03 08:45
Body: Hi Don,

That date works for us. The final destination for the goods will be Boston, MA and the goods will clear customs through Port Newark, NJ.

Thank you for your assistance!
Anne

---

From: anne@shippingco.com
To: djones@freightforwarders.com
Subject: Follow-Up on Shipping Route
Timestamp: 2023-03-10 09:00
Body: Hi Don,

I’m following up about the shipping to Boston, MA. Our customs broker informed that there will be an initial handling in NJ. Will this be an issue?

Thanks,
Anne

---

From: djones@freightforwarders.com
To: anne@shippingco.com
Subject: Re: Follow-Up on Shipping Route
Timestamp: 2023-03-10 16:30
Body: Hi Anne,

NJ is not a problem. The vessel departs from Rotterdam, makes a stop in Houston, and NJ, before reaching Boston. The final destination is Boston, where the cargo clearance arrangements have been planned.

Let me know if you need more information.
Don

---

From: ed@freightforwarders.com
To: anne@shippingco.com
Subject: Details of Shipping Arrangement
Timestamp: 2023-03-11 11:00
Body: Anne,

The carrier for this shipment will be ZIM Lines. They will manage the export from Rotterdam, and stop in Houston, before continuing to Boston. All shipments are handled under FCA terms, meaning the cargo will be delivered to their warehouse in Rotterdam. You are responsible for paying for the cargo and its customs duties post-delivery, as well as unloading or arranging unloading.

Regards,
Ed

---

From: djones@freightforwarders.com
To: anne@shippingco.com
Subject: Clarification on Shipping Quotation
Timestamp: 2023-03-12 14:00
Body: Anne,

Could you let me know if you have any questions regarding our quote? Please be aware that we've already expended our weekly quota, hence your shipment cost would have to be adjusted to the current market price.

Regards,
Don

Body: Good morning Mr. Ahmed,

Your company recently dispatched a 2,800MT cargo of polyester chips from Qingdao to Genoa. I am currently looking for a similar cargo, specifically a 3,500MT shipment, to be dispersed across the Mediterranean region. Could you please provide more details about this cargo and any related upcoming shipments?

Michelle

---

From: ahmed@textileexports.com
To: michelle@globalimportsexports.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry about Recent Polyester Chips Shipment
Timestamp: 2002-06-07 14:30
Body: Hello Michelle,

Thank you for your inquiry regarding our recent shipment from Qingdao to Genoa. The cargo consisted of 2,800MT of polyester chips shipped under L/C terms with confirmation to and a requirement of 10% scrutiny (additional sample required). 

Regarding your need for a 3,500MT cargo, we plan to arrange further shipments that could meet your requirements. We will ensure the liner is ready for immediate loading with your provision for a loading sling.

Best,
Ahmed

Please provide details regarding any future shipments destined for regional ports, ideally with a 4 to 5 week lead time.

Yours sincerely,
Mike Evans
Senior Cargo Manager

- Offer No.: 8964-JK2023
- Buyer’s Reference: 1105-AC2023
- Price per Metric Ton (FOB in USD): $75.00
- Minimum Order Quantity: 55,000 MT
- Product Description: Lump Iron Ore, 55% Fe, 25% SiO2, 12% Al2O3, 0.04% P, 0.05% S, 7% Mohs, 7% SV
- Place of Delivery: Mt Lengma, East Nusa Tenggara
- Loading Port: Cilacap, Java
- Delivery Terms: FOB Destination
- Payment Terms: 100% Before Shipment
- Additional Requirements: LC

This offer is valid until further notice. Please confirm your acceptance.

Regards,
Mr. Tukang

Email 1:
Hi Phil,                    Can you suggest any cargo in NY or NJ that we can ship to our Antwerp port this weekend? It’s for a client who is in a hurry.                    Regards,                    Sam
The way you are supposed to write a business email is completely different from the way a formal letter is written.
Business Emailing Etiquette:
Write business emails in a direct, concise and informal style
Maintain a formal, respectful tone
Address the recipient by name, never by using “Dear Mr.” or “Dear Ms.” or any such title
Always include a complimentary closing at the end of the email
Check spelling, grammar, punctuation and any errors in the content
Use appropriate salutations for various situations
Choose an appropriate email subject
Use an appropriate email signature
After writing the email, add a sender’s signature, which includes your name and contact details
Avoid

John’s first email to Sam:1. The 1st time, when there is no previous correspondence, you should always start with the sender’s name, followed by a comma and your own name and address. The whole point of the sender’s name is to emphasize the directness and friendliness of the e-mail.
2. Avoid first names in your introduction until you get to know the other party. In your subsequent emails, a simple “Hi Sam” will do.
3. The first and last paragraphs should always contain the same information as the cover letter you would send if this were a hard copy. This is done to provide clarity and ensure that the recipient

output_text:
From: info@maersk.com
To: scott@example.com
Subject: Maersk confirms opening of new Singapore-Yantian-Busan-Vladivostok service
Timestamp: 2017-04-01 08:00
Body: Hey Scott,

I'm happy to inform you that we've officially announced the opening of the new SINGAPORE - YANTIAN - BUSAN - VLADIVOSTOK service. The service includes direct imports and exports to Vladivostok, operating on a full-weekly basis and is targeted to start in May 2017.

The vessel operating this route will be MV MAERSK SOUTH WALES.

The initial schedule is as follows:
YM - Yantian: Departure on Wednesday with a two-day port stay.
YB - Yantian: Departure on Thursday with a two-day port stay.
YS - Yantian: Departure on Saturday with a two-day port stay.
YV - Yantian: Departure on Monday with a two-day port stay.
Detailed schedules for Busan and Vladivostok will be communicated later.

---

From: partnersupport@maersk.com
To: partners@example.com
Subject: Updated Schedule for Yantian-Busan-Vladivostok Service
Timestamp: 2017-04-10 10:30
Body: Dear Partners,

Thank you all for your feedback regarding our new YANTIAN - BUSAN - VLADIVOSTOK service. The updated schedule is as follows:
YM - Yantian: Departure on Wednesday with a two-day port stay.
YB - Yantian: Departure on Thursday with a two-day port stay.
YS - Yantian: Departure on Saturday with a two-day port stay.
YV - Yantian: Departure on Monday with a two-day port stay.
The schedule to Busan and Vladivostok is as per the updated file shared.

The first sailings will be:
YM - Departs Yantian on Wednesday, 24/5, ETA Busan on 31/5 and ETA Vladivostok on 05/06.
YB - Departs Yantian on Thursday, 25/5, ETA Busan on 01/6 and ETA Vladivostok on 05/06.

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Ms. Hu,                    For 2,700MT of ammonium sulfate from Damietta to Koper, do you have capacity next week, and can we finalize a CP with minimal laycan buffer?                    Cheers,                    Maria
Email 2:
Dear Maria,                    Thank you for your message.                    Please be informed that we have today allocated a vessel for 2,700 MT Ammonium Sulfate from Damietta to Koper on 9/5 loading.                    In case if there are any issues, please let us know.                    Kind regards,
    Vivian

• 1. For which two events were CNF and CFR both used?
    • Ammonium sulfate.
    • Ammonium sulfate is a white granular solid.
• 2. What events does CFR apply to?
    • Ammonium sulfate is a white granular solid.
• 3. What event do I use if the shipment leaves port on 1 January but doesn't arrive in port until 2 January?

Hi Patrick,

Yes, we can do the adhesives. It would be for your information, not committed yet.

- 10 days e.t.d. including bunkers
- Detention : 0,47 €/day

Gilles

We have a 4,500MT shipment of high quality fuel ready to export from the Murmansk port. Can you provide a freight rate and advise your earliest available berth?                    Thanks,                    Marvin
Email 2:
Dear Marvin, Thank you for your email of 5th June.
Our current rates (including all charges) for the carriage of <Product> in bulk to <Country> are as follows (if you have other ports, please let me know):
Murmansk Port, Russia - Hamburg, Germany - Rotterdam, Netherlands - Le Havre, France - Antwerp, Belgium (Main ports only)
3500 metric tonnes up to a maximum of 300 metres on 34,500 DWT tankers: €200 per metric ton
3,001 to 5,000 tonnes on tankers up to 23,000 DWT: €280 per metric ton
6,001 to 12,000 tonnes on tankers up to 34,000 DWT: €280 per metric ton
12,001 to 16,000 tonnes on tankers up to 50,000
Email 3:
Dear Bryan
Many thanks for your quotation. It is a little too high. I am trying to find a carrier who can offer a more competitive rate. Can you please send me your best freight rate in bulk? I have found that another carrier has offered the following rates:
Murmansk Port, Russia - Rotterdam, Netherlands
2001 - 10000 tonnes on tankers up to 34,500 DWT: €218 per metric ton

Best regards,
Neal

To: neal@cargoexchange.com
Subject: Re: Vessel Inquiry for Naphtha Transportation
Timestamp: 2023-03-01 10:15
Body: Hi Neal,

Thank you for your inquiry. For your shipment of 9,300MT of naphtha, you could consider our Aframax vessel with the following specifications:
Vessel: Aframax
Tank Capacity: 85,000MT
Built: 2009
Flag: Marshall Islands
Technical Manager: Sevenstar Group BV
Classification Society: DNV GL
Type of Vessel: IMO2 (including capacity for 2.5% NaoH)
GRT: 111,881 mts
DWT: 76,990 mts
Length: 254.6m
Breadth: 44.8m
Speed: 13.2 kts
Deadweight Capacity: 77,000 mts
Ice Class: 1A

Alternatively, our VLCC with a tank capacity of 320,000MT built in 2015 can also be available.

Kind Regards,
Jens

---

Neal

Andres

Subject: Offer Confirmation Required
Timestamp: 2023-09-01 09:30
Body: Greetings Zohair,
FYI: The price of fertilizer (FERT) today is 2875/2845 with the last done deal at 2870 for 6000mt x 4mth fixed delivered to Tubarao. Recent transactions show prices consistently ranging from 2845 to 2870 within the last month. As these transactions were completed in a timely manner, we believe the market is on the rise, and we would like to confirm our offer at 2770. Please confirm if you are agreeable to our offer. If we do not hear from you, we will assume your acceptance.
Regards, Johannah Zabcjok.

---

From: johannah.zabcjok@cobexmarine.com.au
To: zohair@cobexmarine.com.au
Subject: Clarification on the Current Market Price
Timestamp: 2023-09-02 10:15
Body: Hello Zohair,
Thanks for the update.
In reference to our email regarding our offer of 2780: You have previously confirmed that your sales team confirmed the deals were concluded between 2845 to 2870 for 1st of November delivery. Yet, you are urging us to confirm our offer at 2770. I am puzzled by this, as the current market price is evidently closer to 2870. We would prefer to finalize our arrangements for 1st of November delivery when we are more certain the market has stabilized rather than at its current volatility. Please advise on your expectations.
Sincerely, Johannah Zabcjok.

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Sirs,                    I have the following samples ready for dispatch from Rotterdam. Could you please give me your earliest availability for transport to Karachi?                    Regards,                    Sandra
Email 2:
Dear Sirs,                    This is with reference to my email of 15 March 2010. Please note that we will be sending out the parcel on 23 March 2010. Can you please inform me the most convenient date for delivery in Karachi?                    Best regards,                    Tom 

Subject line: dOCUMENTA(13)

I think this type of conversation is a sign of a completely new kind of content. When many people read an email, they don't think too much about it. They just get the information they need to keep doing their jobs.

However, if you put the same information into a 'smartcard', suddenly it becomes very interesting. A Smartcard can contain information, documents, images, videos and even music. It can also include online links and information that can be downloaded from the Internet, as well as many other things. Smartcards can be sent as gifts

Andrew

To: andrew@example.com
Subject: Re: Inquiry about Port Availability and Assistance
Timestamp: 2023-02-01 09:15

Best regards,
Ron Liang

input_text:
Email 1:
Hey Mom,                    It’s been 6 years since we saw each other. Are you still in Hong Kong? I am now a captain in the army. I can’t believe how fast the time has gone by.
Email 2:
Dear Captain Yang,
I was glad to get your email. Yes, I am still in Hong Kong, but I will be moving to Beijing soon. Please don’t worry. I am very well, and I hope you are as well. Now you can tell me about your life. Where are you stationed? And where are your wife and children? How old are they?

<Email 3>:
Hi, Mom,
I am glad that you are still doing well. My family is fine. My children are getting bigger. My oldest is almost 6 years old, and my youngest is 4. I will have to wait a little longer until I can send you pictures of them. I am stationed near Guangzhou. My wife and I don’t see each other very often, so I guess you could say that we are basically divorced.

<Email 4>:
Hi, Captain Yang

Timestamp: 2018-08-01 09:34
Body: Dear Team,
Please confirm if we have sufficient options for DFTU 260. Currently, we have six option vessels available at Saldanha Bay, South Africa, scheduled to berth on 10/08/2018:
1. Medilink - Carrying Chlorine & Caustic Soda, Reefer available - 4000 sqm, 10000 cbm, Reefer Temp. -0 Celsius. Vessel Type: MOL MAWA.
2. ONORE - Carrying Mixed Cargo, Reefer available - 3000 sqm, 12000 cbm, Reefer Temp. + 25 Celsius. Vessel Type: MSC IMAGO.
3. ABACUS - Carrying Bulk, no reefer available. Vessel Type: Hyundai Samurai.
4. BIRGIT - Carrying General Cargo, Reefer available - 1000 sqm, 5000 cbm, Reefer Temp. -25 Celsius. Vessel Type: Tore II.
5. AKIRA - General Cargo. Details to be confirmed.
Best regards,
John Weil
